Do you hate missing point blank shots? Do you hate abstract percentages making absolutely no sense? Do you miss time units/actions points and wish you could do more than move and act once per turn? Do you like Fallout’s VATS system for targeting, damaging weapons and disabling specific limbs to confer tactical advantages? Do you like being able to free-aim in order to blow cover out so your squad can get a better shot? Do you prefer missions going sideways because you done goofed up rather than because of a bad dice roll? Do you hate save scumming and wish you could just get out of tough situations with enough smarts? Do you hate timed missions? Do you want overwatch to stop targeting the wrong enemy? Do you hate alien pods? Do you hate them interrupting your turn to disperse and hide? Do you miss base invasions? Do you miss queuing research and manufacturing? Do you miss crisis swapping gear between soldiers mid-mission? Do you miss waiting till daytime to deploy your troops to avoid night ops? Do you miss being able to do multiple things at once on the geoscape? Do you want rescue missions where you can take control of civilians and militia so they don’t do stupid stuff? Do you want to see the other factions defend themselves without you? Do you want to see them attempt to take out alien hives independently of you? Do you wish you could do raids on settlements to steal their stuff? Do you want to get creative with hybrid classes and gear so you can discover OP synergies? Do you want a more simulated, crunchier, weirder and harder sci-fi post-apoc world with conflicting factions to trade and deal with and mutating terrors from the deep to face? 

Well Phoenix Point says yes. The extra year in the oven before releasing on Steam did wonders, and I think it’s in a really good place now. It does have its quirks, rough edges and flaws but I feel these are outweighed by the things it does differently to the newer XCOMs (see above to name a few!). Of course, your mileage may vary. Neither should you.

Until the Dev team sits down, starts a fresh game on the nominal difficulty that they expect their experienced will play on (Hard?) and just do a single play-through... beginning-to-end?  And fix anything that doesn't make the slightest bit of sense?

Don't.  Buy.  It.

At some point, over the years that they've been working on this... they actually had to put EFFORT into not communicating.

Not only have the most fundamental complaints NOT been addressed, but the team has added MORE things for the alien invaders to do that make less than no sense, even inside of the lore.

I'm gonna just give ONE example:

One of the new armored Sirens casts Enrage on their proximity.  The other armored Siren now can move absurdly far across the screen, and promptly does so.  It then casts a 100% hit Mind Control on any one of your characters, AND has plenty of movement to spare.  This will cost the Siren a couple of Will Points per turn.... good thing they have a bank of something absurd like 60, right??

Alright.  Cool.  This happens a LOT.

Your mind-controlled dude then runs over and uses his med-pack on one of those Sirens.
....except.... those med packs don't WORK on the aliens.  But he's mind-controlled.  So... now they do.

Or, maybe he got poisoned before being mind-controlled.  That's another one of those 100% success enemy abilities.  Bet you wish you had one of those, eh?  Only if you have more Will Points then them.  Hint:  You won't.

Now that he's on their side, he'll run away, sit in a corner, heal himself, and act completely opposite to what mind-controlling-your-enemy-during-an-active-firefight would accomplish.  While he's sitting in that corner pumping himself full of stimpacks, your turret blasts him to bit.

But, you've got other teammates.  So you run forward, and blast him with your assault rifle.  Cool!  A good hit.  The alien is now... half-dead. Bethesda gets away with it, because mods.  They leave the door open for players to fix their legendary mess.

And that?  That's just a single battle example.  The battle I was playing right before I finally walked.

After a glitchy, buggy, dull and monotonous start to life, Snapshot have worked hard and listened to the community to give Phoenix Point a chance to survive in what's becoming a genre over saturated with average or sub-par games. I was an early backer and played that first launch where the game was an unbalanced, needlessly difficult and boring mess, but I vowed to give them time to fix it and try again.
Unfortunately, no amount of patches and hot fixes are going to fix this games core, underlying issue:
It is slow. Dull. Boring. Uninteresting. It has no personality.

Now, I'm not someone who needs a testosterone fuelled, explosion orgy in a whirlwind of death to enjoy a game. I play strategy games like Civilization, Stellaris, XCOM, Phantom Doctrine, King of Dragon's Pass, etc. But there is nothing in this game to get excited about or grip you. Even the music is this slow, constantly dragging, two tone snooze fest. I enter combat or go on a mission and have the exact same single music track as when I'm looking at the washed out 2D Base images or the dingy grey world map. The same dreary, monotonous music which literally sounds like a bored, depressed person halfheartedly playing an old piano for a boss they hate at a job they don't care about. Music sets the scene for media - it tells the audience how they should be feeling. Phoenix Point's music tells me I should be bored and depressed.

Combat likewise seems to take an age. Maps are large and mobility is low, even when maxed out, and differs wildly between troops. The maps aren't particularly varied either and seem to either be open, sparse and poorly thought out or a poorly thought out maze of buildings and corners you have to creep through.
Enemies die slowly. There's no sense of urgency and your tactical options are limited. In fact, the largest tactical option open to you is the free aim system, which allows you to selectively pick off body parts and take enemies apart piece by piece, which sounds like a great idea but again it just slows down what is already a fairly dragged out combat experience. You never feel like you've achieved anything when an enemy dies; they either meander towards you and die in a couple of shots, remain stationary and have to be ground down from a safe distance or take so long to wear down that it's relief when it's over and you can finally do something else.

The story and lore, which could have been this game's saving grace, is again halfhearted and often feels like an teenage armature writer's club trying to show off how cool and edgy and dark they are. It's lazy and self-indulgent, mixing in so many elements that I wonder if a lot of it didn't come from other ideas the writers had, which they just crow-barred into Phoenix Point because they were the only ones willing to hire them.

All of this makes Phoenix Point a game which is too simple and too complex in all the wrong places. It badly needs someone to strip out the story, speed up the combat, diversify the game in every area from aesthetics and music to game play and basically just pump some love and character into this game. There is a good game in here, but they need to rethink the core experience they're trying to offer. A slow, thoughtful game is all well and good but it can't be slow and thoughtful all.the.time. Especially when you're facing down a horde of monsters, or subduing a gargantuan mutant terror or defending your base or raiding another faction and in between doing these things the game and story needs to progress. There is potential in here, but the game needs to find another gear.

Also, £46 for this game? lol, just no.

Phoenix Point (PP) plays okay like whitebread on mayonnaise but lacks the soul of a game that originates from its own creation. It fails to recreate its own growth on the branch that it originates from by trying too hard to be new but too similar to be fun. 

The lore feels like it's treating you like a hero protagonist in a stephen king novel written by Jordan Peterson, never calling you commander but depending on you to survive against lobsters and thus giving you all its information and breaking the 4th wall at every turn to succeed. The things you do never feels earned or rewarded, combat feels less fun and after spending 12 hours and losing one person due to a misclick, it just feels wrong. Original oldXCOM had you field dozens of soldiers, and your attitude was, Drago, if he dies he dies. PP places failure and death on optional while the game slides more and more into the ocean of mediocrity. It could have been great as a Peter Molyneux Project. 

While combat atmosphere does better than XCOM by Firaxis, PP being more scary, dark, atmospheric and accurate while not relying on RNG but by giving you the full line of sight ability from each squad member to dictate individual shooting actions (when you have control). But due to certain perspective bugs of your squad's overwatch inability, and being unable to choose where/when to fire during overwatch, means you will see bullets hitting walls/trees when defending. This feeling of the game giving the ability to escape from RNG but failing to perform its function due to technical incompetence became really annoying and ended many feelings of a good combat turn.

Beyond shooting and missing, the fear of danger quickly disappears early/mid game. Because PP overworld (geoscape) gives almost weekly reports (every 10-30 minutes) of creature mutation and stats as "intel report", but your imagination or even the game studio's imagination is never held up to par by being suspenseful to your next encounter. We're suppose to be doing research to find out WHY/WHAT is attacking us, but weekly reports of literal body/weapon stats and all gear the enemy aliens are holding is never hidden and always being spoiled per session. Like watching a sci fi channels but knowing every twist and turn, what is the point of playing if we know all the aliens already?

What's does it in even worse is the mutations almost doesn't matter. There's these 4 legged humanoids, and one that has 2 more legs and a snake monster. This isn't deadspace, they don't evolve based on where you shoot them. Then RNG attachments get artificially assembled onto the bodies like a malfunctioning Toy Stories factory by adding things like shields, guns or melee scythes onto each humanoid and that is all there is, some of them shoots, some of them hide and shank you, but it really doesn't matter in the scheme of exploring the unknown since nothing unknown in a stereotypical alien shit done over a decade ago. 

Then there are the NPC factions that you can either ally or steal from, but it's difficult to create empathy or hatred when one's about fascism/biology-cybernetics, one's about religion/psy-magic and the last is a communist/eco-terrorists, they never grow socially or politically. but they all impact the dwindling supply of human population when they get attacked or tampered with, so if they all die, your game ends. The only three human factions left are so politically polarised and by not uniting to face a common growing threat, it just does not make sense and is never addressed beyond they are just different triangles trying to be circles.

PS. There's mods on nexus but, mods can only change so many things, ideally tweaks and not bugs nor content.

Honourable mentions of Firaxis XCOM, even the 2k XCOM, OldXCOM, Xenonauts and Phantom Doctrine for having some soul. Technically this PP is mediocre.

I don't massively dislike this game, but I completely understand -- and agree with -- the more mixed reception it has.

As an XCOM-esque game, Phoenix Point is *fine* at best, but struggles massively in terms of balance, polish, and direction.

The aiming system is unique, but flawed at times and a bit of a nuisance when it shouldn't be. The geoscape elements are interesting at first, but feel under-developed and without much actual guidance for how you should proceed. My current game seems to be going well, but I couldn't tell you why, as I get the feeling I'm doing something wrong, and that the game will eventually punish me for it when it's already too late to change that.

Which leads to my other point; the balance is way off. Enemies in Phoenix Point become absurdly strong out of nowhere. I like difficult games, especially when they're strategy based, but the enemy factions will soon trounce you by a matter of attrition, when they have more action points than you could feasibly obtain.
I'm sure you could Google the optimum way to play this game so that doesn't happen, but, that's dumb. I don't play strategy games to steal someone else's strategy. 
At the start, this game feels way too easy, and then it's suddenly way too difficult; feeling cheap and unearned. There's no sense of the enemy factions advancing quicker than you. It's as if somebody flicks a switch and they're suddenly 4x more advanced than they were one in-game week ago.
At the time of this review, I am hoping to give the game more time and see if it improves, but, I was utterly hooked by XCOM 2 before my 9th hour of it, but by my 9th hour of Phoenix Point I'm not even sure if I can bring myself to finish it.

A real shame, honestly. There's a lot of neat stuff here, but it is undermined by baffling design decisions and a lack of polish. If I could sum it up in one word, it would be this: unfinished.

I want to like Phoenix Point, I waited for the YOE and even retried 2 months later but the game is strange in the sense that always when it's about to scratch the itch, it just reminds you why it doesn't (so far).

It works fine, never crashes and few bugs or glitches. However it constantly leaves you confused or frustrated when it doesn't have to. Things feel different and changed only for the sake of difference and change. You get many choices that don't matter and then few or no choices when they would matter the most.

Individual perks, multiple classes and a dual class option... well that's great! But the first class is pre-selected for you and the perks are completely random, and are often irrelivant since a few missions would net you the same result. Hmm... alright tell me about second class? Well that is important... so good luck. Oh and we hid some of the class options, better jump through some hoops to see them. Now that that's done, the new options aren't very good.

Alright I found some recruits and can fill my 6 soldier aircraft... but missions allow 8 soldiers, and very soon you need all you can bring. So now you need a bigger slower aircraft or multiple ones, but they vary in size and speed so now you are stuck organizing a time-distance multi vehicle carpool. Not exactly action packed gun blasting alien exploding combat.

Better give my soldiers pistols, pistols shoot bullets. Warning: 'Not proficient with weapon'. Ahh the majority of my soldiers doesn't know how to use a handgun.

We want the player to be on the offense and engage - so soldiers lose more stamina the longer missions go on! Great I get to play aggressive instead of an overwatch competition. Well... about that, see the enemies get stronger faster than your squad and there are more of them so you are at a considerable stat and action point disadvantage. Not to worry though, we put the most powerful action point leveler on the overwatch skill... so welcome back to the overwatch competition.

My soldiers are running low on stamina so I'll swap some out for fresh ones. Recruits are plentiful but base located, whereas equipment is global and takes time to be made, even with plenty resources. So now starts the ever tedious deequip and requip. Join this with your pre-selected soldiers... and your squad members pretty much become numbers.

Base building is there, still for anyone capable of solving a 4 piece puzzle it is a non concern.

The tactical combat
Step 1. Get full cover. Step 2. Fire from full cover. Step 3. Soldier steps completely out of full cover to ensure maximum enemy overwatch activation and return fire damage received.

Haven defense. Ah, defenders advantage! Nope random spawns. You and faction soldiers spawn far away, enemies spawn at their objective. You can try hard offense and rush it... that load or restart button isn't there for decorative purposes.

Your rifle won't dent a wall, your pistol one shots it, but only works on some walls and you don't get to know which. Other times you dash your squad for that line of sight to kill that crucial target... but the cruel forest monster and his many friends have set up quite a few indestructible walls of invisibility which block your bullets with magic.

This continues onward and you send your best squad half around the globe only to find out the mission was a dialog popup. You get better armor and defense against explosions, which is then bypassed by poison, and viruses, and there is fire, also acid, then all armor then gets nullified by armor penetration. So it's pretty much a full blown 'ADD' - Rock, Paper, Scissors, Lizard, Spock, Old MacDonald had a farm, Hey Macarena!

So it's strange. It has all the core ingredients, it's stable and with neat mechanics... yet comes out as a story of many good things that were or could have been, but are not now and can't be seen on the horizon, which I don't understand. The combination of current state + DLC's + console direction + no real workshop/mod/community unfortunately indicates the game will continue on a linear path towards simple and quite guided playthroughs, whereas I'd champion variety and replayability. And it appears even if they developer doesn't want to play around with such things, they seem to take steps so others can't either. Which unfortunately puts it in a box of non-recommend.

Still I'm fine with putting down around $40 for it, it is way beyond many others and whatever my capabilities could create... but I'd much rather be at $60 and have a full potential and recommendable version.

88101926.review:
Despite Phoenix Point's legacy in Gollop's own design; it feels.. off. There are great systems, but they feel unbalanced against each other to the detriment of moment-to-moment gameplay. As such, and much in the same way as XCOM's own spin-off, Chimera Squad, the game leaves an impression of being a clone of something better: a shame, given the reality of the game's roots.

There is plenty of innovation to the developer's credit, but the combination of these systems falls short of what makes Firax's games so compelling. Many have put this down to the drab environments and weak customization elements. They are not wrong; a lack of connection to the world and your squad is one of the great successes of the XCOM series. However, the main problem with Phoenix Point is how loosely the individual systems fit together.

Despite XCOM 2's RNG map design; most maps worked well with the characters, providing an experience that was both tight and open, with pod positions feeling crafted for either maximum challenge or maximum power-fantasy. No turn felt wasted. By contrast, Phoenix Point's few visually appealing maps are open shooting galleries, won only by attrition, with little scope for tactical flair. The least visually appealing maps, the "mist" areas, are drab corridor shooters, made worse by what seems like a good system on paper - the friendly fire mechanic.

And this is really what sums up Phoenix Point; great ideas, but a failure to really understand why less is sometimes more. This leaves Phoenix Point feeling like less than the sum of its parts.

Replacing RNG with a manual aim and specific body targeting does little to enhance gameplay due to the map design. The evolving enemies seem promising, but  enemies feel indistinct and unpredictable, which although counter-intuitive, is essential in a tactics game. Despite the increased action points, characters feel immobile, leaving the game feeling more like a cover shooter, rather than the refined, perceived-high-risk, plasma-infused game of chess that XCOM has become. 

I won't say much about the overworld; it feels well crafted - there is some additional complexity, but much of it feels like busy work, with little indication as to what is a priority and what isn't. The sense of relevancy may be there in subsequent playthroughs, but that doesn't help sell the game on the first run.

To summarize; if it were a board game, I would have created my own rules after the first game and then found great enjoyment in it; let's hope future workshop support or updates makes this the case. Do I dislike it? No. Do I feel like it has the potential to be better than XCOM? Sure. Will I be playing more? With the workshop support for XCOM, probably not anytime soon. Would I recommend it? On sale, yes. Am I being harsh? Perhaps, the long journey to steam was unlikely to help  manage expectations.

87410953.review:
So I just cleared my first lair (tier II Pandoran Nest) and have to say: It was a blast!

Booted up my game maybe two weeks ago on Hero difficulty. First Playthrough, XCOM and Xenonauts Veteran, all good. I love the Overwatch mechanics and rely on it pretty heavily. Playing it safe. Lost no soldier so far *tap on shoulder* and eager to keep it that way.
In the lair though... Jesus. The Devs really did a great job here with level design. So I do my usual business, planning out a route to take through the rocky maze, search&destroy the objective, setting up overwatches and anticipating those creepy fishmen to poke around the wrong - or right - corners. Jokes on me!
The angles in this stupid lair were so... alien - literally - that they were jumping all over their supid stalagnites, taking podshots at me and retreating behind a solid wall with no easy way for me to retaliate... And I loved that. It's their home after all, they should have the upper hand, right?
So change of tactics, more rush, got the lair, all good. First mission to have all but one of my six soldiers injured, a couple even seriously hurting.

Why am I writing this? Because I feel like people are not giving Phoenix Point the credit it deserves. You get a lot of bad feedback on google that is some years old, and people still complain in this comment section that the game is not as far as it should be so long after its first release. I take a look at this game now - with fresh eyes - and I see a solid game. I don't see the balance mess it might have went through. And I think it's important to judge the game in the state it is in now and not how it came here.

Plus I can't really relate to much of the bad feedback I've read about:
I don't feel my troopers are cannonfodder or oneshots. As I said, I haven't lost anyone yet. But I also try to give them 20 strength asap - totaling to 200HP. Maybe I haven't encountered the one-shot enemies yet though. I don't know. The biggest thing I came across was a Chiron so far. And they are... annoying, but far from deadly - on their own.

I don't think there are too many ambushes or missions. If you don't want missions, what do you play the game for anyway? Skip to Outro? And besides the tutorial does tell you that there will be much to handle and you can't possibly be everywhere. So feel free to let that haven decide its own fate.

Tutorial - another curator mentioned that the game is really sparse on info? Cannot relate. While the little intro story arc is great and puts a lot of info up front, basically everything new is explained to you as soon as you encounter it in the open.

Much to do. That's right. Especially with all the DLCs enabled I feel there is a lot of front-loaded content and I did feel a little overwhelmed on what to do. And what matters and what is just fluff. Getting a second and even third team asap is probably mandatory. Have them do the explore and haven defense missions, while your Alpha team does the quest and nest missions.

Reddit super-soldier guides? The game being punishing on "casuals"? I don't know about this. I am for certain not a casual, but I haven't read on guides or anything (besides of weapon stats in the wiki) to keep afloat. I'm not even multiclassing much, because often I feel those 50XP are better spent on the base stats than just a second class.
My A-Team is rocking 4 assaults with the ARES-AR1 (standard) assault rifle and an Odin (standard) grenade
1 heavy with a Deceptor MG, the Neurazer for stunning and an Odin grenade
1 sniper with a Pythagoras VII Laser sniper rifle and the CYPHER standard pistol
Throw in a medkit and a spare magazine for everyone and you are good enough to go. Only multiclass is one Assault/Sniper. I'm pretty damn sure this is far from any Terminator meta build. It is possible is all I say.

But I don't want to sound like too much of a fanboy. There is of course downsides.

The "strategic" UI - especially for manufacturing - is a mess. Lots of scrolling, little quality of life. I would much prefer to have all your active ships with shortcuts on the side instead of having to iterate through them. Hell, I play the geoscape on "slow" because I lose track of what's happening otherwise. With just 3 Manticores (planes). 

From time to time the game stutters. It's probably bugged, because it doesn't always happen with the obvious elephant in the room (like a mist sentinel covering half the map in fog), but often when coming out of the Free Aim or after throwing grenades... But since this is a turn based game I don't have much issues with this. Let it lag out a couple seconds and you're good to go. If not, then most likely after your next shot it's good again.

The game somehow makes you feel bad. Kind of. For example I am on 6 bases now, meaning 12 plane and 12 vehicle capacity. But I only have 3/12 planes and 2/12 vehicles. Which at the start made me think I am progressing way too slow. But lacking the materials there's really nothing you can do about it.
The actual truth is: Less is more. You will probably have a lot of spare capacities and building slots at all of your bases. Feel free to even demolish excess stores or facilites you won't be using. The materials are better spent elsewhere. And that's the premise of the game I feel: You are scratching together a last line of defense. You are not dominating a virus.

Lack of progression. That's kind of true. You don't progress upwards much. There's no better weapons. Just different weapons. You progress wide, though. Up that one 4-man team to a 6-man and two 3-man/1-car teams and you know that you made progress. Starting to cover the area with scans (which are by the way another materials trap!!! You don't need them everywhere) and mist repellants also does feel like establishing a foothold. But not really progression.
Lore-wise I try to explain this with the timescale. You are dealing in hours in Phoenix Point, other than in XCOM or Xenonauts where you deal in days and months. Of course you won't make technological leaps in that timeframe, but rather finding something different to more suit your needs - for example the Synedrion laser sniper rifles.

Just think about it. There are 60+ People STARVING per day in each haven because Pandoravirus makes agriculture and scavanging almost impossible. That should give you a good idea of what state humanity really is in. The game could maybe do a better job at setting the stage, but once I realized this for myself almost all of the aspects of the game made much more sense to me.

TL;DR
Phoenix Point is an uphill battle. And it feels like it.
I appreciate it. Retrospective I would have also spent 50€ on it.

You can't review Phoenix Point without comparing it to X-COM, and I would say they are siblings rather than rivals. Some of the mechanisms are similar, if not the same, but Phoenix Point throws in it's own mix of features that separate it from the "original inspiration". 

The graphics and sound are clear and precise, so certainly don't distract from the game, but they do not add any wow factor either. 

The wide range of classes available for your troops, as well as both the genetic and cybernetic enhancements, give you plenty of scope to play, although you will soon find you end up with squads with the same mix of skills and abilities, as some combinations just don't work. 

The political turmoil you find yourself in, with the 3 other factions, adds an extra dimension to your play. Do you make friends with all, just a few, or none at all? What technology the factions possess goes some way towards helping you decide. Do you get some specific tech quickly by stealing it as the risk of having that faction dislike you to the point of war, or do you build up trust and friendship to gain access to all their tech at a much slower rate?

With the wide range of enemy types, that updated technology is a must. Your starting weaponry is good enough for the initial aliens, and the occasional bandit, but when the Siren's appear on the scene, you best have something a lot better. Those can wipe out an unprepared squad quite quickly.

There are a few bugs that can be annoying. The main one being that some "once per turn" abilities can indicate they have been used when in fact they haven't. When that happens, you just have to spend the turn keeping your troops out of trouble.

All in all, this is a great game with plenty of scope for doing your own thing. I ended up taking 400 hours to "finish" it, as I spent a lot of time doing side missions, building up my squads, and chasing achievements.

It's definitely a worthy successor to the original X-COM line.

Big fan of the more recent XCOM games, Phoenix Point is not up to that level for me. The game feels too long, for one. 80+ hours for the main campaign, I'm not sure I was anywhere under that for XCOM2, but I was really starting to feel it by the end in Phoenix Point.
The good :
- Targeting system is original, and works well (although it is annoying you keep getting shot in the head, though)
- Tactical combat feels good and interesting. All the basics are there, plus a couple new things (see above) that are welcome.
- Enemies are nice. There are only around 5 or 6 main enemy types, but with mutations they feel very different, and evolve nicely as you progress in the game
- Factions relations are interesting, especially as you get nice techs from them.
- Devs seems pretty active fixing stuff, adding content, etc. 

The not so good :
- Missions are very repetitive...
- Weapon progression is boring. When I got a new gun (through factions or research), I always feel excited and build one ASAP to try it out in the field. But usually, they don' t make much difference. The assault rifle from NJ or Synedrion have like 10 damage difference... One has a little more range, the other more damage, but really, they're the same. Then you get an improved AR, and it does a touch more damage with a sprinkle of piercing... Sure, it's better, but it doesn't feel worth the time researching it...
- Weapons again, but a bit different : Explosive are useless past the very beginning of the game. You'd expect a grenade to pack more punch than an assault rifle. It really doesn't. The only point to the grenade launchers is that they can lob grenades and shoot over walls. But really if you can get a direct shot with a rifle, it gets way more efficient.
- Last point on weapons : additional effects (poison, fire, etc.) feels useless. Virus is good, but I think that's the only effect I actually used other than because I thought "hey, my soldier is equipped with it, let's use it, maybe it will this time prove better than just shooting the guy".
- Too many soldiers. Managing 3 different crafts by end game with three teams of soldiers, you sorta get lost in who's where doing what... And that's not counting the empty crafts exploring and pumping ancient artefacts.
- Skills are boring too... Especially high level. I don't think I used most of the high level skills of my soldiers. Some lower level I used all the time. But too few.
- Difficulty : Maybe I got used to tactical combat games and got real good (also, not afraid to load a game when I lose a soldier), but I played on Veteran, and didn't lose one soldier (never loading more than once, when in XCOM I would sometimes have to save scum a bit to keep my squad alive...), got 100% with all factions, didn't lose even half of the world population... Tactical combat is pretty balanced, I'd say, but the overall world mission is too easy. Steal a craft from a faction ?

Overall, I liked the game. I'm really in love with tactical combat games, at the moment, and Phoenix Point is a great example. But there is a load of little things that could have made it better, less boring. I played Firaxis' XCOM2 3 times. Not sure I'll replay this one. (But then again, I understand lovers of the old XCOMs will like Phoenix Point better...)

TLDR: Phoenix Point is a solid but imperfect turn-based tactics game that, if you enjoy the genre and can live without sophisticated strategic gameplay or a compelling story, probably deserves your dinero.

The free aim / visual targeting system during tactical combat is by far PP's best feature - much more fun than the RNG 'dice roll' mechanics of previous games in the genre and, I hope, something we see more of. In essence, you freely direct a camera representing the selected character's POV, zooming in and out and panning around until you find something you want to shoot at. The 'accuracy' of the weapon you are firing is represented by a circle (which scales as you zoom) within which all your shots will land in - the smaller the circle, the more accurate your weapon. Cover is just whatever blocks you or your target from view - your units will duck / flatten themselves against what is nominally highlighted as 'low' and 'high' cover but really the important thing is what proportion of your character's body is hidden behind something that can't be shot through.

With this free aim system and individual hit location effects, combat becomes about surgically disabling enemy weapon systems, targeting unarmoured limbs, and finding shooting angles that keep you as little exposed as possible. The enemies develop stronger and stronger armour as the game progresses but, by finding each enemy's weak points, carefully thinking about the order your units attack in (some weapons penetrate armour, some don't penetrate armour but shred it, some don't do much damage but can stun enemies, etc, etc) and using a small handful of special abilities that higher level characters get, defeating them always feels like a mini puzzle game rather than an RNG dice throw. 

It does feel like this base system could be built on much further but, as the first game (that I know of anyway) to use this sort of system, it's a great new way to approach turn-based tactical combat that feels fun and satisfying. 

Likewise, the pseudo-Lovecraftian lore and way it combines - eerily, given 2020 - mass pandemics and climate change into a horror-survival narrative also feels like a fresh take on a familiar theme... though equally somewhat under-utilised. There are some nice world building text descriptions during 'random encounters' on the strategic-level map but a few more details that supported world-building in the tactical maps would have been welcome.

The main problem with PP is that, with all love for the game, it does become pretty boring during its longish midgame. There aren't enough variety of enemies (the much vaunted 'adapting enemies' means not much more than sometimes the same basic enemy will have a grenade launcher and sometimes they won't) or of biomes / map types or of mission varieties so that, by the midgame, you've seen nearly (nearly...) everything the game has to offer.

Added to this, the minimalist soundtrack, while brilliantly atmospheric at times, is generally so minimalist that you're often playing in near silence and a limited palette of customisation options and little ability to give your units personality meant I was never as invested in individual characters as I was in, say, the later XCom games. 

Finally, on the negatives, while the tactical game is great, the strategic layer is very minimal, 'diplomacy' not worthy of the name, and - most of a problem for me - there just wasn't enough character or narrative to keep me hooked. There are few NPCs to provide emotional content and a very thin overarching story that doesn't have enough dramatic hooks to keep you invested in a story. 

In conclusion, if you're looking for a game with a story that will keep you captivated (such as Banner Saga) or on the edge of your seat (such as XCom 2 et al) or involved strategic or diplomatic gameplay, then I think you'd be disappointed in PP. However, if you think you'll be satisfied with a solid tactical turn-based game with some light strategy elements and a focus on innovative, if not earth shattering, combat mechanic then I reckon you'll be happy enough.

[h1]Very X-COM Like, but not X-COM[/h1]
This is for the Year One Edition. So it means reviewing the game with the DLC and all the patches and improvements. Unsurprisingly the game has a lot of X-COM feel. but there are some key differences. It's possible you won't feel as invested in the game as with X-COM and I'll touch on the why's of that a few times. 

I do recommend it, but there are reasons why you might still be disappointed. So do the "reading all the words" thing if part of what you liked about X-COM was really making your team super and you actually felt your individual soldiers had personalities and you really loved the story. 

On the other hand if the X-COM combat felt a bit tedious at times or formulaic or you found there was a certain soldier class you just wished could do a little bit more, PP fixes that. If you wanted a different type of geoscape/base building meta. If you thought X-COM didn't always feel grand enough, you too might want to read all the words.

[b]How it's different from X-Com[/b]
Pheonix point pushes you to not care about your soldiers as much. It provides mechanisms that allow you replace them faster and more readily. It pushes you to develop multiple teams. This is still a tough thing for me since I don't like losing soldiers and I don't like save scumming so when you get a bad mission draw and things happen that you have very little chance to avoid that get soldiers killed it frustrates me a lot even though I know it likely won't really stop me from progressing. It's not a bad mechanic, if you embrace it I can see how it makes the game feel like a more desperate fight. But this is a hard point for me and I can see how it would make you like the game less even you don't really get why. 

[b]All Your Bases Are Belong to Us[/b]
Lots of bases, and you'll need them. You don't need to develop them all, but with how scanning works in the current version (it's automatic and "constant" once you have the facilities compared to having to manually trigger them in earlier versions) you do need to active a few bases. So it's a very different Geoscape meta from X-COM. I'm OK with this, I just wish that controller navigation worked better. I just have too many issues with not realizing I have a aircraft selected when I'm going to check out a base and since they don't just give specific buttons to the actions when you have a base selected I can accidentally redirect a flight to a base when I was just intending to inspect it to start a repair/upgrade. This isn't really an issue with KB/mouse. But I actually prefer the controller for the combat. I'm odd.

[b]Combat[/b]
You have more actions in Pheonix point, that alone gives more flexibility. You still have the issue where range is way more important than accuracy, but the free aim does help a little with this. There are still times where your full aim circle is completely within the target and you still miss, but it's not as common as a 99% hit chance missing in X-COM once you are used to it. [b]I certainly like combat better in Pheonix Point than X-COM[/b] This is also aided by smaller maps quicker engagement speed, less need to hunt for that one last jerk of an alien. But as mentioned everything is more fragile in PP compared to X-Com. You and the enemy both, even the big armored enemies you face will go down faster, sometimes because of the teamwork you can bring to focus on them more readily. All of your soldiers have more flexibility than in X-COM so it easier to adapt to most situations. Though you do still run into issues where you just get flattened and you don't really have much chance to respond.

[b]You aren't meant to save everyone[/b]
You can, but the way things work they want you to side with just one, maybe two, of the three factions and then you the other as your punching bag to get the various resources you need or want. It really is a lot simpler to just raid one of the factions for a vehicle or tech or food or supplies than just about anything else at certain stages of the game.

[b]Healing is weird[/b]
Your broken limbs heal instantly after battle, but your HP need a medical center. Your stamina is supposed to matter but it doesn't matter until you get to a really a low break point. So this does lead to some situations where you hang around at the end of missions using medpacks to heal the HP damage on everyone so that you can have that team in action again much faster because the fact that one soldier had both legs and arm and their head disable doesn't matter, you can go fight an Pandoran incursion 30 minutes later and she's all good. The mechanics are in place to make it much more interesting, and with how they push you to not care as much about soldiers and develop more of them the missed some opportunities. The simplest for me would be that having a limb disabled is a stamina hit. You have 40 and it really doesn't matter until you get under 10 and a mission only takes like 2 most of the time. So if you lost 5 for a disabled limb then yeah the BS stuff would suck, but it still doesn't stop you from rapid deployments unless your getting disabled a lot. So flying back to a base and just dropping that soldier off to recover and grabbing another would be another strategy layer to add.

[h1]If you like X-COM you'll probably like PP[/h1]
There is more combat, it will be with more squads, this will force you to learn new tactics because you just won't have your A-Team all the time. This will actually make you enjoy things more and make you more effective. You may get tired of it, you may realize that certain mission types just annoy you with risk reward and you'll skip them. But in it's current state, that's OK because there is always something to do for most of the game. You may feel more disconnected from the game than you did with X-COM. The story is not delivered as forcefully, you don't get as invested in your troops. You might get annoyed with how black and white all three factions see things when you sit there seeing all the obvious ways that at least any 2 of them could combine and make even more awesome stuff, admittedly it's hard to see how all three could coexist.

This is a thumbs up but I want to let people know what to expect and highlight some flaws. In general, this is a fun game and you can sink a lot of hours into it and enjoy yourself.

However, if you're coming over from modern Xcom you need to know a few things. They have the same framework but their mechanics are very different at times. Cover really only acts to conceal your soldiers from gunfire by making them bigger or smaller targets. You don't have a % chance to  miss a shot, you have general odds of EACH ROUND going into a specific zone and if one or multiple enemies (or allies) are in that zone they are at risk of getting hit. Free aiming is newly implemented and let's you pick off certain body parts or weapons (very cool and useful). You also get to pick which lanes your soldiers overwatch, which is extremely helpful, but the enemy will take notice and attempt to thwart you through movement. Also, make sure you don't set yourself up so an enemy can pull overwatch through one of your own soldiers (a hilarious fuck up that will cost you a soldier to friendly fire.)

This game lacks certain quality of life features. Examples: your soldiers use action points (AP), which are represented by a bar made up of 4 slivers (each is an AP). The game gives you general information about how much AP will be used moving a character or performing certain actions but there are times (infuriating times) where your character will be left with what looks like 1 AP, which is sometimes all you want or need, but in reality you actually have just a teensy bit less than 1 AP (which generally leaves your character dead,

The overworld HUD will draw your attention to, audibly alert you to, and constantly mark faction havens that are under attack. You will not be alerted in a similar manner when your own bases are threatened. You instead receive a silent text alert in the top right corner of the HUD that you can click on. This cost me several bases.

You will need to remember the names and locations of your bases because the game does not do a great job of easily making it known which bases are where and what resources you are sending to which parts of the world. This caused me to many times back out of what I wanted to do and click around until I found the base, briefly memorized the name, and then clicked back into what I was doing.

When a friendly faction comes under attack you will see two numbers: Attacking strength and defending strength. As far as I can tell, these numbers only mean something if you're going to let the battle autoresolve because you might think that a defending strength of 11 to attacking strength of 3 means you're going to have significant ally support. You'd be wrong. You might have 3 allies on the map and sometimes they will just plain skip their turn and get massacred. Do not rely on them.

Remember how pissed you were when one of your soldiers got mind controlled? Brace yourself because certain enemies can mind control multiple characters (they will then smartly hide so that you cannot break the mind control easily). In short, enemy mind control rocks, yours does not. 

Do not expect the constant feeling of progression in technology that you got from Xcom. The weapons you can get pretty early will pretty much be what takes you through the game. I found the other weapons to be more lateral moves than upward ones. Useful for niche encounters or enemies but not going to make your strong characters feel mightier.

Something unique about this game that separates it from the rest in the genre, but it's like a bunch of ideas were independently developed by a bunch of different people and then hastily stitched together. The result a pretty ugly mess, despite each individual feature being interesting. 

Last year of changes have essentially been bug squashing (a good thing), adding in more stitched together content with DLCs (a bad thing, imo), and simplifying/easing the new player experience (instead of teaching the players and informing them of the mechanics) regardless of how it affects the game overall (a bad thing, imo).

Good:
* Nearly bug free finally
* Functional Tactics/Strategy portion
* Different theme than the usual spacecraft and grey/green aliens
* Lots of customization of skills, stats and equipment - but not particularly balanced
* The nature of Humanity's distrust between factions despite an existential crisis.
* Vehicles in a Tactics game is pretty cool
* Freedom of choice (both a good thing and a bad thing)

Bad:
* Animations aren't all complete or somewhat broken. 
* UI isn't complete. Lacks information. Pretty generic and nothing stands out.
* Environments are cluttered and blocky, don't feel organic enough. Don't provide an interesting tactical experience.
* Few palettes between maps. 3 for Anu, 3 for NJ, 3 for Synedrion.. all very similar. 1 "jungle ruins", 1 cave, 1 annoyingly ugly crusty cluttered alien thing (the lair), 1 prettier alien thing (the citadel), 2 ruined industrial yard (grassy or dirty) --- some special maps use a mixture of these (forgot to mention the 6 or so different LoA maps)
* Height variation in maps only exist within destructible terrain (buildings), no hills or rivers or ditches
* Story Mission design is basic and resembles regular missions - leads to far too much repetition
* Map design is too cluttered and nonsensical - objectives in all maps tend to play the same as all other maps.. nearly every mission feels the same, regardless of the actual differences (especially in regards to tactics to overcoming the mission/enemies)
* Player is overpowered, difficulty is nonexistent (Legend here is the same as Easy in War of the Chosen basically) - customization of skills/stats/equipment can create living gods among your troops. Enjoy beating missions in 1-3 turns with no challenge or satisfaction resulting from feeling like you pieced together a puzzle... because you're "solving" the same "puzzle" over and over again.
* Faction Diplomacy is basic to the point of actually being detrimental to the experience
* RPG elements clash with strategy/tactics elements of the game causing both aspects to suffer. * Resource gain is unpredictable unless you Raid/Trade - raiding can be exploited - resources can be negligible - everything else becomes pointless as a result - trading is a tedious act of click to move to a point, drag a slider, select, click to move to a point, drag slider, select, repeat indefinitely. more aircraft trading, more you're doing this.

Took me a while to finish my first campaign, but I can say it just clicked for me in a way XCOM2 never did.
My biggest gripe with XCOM2 is that everything runs on countdowns which eventually put me off so much that I've never finished a campaign on that one.
In PP however, countdowns are used sparingly and make more sense.

The free aiming system, which some people dismiss as 'gimmick', is quite fun to use and has its uses beyond the 'cover as large an area as possible on the bad guy'. E.g if an enemy has no means to hurt you anymore, he's basically taken off the board. So if someone has just a 2-handed weapon and you shoot off one of his arms (or destroy the weapon), he's no threat anymore.
It also gives more immersive feedback on your hitchance than a simple number; and since a lot of the weapons fire in bursts and each projectile is rolled seperately, it doesn't need to artificially roll a 'glance' or similar for you, you just hit with 3 out of 6 bullets on a bad shot and that's it.

The 7 classes can be combined into 21 different 'cross-classes' (since Sniper/Heavy is the same as Heavy/Sniper) and while some combinations are more obvious than others, each ability has at the very least their niche where it comes handy. Each person also has up to 3 random perks which can make a difference in what class-combination and what combat role they'd be best suited for.
Mutations and augments add additional variety and further abilities - I was quite surprised how much room for theorycrafting and experimentation is in this game.

However, the UI is adequate at best:
- there are no standard gear layouts or 'unequip all' buttons
- the manufacture and equip screens lack sorting options (the default order of items is just a mess) ...
- ... and are using not enough space on the screen which leads to way too much scrolling, especially if you don't know exactly what you're looking for while you haven't memorized the names or looks of items (and even if you know the names, there's no search function).

All in all, 'twas fun and well worth the time.

85604970.review:
Let's call this a review for people who've played one of the three XCOM remakes. Did you like those? Were you hoping for a fresh take from the godfather of the genre? Well then get Chimera Squad or Long War. 
I really want to like Phoenix Point. The aesthetics are great, it's a world three Crab apocalypses deep, and the survivors are scarred. Accordingly, the diplomacy is a step up from XCOM's country management. Do you make nice with fascist Elon Musk? How about the Church of Crabology? Maybe you're into high tech anarchy? The choices feel, initially, unique and compelling as your ships traverse the globe and you struggle to fight the literal tide of ocean borne monsters. When you do get to fighting the way turns break down is easier to manage and makes each bad move less punishing. I don't feel like a misclicked tile is a death sentence in Phoenix Point, for instance.
But.
If there's a word that's missing in this game, it's polish. For instance, you can free aim a shot, creating a kind of VATs system where limbs can be freely targeted. A head isn't always the best target either. Tritons have four arms, there's no disarming that. They are always better served with a chest shot. But sometimes at close range your shots clip through the target. Or at long range, a bit of cover blocks the shot in a way you can't anticipate. If a character is taking a regular shot, they'll step out from cover, but if you free aim it, they don't. That should've been a fairly straightforward fix, but it's not here. The same applies to overwatch. If you don't demand an overwatch over completely open ground, expect to miss. Cover too, doesn't actually cover much, so expect return fire to hurt almost always. A full shield just means your character will lean forwards and stick their head out, and you can expect the AI to nail a few shots. 
Then there are the mechanics that just don't work, or aren't explained at all. Did you want to capture something? You'll be told to build a tazer, but not that you have to taze the enemy above its threshold, then just ignore it for the rest of the mission. Depending on the enemy, that's an extremely tall order too. Not that anything in the game will tell you that. The enemies themselves also feel imbalanced, even with late game maxed out powers. One melee heavy enemy will spawn a doppleganger on its corpse, which is almost impossible to gun down with overwatch, and can easily one shot a character if you haven't killed it further back. Even then? Expect a hit or two. 
Then there's just the mix of busted, over aggressive AI on some, and potato brains on others. It's not that I can't deal with an enemy that corner camps and spams artillery while the rest of the foe charges, it's just no fun at all to deal with. It makes every missiontake another five real world minutes What about a siren that can control up to two soldiers a turn? In a squad that, if you brought a vehicle, might only have three? Essentially some builds and class types become useless, but even then playing well leaves you feeling cold.
Basically the end tier to this game is tedious and frustrating. You'll not feel overwhelmed, just constantly annoyed. Since the first draft of writing this, I've played almost exclusively base defenses and panic missions, 2-4 a day, while I wait for the final research missions to wrap. There's nothing more to it, it's just tedious and annoying. Each wave of missions plays out with a level of jank you didn't ask for, and after a year and three dlcs, feels unacceptable to see. It's a real shame to say, but there are better options.

Pros:
+ The aiming system is much more realistic, but still relies on RNG, but allows you to control it, do you want to try a risky a headshot or a guaranteed torso shot, but less damage.
+ You can have multiple teams to cover multiple sectors of the world.
+ Different factions with different technology focuses and classes with different play styles to recruit from.
+ You gain "global" skillpoints that can be used on newer recruits that you acquire later on that you like that have better abilities/traits.
+ There a vehicles in the game, but they come at a cost of taking two soldier positions, and cannot reload ammo.  But it is a nice addition.

Cons:
- Story is bare bones non-existent, the story line missions are almost no different from the typical gather/protect missions.
- Inventory management is a nightmare, and immersion breaking, why can you take a gun/armor from a soldier and equip it to another solder half way across the world?
- No point in having storage if there is not enough resources to build enough equipment to equip all your teams.
- Repetitive missions.
- Tech research is needed to move the storyline, but overall lacks an impact.
- Weapons max out near the mid game.
- Mist animation graphically intensive for how little impact it has.

Overall:
Get this game if you already played XCOM and want to scratch that itch again with a different setting.  But I would I recommend getting this game when it on a discount.  I could not get myself to finish the game due to the repetitiveness of the gameplay.

85469877.review:
The Game is nice, it took the best of classic [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/7760]X-COM: UFO Defense[/url] and the modern and dynamic [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/200510]XCOM: Enemy Unknown[/url]. It offers decent amount of playtime (it took me about 150h to complete everything). However, I feel that the game is quite unpolished, which is really disappointing given that they agreed to Epic Games' exclusive to get money upfront "to polish the game". There is a lot of balancing problems, serious bugs and other minor issues. I think [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/559100]Phantom Doctrine[/url] was better.

[h1]Good things[/h1]

[list]
[*] More classic action point system that gives you more freedom of moving and shooting. Every unit has 4 action points, attacking requires 1-3 AP depending on the weapon size and that can even be decreased to 0 with certain abilities. Each unit has speed parameter (usually 15-30) which defines how many tiles the unit can move in a single turn. However, moving one tile consumes only a fraction of the action point.
[*] Free aim. You don't just order to shoot at enemy, you can actually aim with your soldier which allows you to see the bullets spread of the weapon and target specific body parts.
[*] Targeting and destroying body parts. You can cut off alien's arm or destroy their weapon,you can damage their legs so that they bleed and walk slower, and so on.
[*] Realistic bullet trajectory - no more bullets hitting an enemy and seeing “missed” pop up. Bullets damage what they really hit.
[*] Multiple bases and aircrafts. You have to actually make tough decisions on the strategic screen, manage multiple teams, consider the speed of aicrafts to be able to respond to attacks and so on.
[*] A very interesting choice of skills and classes. Together with dual class it opens a way to some very powerful combos.
[*] Soldiers in overwatch shoot one-by-one rather than all-at-once.
[*] Soldier's movement is stopped when they spot an enemy (although you will lose some AP).
[*] The story is interesting - rather than classic alien invasion and UFOs, the humanity has to deal with a deadly virus that mutates living organisms.
[*] Equipment pool is global - this might not be a good thing, however if I had to transfer equipment and ammo between bases, it would add a lot of overhaul. Also, ammo crafting is instant and you can automatically replenish soldiers ammo at the end of the mission (at the regular crafting cost).
[/list]

[h1]Bad things[/h1]

[list]
[*] Tradeoffs. There is no clearly better weapons/armors/vehicles (excluding DLCs), all items are just different and you have to decide what parameters are most important for you.
[list]
[*] For example, basic helmet sensor mod gives motion detection, but if you complete advanced sensors research, you will be able to craft a mod that gives thermovision instead of motion detection.
[*] I have spent first 30-40 hours using the basic assault rifle, because nothing else I discovered was better. Take for example the end game assault rifle [spoiler]Piranha AR-51 - although it has 15 armor piercing and 40 damage, it fires only 4 projectiles. Starting Ares AR-1 deals 30 damage and 1 armor shredding per each of 6 bullets. So if enemy has no armor, AR-1 will deal 180 damage, but AR-51 only 160. If enemy has more than 55 armor, AR-51 will do nothing to the enemy, but AR-1 will shred the armor eventually. Also, AR-51 has lower effective range.[/spoiler]
[*] Same goes for aircrafts - if something is faster, it has lower capacity (but luckily you can send two aircrafts for the mission and pick the soldiers from both). So all the hard worked research doesn't give you anything better, it gives you something different.
[/list]
[*] There is a lot of tactical missions. Really a lot. And no auto-resolve. If you send an aircraft to respond to an attack, by the time it arrives, you are likely to complete 3-4 other tactical missions elsewhere. So if it turns out to be too slow, you won't be able to load an earlier save. There is no time in strategic view when you are just waiting for a mission to pop up. There is always dozens of things to do.
[*] Unclear and clunky stealth mechanics. Even if soldier has 100% stealth, enemies will still shoot at them. It still makes the game easier as you don't have enemies from the entire map rushing towards you, but forget about running between enemies undected.
[*] Inability to reorder, rename or scrap aircrafts.
[*] You cannot skip movement animations or issue move order while the previous soldier is still moving.
[*] No quick save/load and although saving is quick, loading takes ages (30+ seconds).
[*] Game in borderless window minimizes on focus lost.
[*] There are some long scrollable lists of equipments with very limited (or none) filtering options and no search.
[*] List of soldiers auto-scrolls whenever you move soldier between base and aircraft.
[*] Not much customisation, neither functional (like weapon mods in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/237950]UFO: Afterlight[/url]), nor cosmetic. Your soldiers will rarely wear the whole set of armor, making the soldiers look rather ugly.
[*] Low replayability - no randomness in regards to map objects - all Phoenix bases and havens are always in the same places.
[/list]

[h1]Lots of bugs (these are still bad things)[/h1]

[list]
[*] Loading a game in tactical mission is pretty bugged and doesn't save the state correctly. You won't be able to use certain abilities, claiming that they were already used this turn (even though it was actually the previous turn), enemies will do nothing on the following turn (nice exploit if mission is too difficult...). There is also another heavy exploit using neutral soldiers [spoiler]as once they are under Phoenix control, save-loading the game resets their AP back to 4...[/spoiler]
[*] [spoiler]Sniper's Marked for Death[/spoiler] skill doesn't do what its description says and can be exploited easily. [spoiler]I read that it was nerfed from giving +50% multiplicative stackable bonus to +10 damage per bullet, however other than description, nothing has changed. Use it a few times on and[/spoiler] you can kill everything (including the final boss) with one hit.
[*] Passing items between multiple soldiers standing next to each other is pretty bugged. Items don't get moved despite consuming action points, another time items get cloned (yet another exploit).
[*] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/839770/discussions/0/3102386014773768635]5 unobtainable Steam achievements.[/url]
[*] Repeller Module helmet mod doesn't restore will points in contrary to what its description says. A bug that exists for over a year...
[*] Sometimes equipment filters disappear.
[*] Sometimes spider drones disappear after deployment next to some obstacle.
[*] Sometimes there is no line-of-sight indicator even though the target can actually be hit.
[*] Units are automatically put in standby when they run out of action points, even though they still have free abilities available.
[*] Fog of war in Pandoran Nest often doesn't reveal correctly - be ready to navigate through the darkness.
[*] A lot of statistics on the game over screen is bluntly incorrect.
[*] Although you can search encyclopedia, if you do so, first few lines of the entry's description will be truncated, making the search useless.
[/list]

85422606.review:
It took me a while to figure what exactly about this game didn't catch my attention the way the rebooted X-COM games have; I think I finally figured it out.  On paper, there's a lot to like here if you're a fan of X-COM.  The strategic map is well, more strategic in Phoenix Point as you have to carefully decide how you are going to allocate resources to best fight the mutant menace.  You also have to pick and choose which faction(s) you'll back, which you'll raid and when since after all the best way to get resources is to help a faction against their attackers, but if you piss off one faction too soon you'll lose any hope of getting resources.  Your soldiers are also fairly unique, each soldier gets a random assortment of abilities they can unlock  from their class and you can choose what stats you want to improve as they gain experience.  Units can also eventually learn a secondary class granting them access to even more abilities.  You can give soldiers a different helm, chest piece and leg armor, any weapon you have the ability to make (though they do best if they have proficiency) and more.  In the tactical combat the idea of being able to see what your digital soldiers are shooting at is a great idea, although I will note it does not fix the issue of frustration when a bullet just happens to go into the one tiny spot where it could miss.

Here's where Phoenix Point falls apart though, most of the action that you can take in combat are not interesting.  The abilities you can unlock for each character class are either passive buffs of minor importance or abilities  you can use to do something like moving or shooting at a reduced action point cost.  What's more, the vast majority of enemies you face won't have anything more interesting to do either.  Most of the mutants in the game come from two "base" mutants that over the course of the game gain new mutations making dozens of different variants, but pretty much all of these variants end up with "I have a gun"; the end result is that pretty much every fight is very samey.  I'm fighting fascists in power armor?  Get in cover and shoot them.  I'm fighting humanoid robots?  Get in cover and shoot them.  I'm fighting mutants?  You guessed it, get in cover and shoot them.  In X-COM there are different reasons to shoot different enemies at different times, forcing you to prioritize certain enemies and attack them in different ways...but by and large that doesn't apply to Phoenix Point.  With the exception of a handful of late game enemies, every enemy pretty much fights the same and you in turn pretty much fight them in the exact same way too; an endless cascade of bullet casings that don't really add up to much.  If there is a Phoenix Two (or whatever they might call a potential sequel) the developers need to focus on creating varied and interesting tactical battles first and doing all the other stuff second.

85052920.review:
(Note: Played on hero difficulty, cannot speak for others.)

As a big fan of tactical games like X-COM (You can't not compare the two games), I wanted to like this a lot more. It starts off strong and has some nice features that arguably improve over the X-COM series, however, it has many glaring faults that take away the fun factor. Aside from multiple glaring bugs, a bare-bones UI/World map and the lack of basic features such as loadouts, the game gets more and more painful the farther in you get. The pacing slows down dramatically in the mid to late game as you constantly find yourself on call to defend allied settlements from attack. The lack of auto-resolve or any kind of automated defense means you have to spend hours chugging along the map fighting samey missions over and over again. 

My biggest issue is with balance. The game raises its difficulty with unfair mechanics and by throwing masses of highly equipped enemies at you. This may not sound like an issue but the sheer amount of resources they have available to them make the combat extremely un-fun. First of all, they introduce status effects (virus + paralysis) that not only completely delibitate a character once procced but are also (and I am not exaggerating) completely uncounterable until very late-game research (at least for virus, paralysis has no counters that I am aware of). If this was all you had to deal with, it wouldn't be such an issue, however, on top of enemies with these status effects you have other factors such as heavily armoured, mobile artillery cannons that will pelt you with explosive worms from a distance, forcing you to deal with them or take constant heavy damage. Enemies that will take control of your characters (multiple ones if not dealt with rapidly), with the only real counter being to destroy their heads (which are heavily armoured) and near-invisible snipers that can cripple or one-shot your characters from the other side of the map, who, if you DO manage to seek out and lay down fire on them, can then actually turn invisible and get a free shot on you next turn. Beyond that, you can very easily just get one-two shot, even through cover and with late-game equipment. With an average squad size of 6-8 characters, you can very easily find half of them completely delibitated or dead in the space of a turn. 

It becomes basically impossible to choose high priority targets because, of all of the bodies the game throws at you, pretty much every single one will disrupt/kill your squad if left unchecked. 
This forces you to either take heavily losses every mission (which is not sustainable) or save scum through missions in the hope that you get an enemy set-up that is lower on the bullshit scale. 
There are other glaring balance issues but it feels needless mentioning everything.

All of this serves to make the game an incredibly frustrating drag to get through, do not recommend at all.

So, I've been waiting for this for a year now and yes, I'm sort of disappointed - I've been playing Julian's games since he was first writing them and this had a fair bit of anticipation built up over it.

 The biggest mistake it seems to me to make is that it's framed as a global game, in the style of UFO:EU or XCOM, but it plays more like a sequel to XCOM: Apocalypse, which is to say that the world, the factions and the missions feel small in scope and scale - you're not liberating a city from the alien hordes, you're recovering a robot car from a ruined garage. It might have fared better if you were defending a cut-off region from The Mist and doubled-down on the storytelling as a result. Then there's the fairly steep story curve, which more or less goes from 'bad things happened' to 'after the fast-food wars, all restaurants are taco be, uhhh, one of three factions with no relation to the cultures or nations that existed before. Some of the base buildings seem wonky (I swear there's something wrong with training rooms) and a lot of the possible charm of staffing and developing your bases has been replaced by ubiquitous AI R&D facilities which don't seem to need staffing or indeed, character.

 In the tactical games, the enemy don't have a lot of variety (which is ironic, because the mix-n-match mutations ought to have made this a shoo-in, but in effect they mostly break down to 'more armour' and 'different weapon package' and the vaunted line-of-sight shooting makes overwatch a definite crapshoot at the best of times. It doesn't seem as though any of the various factions, inheritors of the world after multiple invasions from the sea have developed 'wall' technology and while there are many 'go and do this thing' missions, they all take place in a number of extremely samey maps drawn from a small number of tile sets that never succeed in looking much like places of business or work, even allowing for said apocalypsi... apocalypses... apocalises... Catastrophes. Oh! And the final mission mostly sucks. I get what they were going for, but 'fight through to the big giant brain and press the Endo-tron 3000 button you got from research is a bit of a hard sell.

 But I'm still recommending it.

 Why, is because the basic gameplay is pretty good. Missions are short and punchy, many of the weapons are - if underpowered - gratifying to use. You mostly feel smart when you bring something down (ubiquitous enemy return fire skill not withstanding) through combined arms and there's a fairly robust character development system, with a few arbitrary 'huh?' moments along the way.

While the game is not really bad, and adds a bunch of innovations to the genre, it cannot compete with XCom/XCom2 in terms of pure fun IMO. While the combat is entertaining, and in many ways an improvement over XCom, there is just too much micro-management needed on the strategic layer for my taste.

The Good:
* Ballistic targeting & disabling body parts is great and extremely satisfying.
* Interesting combat mechanics all around that allow great tactical flexibility.

The Bad:
* You need to maintain multiple aircrafts & crews to respond to events in time. Realistic, but just adds more things to look after.
* The resource squeeze forces you to trade with other factions. Which means managing aircrafts to fly around between them. Something that could easily be replaced by an automated trading system that just generates resources over time.
* With the DLCs come ancient sites. Once conquered, you have to manage aircrafts flying between them to collect mined resources. Something else that could be automated easily.
* Combat equipment is far too expensive. A hammer costs about 1/4 of an aircraft. Troops go into combat with half-empty magazines because they cannot afford full ones.
* Weapon balance is off. I'm at the point where I rather walk up to aliens and hit them with a big hammer, because (a) it deals more damage than my best gun, and (b) doesn't use up ammunition.
* The "realistic" approach of requiring multiple teams in multiple places is somewhat undermined by equipment just sitting in a common pool, meaning you end up moving equipment between teams on opposite sites of the world.

Well, you've seen the screenshots and you've probably watched some gameplay on Youtube so you know this is game is <cough> very heavily inspired by XCOM2. So, if you already like XCOM2 and you're looking for a new fix to keep you hooked until XCOM3 comes along whenever that might be, is this game for you? Let's have a quick look at what's different.

Character customisation is not as detailed as XCOM2 but it is more than good enough for me. You're not going to be running cute girls around the battlefield in hot pink shorts and a t-shirt, all the characters are military-style, like they were in XCOM1. But you can name them and set up the colour and pattern schemes for their kit.

You don't have Bradford shouting at you telling you not to let the Berseker Queen get away when you're letting out a huge sigh of relief that the beast is exiting the field. And, after 13 hours in, I have yet to have my in-game performance assessed by some shadowy, bald geezer with a gravelly voice. Don't miss that at all. I know how well I'm performing. (Badly!)

The tactical maps are gorgeous and you really feel like you're playing XCOM2. However, IMO, tactical combat appears to be deeper than XCOM2's combat. You have four action points instead of two and your characters also have willpower which you 'spend' to activate their special abilities. I really like this. I'd have prefered to have XCOM: Chimera Squad's impulse turns but this is a slight improvement over XCOM2.

This is also a difficult game. You might feel like you're walking it your first couple of hours in the game but the difficulty ramps up quite savagely a few hours in and you'll need to form whole new strategies for playing the strategic map. You will find it hard, if not impossible to keep all the factions happy so you'll have to pick one aover the others and go with that so that gives the game more replayability as you'll want to see what all the factions have to offer.

There is so much more to talk about but if you're one of those folks who gets bent out of shape when someone reimagines an existing title, like 'Iratus: Lord of the Dead' did with 'Darkest Dungeon', or 'Knock on the coffin lid' did with 'Slay the Spire', this will cause you a world of pain. It says it's "from one of the creators of XCOM", and that certainly shows. The broad strokes of the game are very similar to XCOM: You have a global strategy map, you face an implacable global threat, you train and equip squads of troops, and you go on daring high-risk missions with intricate tactical combat. Even most of the details of how the tactical combat proceeds feel very XCOM, from the satisfaction of getting a sniper headshot to the despair of seeing your squad leader get one-shot. 

But there are some important differences, some obviously good, some more ambiguous. The realistic ballistics simulation, the addition of land vehicles, and the option to build new bases and aircraft to deploy more squads are all excellent improvements on the formula. But some of the more realistic details require more micromanagement, such as needing to keep track of ammo magazines, replacing used medkits and grenades, and equipping each soldier with their own specific armor. Your mileage may vary on whether this increases your immersion or just feels frustrating. The way that enemies continually mutate and improve over time makes for a compelling challenge, but it can also be annoying to try to keep track of so many different enemy types at once. There are like twelve different types of Arthron alone. You will receive periodic intel reports on the new enemies, which are so long and detailed you will want to TLDR them. 

The biggest differences from XCOM are actually in terms of setting and plot of Phoenix Point. The Pandorans are not a alien race with advanced technology; they're more like a virus that mutates and spreads itself through infesting and dominating humans. The situation is considerably bleaker than XCOM: Human civilization is already on the brink of ruin, and the few remaining factions are either naively idealistic (Synedrion), dangerously purist (New Jericho) or just plain bizarre (Disciples of Anu). 

If you love XCOM, you'll love Phoenix Point. At least you know what you're getting, eh?
