Played at launch with Epic, then came back for the Steam version. Completed both versions. Inevitable comparisons with XCOM aside, PP does a few things well, and others not so well. 

POSITIVES:

> Shooting is arguably better than XCOM, as there is no % to hit. So no frustrating misses due to that 99% which whiffs. Positioning and weapon choice are rewarded, along with being able to shoot specific areas (like the head of a mind control enemy, or shielded crab etc)

> Action Points are more flexible, with a move, shoot, and move again. Or shoot twice. There are option here that I miss when going back to XCOM. 

> Steal stuff. Be it vehicles or research. Again this is more flexibility, that lets you adjust what you want and when. 

> Factions. Stereotypical yes, but it's nice to have them around so it feels like the world is also doing it's part combat the enemy. Trade with them, do missions, and also double cross them if you so choose. They need work though..

> Soldiers. Lots of play here for soldier builds, with RNG skills mixed in with multi-class options. Customization is ok, but XCOM trumps it here in a big way. Still, soldiers look quite nice. 

MIXED:

> Story. Eh, it's ok. Multiple ways to win though, but you wont exactly be gripped by the narrative.

> DLC Content. A real mixed bag here. The main one, Ancients, throws in new enemies and powerful gear. But it is super grindy and confusing. The smaller DLC gives you augmentations which are good, and gives you more soldier customization. The last one is a small one, with an armor set, and couple of guns that mostly not worth the missions.

NEGATIVES:

> Mid to End Game is quite frankly a mess. Haven defense needs a full rework as you are just spammed with random defense missions as the mist covers more of the globe. And those missions lack interest and meaningful reward. There is no percentage to see if the haven might successfully defend (most times they don't, NJ faction sometimes does win). No option to help them set up defenses, or lend them some troops to bolster future attacks. They are just awful, and keep coming...and coming. 

> Doomsday clock. Sigh, does anyone like these? As the lil bar depletes you are supposed to be filled with urgency. But instead you get spammed with haven defense missions as described above. This needs a rework, as the pacing is just so off.

> Character. This is where the big budget clout of Firaxis beats PP hands down. The game lacks a Bradford, and anyone interesting to breath life into the story and tactical missions. 

> Enemy design. You like seafood? We got crabs. Big tanks ones, skinny sneaky ones, and slithering mind control ones. Even giant building crushing ones. But still, nothing really memorable that makes you love to hate them. The goo ones just feel cheap and frustrating, while the mind control ones teach you to never leave home without a headshot specialist. Faction enemies are more interesting though, as are the ancients. But the Pandorans are largely forgettable. 

>Sound and Music. There is a fine line between atmospheric and depressing. PP often opts for the latter. While combat music just lacks any excitement and bite. Strategy layer music I end up turning off as it is so gloomy. Sound effects are hit and miss, with a few larger ones sounding low budget. Yet the crack of a rail gun is satisfying. 

OVERALL

Despite the cracks, there is a good game here and the core is solid. A few mods could easily sort out the issues and add polish. Plus the year one edition is vastly improved over what was released. DLC is ok, but the next one is supposed to be biggest yet.

83647237.review:
It's a hesitant yes from me. This is one of these good news bad news games.

Good news:

The free aiming system adds a lot. At first I thought it was going to be a gimmick, but once you learn to read how the system displays information and learn the value in targeting different body parts you wind up making a lot of meaningful choices and getting a lot of gameplay out of it.

The class combination idea is excellent. The game doesn't have that many classes, but every character gets two. In addition they get three unique masteries which can include the ability to grab proficiencies form other classes. Want someone who uses the heavies jetpack to fly on top of a building where they can deploy an engineers turret while taking shots with a sniper rifle? You got it. There's a lot of uniqueness to the performance of different soldiers.

The geoscape level gives you good reason to run several squads. They need recovery time between missions, even if just to rest when they're not injured. The aircraft are only so fast and missions can pop up worldwide, there's no guarantee of them being in range of any one squad. Juggling a bunch of different squads keeps the gameplay fresher than having one A-team that does everything.

The mission variety feels decent. While every mission boils down to one of essentially three things (Go there, grab that, kill that) there's enough difference between mission types that they feel like they reward different approaches. Some feature infinite reinforcements and are best served by a fast squad that does the job and gets out. Others require you to clear the map and benefit more from something slow and careful. They also offer decent trade offs between grabbing extra loot and winning that can make you question if it's reaaaally worth going for that last box or if you should retreat with what you have.

A lot of thought has gone into giving the aliens unique powers that go beyond "Have more hitpoints, do more damage". There's already a lot of this in existing titles with psionic and melee enemies doing special stuff, but this at least doubles the sorts of weird attack you could be subjected to compared to other games in its genre. I'd rather not spoil them but it's nice to see.

The willpower mechanic works pretty well. All special abilities use willpower. Seeing allies die uses willpower. Some attacks drain willpower. Having a body part take severe damage drains willpower (especially the head). If you hit 0 then you miss a turn fleeing and taking cover. Also all psionics are based on "Is my willpower higher than my targets" rather than a percentage chance which makes critical moments like mind control feel less RNG. Conversely you can skip a turn to regain willpower and some abilities offer other ways to restore it.

Bad news:

There is a lot of not fun micromanagement to get to the good bits. At the end of a mission you get a button to buy back all of the ammo you fired during the level, but if you don't have the resources there and then you'll have to do it manually weapon by weapon once you do. Doing things requires the right balance of tech, materials, and food - trading one for the other means flying to an outpost and trading things they don't have for things they do - but each outpost has limited supplies and replenishes every so often so you'll need to do a circuit of them every now and again to do basic building and supply.

The documentation in the game is so-so. Some abilities, equipment and modifications won't work exactly as advertised. Some critical features of them aren't mentioned and you discover them by trial and (mostly) error.

The game doesn't autosave each turn, which is for the best since it'd be tempting to save scum every death given how tedious hiring and equipping a new recuit is (trade resources for the right types, queue up their leg armour, body armour, head armour, weapon, and equipment to be built seperately) and it seems like the odd misfortune is part of the game rather than intended to be avoided. The thing is: Sometimes the game crashes, or gets stuck on an infinite enemy turn. It's not a lot, you'll only see it once every ten hours of play or so, but if it happens near the end of a long level it's frustrating.

The interface lets itself down in places and there are a few times that the game seems to trip over its own feet. The first of these you'll probably encounter is that its realistic bullet physics are based on where the character holds the gun, so the heavy weapons users who start with jetpacks are also the ones who can't take advantage of high ground because holding their gun at waste height makes them most likely to shoot their own cover if they're angling downwards. Also just little things like the game automatically switching off a character every time they run out of action points, even if they can overwatch for 0 cost or the last thing you did was activate an ability that reduced the cost of their next shot to 0.

Overall:

There's more pros than cons and it's taken some risks doing a lot of worthwhile and interesting things. It's a shame that they've failed to nail some of the core stuff, but the bells and whistles? Very ringy, very whistley.

83403405.review:
Now this is a story all about how the Earth got flip-turned upside down. And I'd like to take a minute, just sit right there, I'll tell you all about how people were mutated by the air!

Phoenix Point is the brainchild of Julian Gollop, creator of the original X-COM series. As such, it has many of the things that players of XCOM (And Xenonauts) will be familiar with - turn-based battles on tile maps, base building, recruiting soldiers for your squads, and the Geoscape, to name a few things.

Where it differs is in its story, shooting in combat, havens and difficulty curve.

Unlike the XCOM storylines, where earth is being invaded by extra-terrestrials, PP's enemies are the result of a mist-borne virus that causes people to lose their marbles, walk into the sea, and mutate into CRAB PEOPLE. CRAB PEOPLE. CRAB PEOPLE.

Obviously, XCOM Terror from the Deep and HP Lovecraft inspired quite a bit of PP (To the point that Lovecraft is mentioned by name in-game). That said, I really wish the horror was better executed. Aside from narration over still images, there are no real cutscenes. This is a huge missed opportunity, especially considering the revamp of the tutorial introducing some named characters. Remember in Starcraft 2 the optional cutscene of Dr. Hanson becoming infested with Zerg DNA? Considering this is an entire game based around mutation and body-horror, you'd think they'd have fit some truly terrifying (Or at least suitably creepy) cutscenes in.

The mission maps also lack any variety. There are all of 2 or 3 maps per setting, so you'll become familiar with them very quickly, and this makes the game feel somewhat bland and repetitive compared to XCOM 2 or Xenonauts.

It's not a *bad* game though. The difficulty curve can be extremely unforgiving, and you should expect to fail or wipe on a few missions, maybe even lose a campaign or two until you get the swing. "Easy" is more like playing WOTC on "Normal" (or even "Hard" at times), but this makes those victories all the sweeter.

Speaking of combat, I love the Free Aim feature and true bullet physics. It's much more satisfying to be able to see an estimate of where your shots will hit rather than missing an entire burst of shots on a stated 99% hit chance.

Havens are nice, they work similarly to the factions in WOTC, with a bit more depth. They're a mix between that and an AI-Controlled PP equivalent. They're passive for most of the game, but near the end they may declare war on one another to mix things up.

Ultimately the game is decent, and if you like TBT games you'll enjoy it. That said, it feels very half-arsed in a lot of places, or at least like you can see the seeds of a good idea that just fell flat.

With only 1 DLC left to publish by the point of me writing this, I hope they're planning some free content updates to flavour the game a bit more, but I doubt it. Still, pick it up if you see it on sale. In some ways, it's better than XCOM 2 + WOTC. But in many more ways, it doesn't quite measure up. Still, a worthwhile addition, especially at a discount.

I'd like to point out some of the more glaring negatives here with the disclaimer that PP is a full fledged X-Com-like you can definitely get enjoyment out of. My point is mostly that it doesn't have the kind of design to make it a timeless classic. Playing PP you'll have to put up with some rough edges and unless you're deep into tactical strategy you might be better off looking at some of the contemporary games e.g. X-COM 2 and Xenonauts.

- The game balance is fairly whack. From what I've seen It has definitely improved since the backer/epic builds but still the scaling curve is way out of whack. The early game is passable providing a moderate challenge that rewards tactical play but in the mid-end game one of 2 things happen. Either you're way behind the curve so you struggle to stay alive or you completely stomp by exploiting certain wombo combos to the point where you beat most missions on the first turn. Ideally the challenge would reflect the difficulty you're playing on across the whole campaign, to me this dichotomy indicates that the action point/ will point system is extremely exploitable to the point that it makes tactical play obsolete. As a sidenote, I feel that some game elements are also way too punishing in a way that provides no options for counterplay (E.g. Virus, Paralysis). Across the board there seems to be this philosophy of "when it rains it pours" baked into the game and I can't say I'm a huge fan.

- There are too many missions. If you're played Xenonauts its the same concept here, after a certain point you're doing missions just to do missions because you're just waiting for research or some other progression trigger. Many missions don't feel impactful to your cause especially when you can just blaze through them as mentioned before. Of course you can ignore everything if you're already set but either way it's not a good look when you can't be bothered to play the game so you just try to get it over with asap. In Firaxis's X-COM 2 the game is more or less balanced so that a typical campaign will span 40-60 missions, In hindsight that is about the perfect amount so that you always feel like you're progressing.

-There are too few enemy types especially with the amount of missions the game expects you to do.

-There are a fair number of rough edges and missing quality of life functionality. E.g. Gave this game a fair shake as its in the "XCOM" genre and posts some high level names from the original dev team. But overall, just been disapointed by the formula that theyre using. 

First off, alot of UI elements are missing, like chance to hit, savable customization options and default gear which makes the game feel empty. This makes alot of the "not playing the game but building my story" stuff that helps sell these games -very- tedious, and is just an outright design flaw. Which by itself isnt that bad, but when you combine this with how short encounters are outside of story missions, you spend a very noticable amount of time just clicking on the geoscape doing "exploration" dots (which are just random encounters that take several seconds to unlock) or in your barracks just regearing your dudes while handling logistics. Its not the greatest designed system and lacks engagement like XCOM2s 'choose one of 3' method and infinite logistics in terms of non-upgraded gear and detracts the player from "getting into the game". Overall it ends up being a very boring grind to queue up even basic gear for new recruits while you start poking around at the games first handful of side missions, which in themselves barely push even a basic story narrative for the first hour or so of play. 

In terms of the combat mechanics. the traditional xcom series each mission has anywhere form 2-4+ "pods" of enemies. This game just doesnt do that, so squad level engagements are limited, alpha striking, breaching, etc is just not there. So your squad doesnt feel like this hardcore shock and clear infantry platoon like the game tries to sell its self as.  Its much more like xenonauts where enemies appear randomly and spawned throughout the map, following a objective script. While its not necessarily the wrong way to do it, the presentation of it all is wrong and lacks engagement. Xenonauts counters this by giving you alot of dudes and alot fighting on every map. Phoenix point lacks both as engagements to be smaller, and less tactical in terms of squad synergy overall. And to top it all off theres a performance issue with this as the game will often time out and invisible enemies can take 5-10 seconds each to perform their turns. Combine this with the fact you can't queue up orders while your soldiers are doing basic actions like moving can make the relative short encounters feel like they take ages to complete while you scour the maps. The game does have a sound-esque system to help you find the aliens in the fog of war, but the performance issues with the relatively slow pace of combat make it a downturn. 

That said, the games not all that bad. The story isn't terrible and isn't far from feasible in terms of writing. Though it isnt very engaging, and theres not really any characters to attach to. The faction system is unique and integrated enough to stand on its own two legs as a game mechanic, and the subfactions of each faction help with replayability as they can lead to a variety of alternate endings. Realistic bullet physics also is a very big part of the game, and when dealing with the various mini bosses of the game, is a unique and enjoyable combat system as you blow off their arms and legs and fire your mini gun through walls to hit enemies you cant see on the other side.  


Overall though I give the game a thumbs down due to performance issues I experienced, the micro intensive and unsastifying geo-scape and the snails speed overall pacing of the shooting things part of the game. If youre looking for a spin on the XCOM genre with its own unique blend of combat mechanics, this might be for you. But it wasnt for me.

TLDR: Good foundation. Mostly lacking in content and polish. Would recommend.

I've played all of the reboot XCOMs extensively. I've also played a bit of the OGs, but I never completed them.

Phoenix Point comes along as a kind of middle-ground between the old and the new. Where the new (reboot XCOM) focuses mainly on tactical combat with a brief strategy layer getting you between battles and old is mostly about having the right number of men with the right gear in the right place at the right time, Phoenix Point straddles a fine middle line. Whether or not it does so successfully is up to the player. In my opinion it does well enough.

The good:
[list]
[*] The combat system lends itself to actually interesting gear choices. One of the problems I've always had with reboot XCOM is that there weren't any real choices for gear at any point in the game. You use the best stuff. All your weapons upgrade at once. Plasma weapons are always the best, etc, etc. In this game, there's 5 different types of shotguns, 5 different heavy weapons, 4 sniper rifles, and while there sometimes is a best option, almost all of the weapons remain situationally useful even as you acquire other weapons. This, along with the enhanced strategy layer, is the most important thing that other games like this should try to take away from Phoenix Point.
[*] Like OG XCOMs, it's not too punishing to lose soldiers, so save-scumming never really felt justified. 
[*] Although tactical takes a back seat in comparison to reboot, the multiclass system allows for a surprising level of soldier customization. However, the way that faction classes are pretty much strictly better than PP classes meant that I had to wait to upgrade soldiers for a while after they hit max rank.
[*] Strategy is good. It's not better than the OG, but it's MILES ahead of reboot. There's multiple ways of getting the stuff you need to beat the game, and it's balanced enough. There's interesting decisions to make concerning your forces size, composition, and logistics. The research tree kept giving out interesting new gear and items. 
[*] Campaign was decently paced. The only time where I experienced fatigue was in the extreme lategame when uh... every haven was under siege. I wasn't going to do all of those defenses.
[/list]
The mediocre:
[list]
[*] The combat is okay. It's not better than the reboot. It honestly might not even be better than OG, because at least in OG it was pretty damn fast-paced. But it's passable.
[/list]
Some criticisms:
[list]
[*] There are not enough enemies types, straight up. All enemy types should get mutations, at the very least, and there needs to be more base types. The only time I ever felt scared was the first time I got wacked by a tar shadow.
[*] Atmosphere is lacking. Just felt a bit bland/unimmersive.  
[*] Polish. This game really makes it clear as to the level of polish and production that goes into Firaxis XCOM. Things like the pervasiveness of voice acting, 2D graphics for UI, multiple skills just not doing what their description say they do, the way all cover gets destroyed in the exact same way, where everything including rocks and walls get turned into super-blatantly-video-gamey polygons with no weight when the get destroyed--- yeah. It's not the greatest.
[*] Not enough/Not interesting enough exploration targets. Fixing this is easier said than done, but I liked the haven discovery events a lot. A quick and easy way to start would be to give all revealed havens an event (when you hit 25 rep).
[*] Part-based disabling means that almost all combat comes down to shooting arms or weapons. Turns out aiming for center mass or the head was a lie. Just feels really wrong that disabling an arm means you can't use 2-handed weapons but disabling your head doesn't mean you can't use your brain. This means that free-aiming is rarely a decision. You either aim at the shredded part or the arm/weapon. 
[*] Free aiming should always be available and you shouldn't have to have an enemy present to utilize step-out firing positions.
[*] Maps, simply put, suck. Maps are one of the most important parts of a game like this, but there aren't any interesting levels in the game, straight up. This was also a problem in the new XCOM games to a much lesser extent. EU/EW had interesting levels, but not enough of them. XCOM2 had a couple interesting levels, alongside randomized tilesets that could sustain some interest due to their nature (and several dedicated modders, credit to them). But the levels ARE interesting. In Phoenix Point, the levels are repetitive and the levels are bland. Random forest. Random house. Nothing feels lived-in. Often times there's no meaningful elevation, just a flat game board with cover dispersed all about; this is especially bad with Synedrion haven defenses, for example. I noticed it on the first glance and when it became apparent that the campaign was going to be ~120 missions long I knew it was going to be rough. It all comes back to polish. 
[*] Mod support. Games in the genre cannot compete with XCOM fairly without it.
[/list]

83082446.review:
Recommended for people who enjoy XCOM-style games, but want something a little different.

One of the key differences is the way combat works.  Cover is not an abstract -40% to hit; it's a physical entity, and the paths of bullets are modeled individually.  Instead of a flat percentage to hit, you have a target circle that indicates the zone where bullets will land.  You can target specific body parts, or shoot weapons out of enemy hands.

Movement is also a bit different.  You get 4 action points, but movement uses fractional APs (firing weapons and using skills uses whole numbers).  Where in XCOM you would find a spot of high cover and dig in, in Phoenix Point it's better to move-shoot-move.  All enemies are active from the start, so there's no creeping and pod-revealing.

Enemies have a handful of base types that get random attributes. It's like enemies have a few chassis types and then a randomized loadout.  Guns, grenades, shields, poison-spit heads... the types aren't as distinct as XCOM, so it feels like less variety.

There are a couple of things that it doesn't do well. One is limited mission variety: there are a handful of maps, which get some randomization but don't really feel different, and your goal is either to kill everything or touch a square (and maybe evacuate).  In Haven Defense missions you're supposed to protect civilians or buildings, but mostly those are there so the bad guys have something to shoot at instead of converging on you all at once.

The other thing it fails to do well is to explain the end game.  I had no idea what I needed to do to win.  I just kept researching stuff and playing whack-a-mole for several hours and eventually the factions started building some special structures.  There's one tech you can research that apparently brings about a swift end; they warn you about this, but don't explain what your alternatives are.  (My 109 hours was spent on *one game*.  Apparently I should have built more research centers?)

Sometimes the randomization produces a nearly unwinnable level.  (Explosive artillery on a citadel map with no roofs?  Good luck.)

I encountered very few bugs.  There's a nasty one that cause the game to get stuck on the enemy turn. Be sure to save frequently to a pair of files.

It's got some rough edges, and it drags a bit toward the end, but on the whole it's a fun game.

While the game is a great example on a tactical strategey  game, it does have a few issues. Before i write down my critics, i want to let you know im playing on Veteran (Medium) Difficulty, as i have experience with RTS's.

1. Balancing - Early game: its exceptionally hard to compete against other factions , which seems to be the best way to get resources in the game, enemies from factions such as Diciples of Anu have an ease to one-shot your average soldier, which early game is very punishing. If you were to play the game without fighting or making enemies with another faction, it would make it too time consuming to gain resources to build your bases. 

Mid-game state: the game sort of forces you to have a second squad of high ranking fighters as well as having soldiers at all the bases you own, which isn't that hard to manage. However, equipment and ammo management is a nightmare, when you have to keep track of all the ammo for all sorts of different guns that enemies don't usually use (which means they have no chance of dropping that ammo type). Second is skillpoint/skilltree management, you'd be forced to send them on missions so they'll be able to level up their abilities, otherwise, they're targeting dummies whom only have good gear to complement them, which later game, is very hard to play missions with as they're too slow or weak in stats to fight efficiently.
Another issue early game is that there aren't any hints or tips that tell you that satellite structures in the base with its scans in fact, only scans the explorative locations around base and NOT Pandoran Lairs, info on how you're supposed to repel the Pandorans from infecting more of the planet is unclear, unless by the use of Mist Repellers, which appear late in the game, and doesn't even give you the ability to build ones yourself. Enemies such as "Scourge" (I think its called) enemies whom if you kill a Pandoran wraith, will be auto-revived in their next turn. These enemies are imbalanced, as such are the pandoran enemies with pinchers, because they have the ability to walk around in a 1 action point radius, and attack 3-4 times in a row after walking. Enemies such as Pandoran vehicles (The four legged big monster thing) has a variant which causes stalling for turn after turn. There is a variant with a goo launcher, the imbalancing with this enemy is that it can goo once every turn, which if you have regular soldiers and characters on the map, will indefinitely get stuck in the goo, causing to changes to many turns forward, until the monster itself, loses all will-points.

2. Levels and classes
Classes in the game come in minimal varieties (Unless you've unlocked Diciples of Anu as allies) You start with three classes in game, which all other factions have as well. The diversity of classes are very minimal as the each faction has 1-2 unique classes except the Phoenix Project (Unless unlocked late game). There's not much else to say, but that classes feel a little bit slow and not very diverse compared to each other.

Leveling is fun , and is crucial for characters in this game to become stronger and unlock skills, the leveling is balanced, but feels a little bit unrewarding, essentially, a player could camp out their level ups and only spend the points in skills late in the skill-tree, which unappreciates the other skills, potentially making them worth less or less useful at least. ranking up characters in general is fun, and id recommend adding more levels to the characters, and maybe add skills to them that would make them stand out a lot better towards other classes. A good example of class diversity is comparing the technician class to the soldiers class, which might/might not emphasize on different play-styles. soldier and heavy though feel too similar, with very few unique differences. Infiltrator feels like a technician in disguise (They're very similar).

3. Vehicles (Special Units?)
What would make the game incredibly interesting and fun is to have "unique" characters in the game, with slightly different alt to the class they have. A great example is you could have a sniper character in which his class is "bounty hunter" which would be a sniper class, with some unique scavenging perks. or getting bonuses at damaging specific units! This a passionate example ^u^
Vehicles, we have to cover this... the vehicles feels like a double-edged blade. In it self, it is a bigger unit which can do powerful attacks. They feel kind of lacking though, as that's where the line ends. they're units with stronger attacks and bigger hit-boxes, the main critic would be there's barely any special units like the phoenix project APC or Diciples of anu's mutated dogs. special units in the game form each faction are 3x3 grid big, it would be very interesting and diverse in play-style if 2x2 units were added (1x1 are regular units) to the game, they could be soldiers in mechsuits or a steed / a warthog with more inventory space (for example). 2x2 units would see lots of play as its perfect for balancing squads Surprisingly there aren't any ground vehicles with a light machine gun mounted in the game.

4. Feedback
With all these comments i've made, they're only criticism! I don't hate or dislike the game, in fact this is the best game of mine in recent weeks since i got it! I fully support this game and all its efforts, and wish i could help them more seeing as this is a game , which may not be perfect, whom i believe have what it takes to reach perfection.

[h1] Everything I Hoped For [/h1]
I saw this game when it launched its crowdfunding campaign and immediately backed it.  In my youth I was addicted to the original X-Com series.  Ive played many clones and games trying to be like that series always hoping for something close, and always being let down.  This game comes closest, while also being its own independent incredibly fun game.

I love so many things about this game.  It has a vast tech tree, similar to the original X-Com but also allows you to branch into specific paths depending on the factions you choose to align with.  It has base building and resource management without being boring or tedious.  It even has its own form of timer, however NOTHING like the new X-Com game.  You have essentially as much time as you want to develop your teams, bases, research and equipment so long as you don’t let the enemies overrun the planet.  You have character classes that as they level can branch into another class, so the combinations of skill trees and abilities makes for some fantastic team building options.  Don’t like human legs and want to be able to jum?  Sure, just switch them out with the new cybernetic legs you developed.  Want a sniper who can also be a scout and see the enemy from far even in the dark?  Just mutate his head into the new special mutation you researched.  Honestly, this game has so much of what I loved in the old X-COM but is so enhanced.

Honestly I don’t have anything negative to say about this Phoenix Point.

[b]Sound –[/b] Everything you would expect.  Music is good, keeps the mood right.  Alien noises are great.  Sound effects simple and immersive.
[b]Graphics –[/b]  Great for what its trying to be.  Nothing cutting edge, but its not that kind of game.
[b]Gameplay –[/b] I covered it above.  Very fun.  I kept doing the “Oh just one more thing” bleeding my hours away.
[b]Replay Value –[/b] There are multiple endings depending on the factions you align with, so definitely repayable especially if you enjoy uncovering the different endings.
[b]Story –[/b] Not a new concept to the genre, and between factions and exploration a lot of lore/story to discover.  Adds something to the game for sure.

If you ever played the old X-Com’s or the new, and enjoyed them, you will love this.  If you like turn & squad-based combat with a team you can equip and design from the ground up, again you will love this.  As someone who backed this, I got MORE than my moneys worth.

82951628.review:
Phoenix Point, recently released on Steam, runs very well. 
Most missions in Phoenix Point can be taken on at any time.  Exceptions are ambushes and stopping attacks on the facilities of the other factions.  There a few other missions that appear that have to be responded to in a limited amount of time.
There are three other factions actively fighting the threat.  Each has many bases around the globe and a player's reputation can increase or decrease based on actions taken with factions as a whole and with individual bases.  The player can recruit soldiers from the different factions but the more important goal is to get a good enough relationship with one or maybe two of the factions so that their technology will be shared with the Phoenix Project.  At some points diplomatic missions must be undertaken in order to increase status with factions.
Improvements in weapons technology are not dramatic in Phoenix Point.  Rate of fire, effective range and accuracy all have a part to play in selecting weapons.  Armor comes in three parts, helmet, torso and legs.  Weapons can be destroyed in combat by enemy fire and consumable items like grenades and ammunition must be replenished between missions.  The game makes this quite easy after each mission overall but some equipment must be picked up at a base after manufactured.  Items are not manufactured instantly.  
Units have far more hit points so it is not possible to wipe out all enemy units in an ambush  easily.  It is also possible to target individual sections of an enemy unit.  Over-watch is not 360 degrees and units have four action points that can be used in any order.  There are no pods in Phoenix Point and when a unit is discovered movement is stopped so a player can decide how to handle the situation, another difference from some other games of this type.  
There are many story line type missions since each faction has a series of missions to compete in order to gain influence with them.  Phoenix Point has a good variety of missions.
Phoenix Point allows the player to have more than one base.  Bases are needed to detect alien complexes and for increasing manufacturing and research capabilities.  Base development requires a lot of resources which are tight in Phoenix Point.  
It is possible to have more than one aircraft and fighting vehicles.  
Research is tied to acquiring certain items, killing certain aliens or capturing them.  If influence with a faction becomes high enough then their research will be shared with the Phoenix Project.
Phoenix Point will definitely scratch that strategic/tactical  itch.  It plays very differently in some ways but is an excellent addition to games of this genre.  I can easily recommend it.

I enjoy the game, but the amount of tactical combat, ironically, can be too high sometimes. I frequently find myself queuing for three encounters in a row, which quickly gets repetitive (especially in the end-game, when there are usually 3-5 pending haven defense events, so at some point I just stop bothering). With this amount of encounters, the game doesn't let me spend nearly enough time on the global map, which also slows down any research and construction, making the game to progress extremely slowly. I realize it's a bit unorthodox and maybe defats the core gameplay purpose, but having auto-revolve mechanic for some battles would be really helpful to deal with the sheer amount of repetitive encounters, such as clearing nests and defending havens.

Other than that, there are some balance issues, especially related to the antediluvian weapons. In fact, the entire Legacy Of the Ancients DLC doesn't fit the plot too well, ending up in a situation where we're looking for a proof about antediluvian existence AFTER having excavated their artifacts and even manufacturing their weapons. The weapons themselves are too overpowered and more or less easily obtainable, so by mid-game I have most of my troops carrying end-game weapons that don't even require ammunition. Most of the advanced weapons tech comes way later, and by then it makes no sense to research or manufacture them, because they are weaker and need ammo.

Despite the abovementioned flaws, I've had my share of fun with the game and would like to thank the developers for making it! Great work, guys! I especially enjoyed reading The Briefing volumes during the development, which was likely the main reason I was waiting for the game to finally come out on Steam.

82891447.review:
If you like XCOM, this is a really good buy. Be aware that the game uses different features and you can't always rely on old XCOM tactics.

Phoenix Point has innovated the standard features you get in an XCOM-like game, while retaining the same spirit of the game. This cuts both ways; the new features sometimes increase risk and other time decrease it. 

I played >1000 hours of XCOM (combined) and had gotten stuck in a rut, using the same tactics based on certain game features. Phoenix Point changes its gameplay enough that it caused me to reevaluate my usual playbook.  
Over all, it's a very good game if you're looking for an XCOM-like game and need a fresh take on gameplay features you're experienced with.

An overview of changed features relative to XCOM:

* Gone are the hit chance percentages. All weapons have a bullet spread, and when you shoot, each bullet is randomized within the weapon's spread. The scenery blocks shots but can be destroyed in the process.
* Similarly, cover does not grant a flatout percentage defensive chance. It's all about how visible your target is. Even in full cover and not flanked, an enemy that is close to flanking your unit is going to see most of your unit and have a good chance to hit. The game still shows you half/full cover icons but you have to use your brains: a handrail is obviously not going to block as many bullets as a waist-high rock.
* Overwatch is conic. You get to choose the direction, distance and width of the overwatch cone. It allows you to focus overwatch on specific targets. But you can only have a 180° field of view instead of XCOM's 360°.
* Similar to Fallout's VATS, you can target limbs, heads, weapons, ... Disabling certain body parts confers certain debuffs on the enemy. Disabled legs lower movement speed, disabled arms prevent melee or wielding two-handed weapons, certain enemy abilities are disabled when the relevant body part is disabled.
* Enemy AI is about as complex, but each enemy uses their own advantage better. The flanking units really scurry around and hide from sight, making it hard to take them out before they get to you.
* Soldiers get skill points which can be invested in stat increases or the skill tree. There's a fixed class skill tree but each soldier also has a few personal randomized skills to choose from.
* Soldiers can multiclass.
* Geography matters for travel time and ability to respond to emergencies. You start building multiple bases across the globe, and you can build multiple ships and have multiple squads running around.
* For the most part, technology unlocks are vertical. That is to say that new weapons are usually not flatout better, they just have different stats.
* Consumables are consumed. The game makes it very easy to resupply your soldiers after every mission, but each ammo clip you empty or grenade you throw costs resources to resupply. By extension, soldiers need to carry ammunition if they want to reload.

There are some minor bugs and glitches, but they're mostly cosmetic. I have not encountered anything game-breaking. Comparatively, I have encountered about the same amount of issues that you get in XCOM or any similar game, maybe slightly less, so it's par for the course.

82794000.review:
Phoenix Point is one of those games that makes me curse the binary nature of the steam review. It is a classic 6/10 game and the thumbs up it receives from me is so half-hearted that it barely makes it above the fingerline. I want you to know that this is a deeply flawed game, that you might enjoy for at least a little while.

Standard opening for context. Who the hell am I? I'm the guy who;

-Got X-COM: Terror from the Deep as one of the two first games I owned on my PC in 1996
-Have since played UFO: EU, Apocalypse, XCOM (2012) and XCOM2, in addition to one of the open source UFO games.
-Of those games, the one that stands out for me as the series at its best is XCOM2 (vanilla). The others are, to my mind, all similarly flawed.

But enough about me, let's talk about Julian Gallop, the man on whose name this game was sold. See Julian was responsible for the original XCOM (and Apocalypse), and since XCOM is strategy royalty and the series has been in a bit of a rut since XCOM2, who better to reinvigorate the genre?

Let's be clear. Phoenix point is XCOM. It's a cover-based, turn-based shooter where your team of marine-types fight of scores of alien creatures, whilst also managing bases and researching the alien menace to progress. I would assume that if you're reading this, you know XCOM and are simply asking where this sits in the list of best XCOM games.

Phoenix Point continues the tradition of XCOM games being b-movie stories. If the modern XCOM games choose the ass-kicking scientists trope, Phoenix point prefers a slightly more nerdy approach. The plot is there, but after a bit I started skipping the new plot sections. I doubt anyone would be glued to their seat in awe of the badly scripted and acted scenes, but they are there to provide some context to the carnage. What I will say is that following WotC's assertion that Alien's are basically Orcs who got lost on the way back from the last Shadow of Mordor design, it is pleasant to see aliens that once again look alien.

So what does Phoenix point bring to the table that XCOM doesn't? The key differential is the "realistic ballistic" mechanic. Realistic is probably a stretch, but rather than the simple percentage chance to hit, you now have a crosshair based system where all shots land inside the outer circle and 50% will land inside the inner. I suspect the inspiration for this all the times your soldier in XCOM had been stood next to an enemy and inexplicably decided to fire straight up into the sky. The other idea is that with each bullet in a burst calculated individually, you are less prone to XCOM's bullshitometer. Phoenix point is a world where you work on 50% of the potential damage output and anything else is a bonus. By and large the above system actually works very well, and though the bullshitometer is very much present, at least I'm missing by a hair rather than a point on the compass.

The other thing that has changed is the tactical map. XCOM's floating base - which a lot of long-term fans found quick reductionist - is gone, and we are back to the Terror From the Deep world of multiple bases to cover multiple areas. Although even by TFtD's standards this has been cranked up heavily. I suspect you would need something like 30 different bases to cover the globe. That isn't a requirement necessarily, but if you are the completionist those are the figures that you're looking at.

This is a major theme in the design of Phoenix Point; the idea that "less is more" is wholly untrue, and in fact "more is more." How would you like five different types of shotgun, all with their own strengths and weaknesses? 10 alien unit types? Pfft. Phoenix point has well over 40! Three factions (more with dlc) to either ally or antagonise. Several different quest lines. A huge research tree. The works. For the people who were disappointed that the modern XCOM's scaled back so many of these features it reads list a wishlist.

As the adage goes, though, be careful what you wish for.

My first issue with Phoenix point is that the interface has a clunkiness to it that really seems like bad design. It is epitomised by the manufacturing screen, where you can sort items by the soldier's class, but not by item type. So to go back to those five shotguns you will need to memorise each detail and scroll up and down through the rest of the items to view each one. It makes comparison a pain in the arse, and I'm not sure why it was excluded.

The next issue is that for all the choice to have 40 odd aliens, the reality is that most are copy-paste reskins with boosted stats. The simple reality is that there are very few that create a true sense of fear when they arrive on the map. I didn't always like the art design in XCOM2 but there was no doubt that when a Muton/Crysalid/Gatekeeper showed up for the first time it was always a brown pants moment. Phoenix Point only really has one of those, the mind controlling, will-sapping Zerg-like shitbag. The game also tells you at the start of each month that you'll be facing new enemies and gives you a breakdown on each one. Call me a traditionalist, but would it be more dramatic to discover these threats in battle rather than in a small pamphlet?

There are technically more variation in the classes in Phoenix point, including the option to multi-class (which most soldiers will inevitably do). Yet when I compare the choices on offer to that of XCOM:EU or XCOM2, most powers feel a lot less dramatic. They have also done away with the rank system, and instead gone for simple character levels, which is a bit disappointing. The de facto best way to level up those characters is to buy training centres and just leave them in the HQ, which isn't really in the spirit of things. Customisation is very much a tertiary concern, but Phoenix Point is much more limited than XCOM and also seems to have some very, very odd ideas about what hair looks like. I'm also still scratching my head why I can't rename and customise the two characters from the prologue, who have contributed absolutely nothing to the story at any point since.

Yet these issues are but minor ones, and Phoenix Point could still be a great game in spite of them. It isn't, of course, and that is because of the next issue.

It is exactly the same problem that UFO:EU had, that Terror from the Deep had, and that XCOM Apocalypse had, but it's somehow even worse here. See all those games were characterised by Julian's approach to game design: Take a good idea, make the game expansive and then slowly drive the player off by making them engage in the same process an ungodly amount of times. The XCOM games I mentioned at the start - only the modern games I completed. I didn't fail to complete the early ones because I couldn't, I chose not to complete them because after a while they became repetitive and dull. XCOM:EU and XCOM2 don't get everything perfect but they have gone to great lengths to make ensure that you're stuck in these traps that plagued the old games.

Eventually in Phoenix point you will expand to have bases on 3-4 continents. At this point the game falls apart on itself because it feels like that should be headway, but at that point - the point I am at right now - the Haven and base attacks are so frequent that I don't have time to do the main quest. Yet these haven attacks are directly tied to a failstate of the world's population, so I have to get involved. Even more frustratingly, the transport aircraft presumably have an elaborate holographic device that creates the illusion of jet propulsion instead of the propellers they must actually be using in order to get anywhere that slowly. My troops were in my base in the western US. My base in China got attacked, but I had 24 hours notice. The craft could not get there in time.

Phoenix point quickly descends into the standard Gallop slog. If you liked the original XCOM games, carry on. If it was just the reboots, you might want to steer clear.

I picked up the game when it released on steam. I would have bought it the day it came out but they pulled the 1 year epic exclusive crap. I refuse to put that launcher on my pc. I beat xcom reboot and put over 1k hours into XCOM 2+WOTC because of the awesome modding community. I have mixed feelings about Phoenix Point. I for one hated how the creator back stabbed the donators by selling his soul to EPIC. I'm glad I waited the year for the release because I heard the game was very buggy at launch. Which makes me question "Hey. All those millions of dollars EPIC paid you to release your game on their platform. If it's this broken at release just how much of that money went into the game?"

The geoscape. Feels like it's more play your way instead of playing how the game wants you too. Keeping nations happy for supplies, no thanks. In PP(lol) your mostly left to your own devices. Which can feel overwhelming at first but is nice once you get the hang of it. The pit stop mechanic feels wrong though. There have been times where I didn't do missions because I couldn't get there. The Pure's fortress was in Australia for me and I had nothing near there. By the time I got a ship with a far enough range to raid the place the entire country was wasted.

I love how you can aim at specific body parts instead of a hit %. I really hated in XCOM how you can fire a shotgun point blank into a muton with 98% and miss! I love shooting things in the arms to disable their weapons ect. I also love that I don't need a target to fire. If someone is hiding behind a wall I can try to punch a hole in the wall. I could do that in the original XCOM and I missed that feature.

Their version of overwatch is better than XCOM and worse at the same time. It was good to be able to point where I wanted the soldier to shoot. However that wasn't enough. Several enemies crawl. Your soldiers will take shots at them even if it is impossible to connect a shot. My biggest issue with overwatch was the fact the enemies are still moving when a shot is taken. I've had 5 people pointing at one guy. When the first 2 finished their shots the little bastard had ran past the other 3 and killed someone. Forcing me to restart the mission. It would be nice if the enemy moved a bit slower when being shot at or my troops fired a bit faster.

Not enough mission types. Mostly I'm protecting havens or doing a scavenging missions. Those got old real quick. I like the base defense missions but it would have been nice to actually have facilities to help you with those defenses. Eventually I ran out of points of interest and it felt like I was only doing haven defense missions majority of the game. When I completed the game I checked my stats and I had done over 6 scavenging missions, 2 soldier rescues, 6 base defense missions, 4 ancient ruin defense, 19 nests, 12 lairs, 5 citadels and over 60 haven defense missions. That gives you an idea of what you will be doing most of this game.

Base layout was dull. There was no real reason to think about how you build your bases. No thought process on what to build or where to put it. Except for 1 base that was basically a farm, all my other bases where exactly the same. There is a reason to build multiple bases, which reminds me of the old xcom. However each base feels so dull and like it's there so you can reach other areas. In the old XCOM I had several defense facilities I could construct. If I had enough a UFO was destroyed before it landed. Preventing the need to defend the base at all.

Not enough enemies. I do love how they evolve and adapt to what your doing but it just felt like there wasn't enough types. Their version of a heavy, assault and berserker was the exact same enemy. Just with different armor and weapons. Some enemies had really cheesy mechanics. I hated Umbras. I really disliked how a siren can walk a country mile, mind control someone then walk another mile to get behind a structure. Making it impossible to hit her.

Classes. I like and hate the fact you can mix classes. Some combinations are amazing. Like snipers with rage burst or techs who can toss turrets straight from their inventory. However I felt the classes alone were not enough. It's like they knew you would combine 2 classes so they gave us 2 halves to make 1 whole. Some classes flat out need a specific sub class to function. Like the berserker. I felt I needed to train them in assault for dash so they could get into melee range. The Priest class was cool but it feels very weak compared to the Psi Operatives I'm used too from WOTC. Once a squad got maxed out I lost a little interest in battles because there was nothing more to learn.

I like the 3 factions. Their backgrounds, the fact we can trade with them, share research, steal stuff from them. A nice touch. I did feel a little overwhelmed at times when multiple havens were being attacked at once. I like how we can appease to all of them but once they start fighting each other, it felt like being ashamed to be a human. Couldn't we at least wait till after we wiped out Pandora before turning on each other? If I start another play through I plan to raid them more so I can get a better start.

The aircraft. I felt like the generic manticore is the best aircraft. Fits enough people and goes pretty fast. The New Jericho helicopter plane had more room but it's slower than manticore. The synedrion plane was quick but could only fit 5 people. The Anu blimp has the most space but it was so damn slow I regret stealing it. When I found out how slow it was I wanted to give it back. I had a starting position in South America. When I expanded to North America I moved my blimp up north. Some missions ended before it even got there. I had to send it back south and move the manticore up there.

I liked the various research trees. Different weapons for different play styles. Certain factions offer different research. It didn't feel like a linear path compared to xcom. Unlock laser/gauss weapons first, get armor then go straight to plasma weapons. 

The story is gripping me. Similar to XCOM but different enough to be it's own thing and I love the lovecraftian take on it. I would have enjoyed some actual CG cut scenes instead of still pictures. The voice actors were average but they didn't have any names I recognized. My biggest issue with the story is multiple endings. I don't have a problem with that but how to get them. Making max research with a faction unlocks their final mission. Which is essentially the same as the final battle except the ending is different. Researching the Phoenix solution forces you to take their ending.

I despise the ancients DLC. The hoplites are annoying as #@$% with their shields. I have multiple sites and I still can't find the one that lets me craft the weapons and it's more crap to protect. I couldn't find all the manufacturing sites.

The cover system feels crappy. I felt despite being in cover enemies could still hit me pretty regularly. I had a heavy with a robotic augment that gave him a shield. They had zero trouble shooting him in the head -.- It almost reminded me of playing Gears of War 5. When playing horde on Master difficulty. Even if you are in cover they can still hit you. It's just flat out better to block line of sight then to be in actual cover.

Last the final mission. First half is fun but the 2nd is really bad. You will know when you see it.
Overall if you like xcom this game is alright. Has some things I wish xcom had and vice versa. Get it when it's on sale though.

Had several dozen hours on the X-Box App before buying it here.

Phoenix Point is a nice deviation away from the linear formula of Firaxis' XCOM and XCOM2. If you found the lack of strategic layer a flaw in the Firaxis games, then Phoenix Point will give you more to do, although don't count on it being very complex. Technology progression is more of a web with more subtly defined power level progression. For instance, the enemies will develop armor plating, but you can get weapons that have more armor penetration.

The setting is more interesting, but again, don't expect anything ground breaking. The overall production value is nice but is clearly outproduced by Firaxis' much bigger development budget. Overall, the game's technical details are passable.

Is it a solid recommendation? No, but it's still worth playing, especially if you found XCOM2 to be lacking in that open decision space that players of the original X-Com games enjoyed. The lack of a pod system and strict turn limits on missions alone makes the game worth checking.

82739781.review:
Adding complexity can make a game more interesting and strategic, but it can also make you lose elegance.

Phoenix Point is XCOM with too many fiddly bits, numerical values, all without a well constructed tutorial for the non-combat portion of the game. And yes, I'll be comparing the two because more than likely if you're getting phoenix point it's because you like XCOM. Phoenix Point ads complexity in some ways that are, in theory, nice additions. Controlling the range of your Overwatch so you take better shots is the best feature with nothing to complain about. Splitting your actions into 4 per turn that can be used in any order is nice, but movement in PP is so poor that it often feels like you can do less than in XCOM.  The option to build multiple aircrafts and bases is good in theory, bogged down by the game's poor handling of resource management. And then it's downhill from there, with a dozen different damage types, resources that don't clearly portray their availability or use, and various mechanics that aren't clear. Finally, the attempt at a VATS knockoff falls flat, as most enemies either die fast enough that there's no point in limb crippling, or have so much HP and armor per limb that you're better off just focusing down their head or torso for the kill.

The game boasts 7 classes, but 4 of them are only available through the other factions. Multiclassing is an option. Most skills are very boring and direct in their usefulness. Ultimately, the Heavy and Assault classes felt horribly inferior to Snipers, so the game became about whether you wanted snipers with more horizontal or verticle mobility. 

In a vacuum, the enemy designs are good, but it gets samey very fast. In XCOM, while a few enemies are upgraded versions of weaker ones with a slightly different look, at 20 hours in all enemies look like one of only a handful or variations.

TL;DR Phoenix Point is XCOM with more ideas than good gameplay. Play only if you'd rather read a player's handbook than play DnD.

82731986.review:
Fun game.  Worth the asking price.  A steal on sale.
What are you getting for your money?   An enjoyable game with turn based battles and a decent story.
What aren't you getting?  X-com.   THIS IS NOT X-COM.  

I've played all the X-Coms, and while I enjoyed them, the big combat maps ( especially in X-com 2 ) could drag on and on.  Maps are smaller in Phoenix Point.  Enemies have their own agenda - sometimes they are gathering supplies,  sometimes destroying buildings, sometimes killing citizens. sometimes gathering intelligence. 

It gives a nice variety to the game.  And that's the area where Phoenix Point shines - in its variety.  Land on an "explore area" and you could wind up with a text encounter that yields supplies, faction, or moral choices.  Or you could get ambushed by raiders, or critters, or one of the three factions. 

 You can help the in game factions or choose to raid them yourself.  Why build an aircraft when you can steal it? 

In some ways the game improves on the X-com series.  You can always choose to "free aim" . This brings up a targeting ring with two areas - an inner area and an outer ring. Bullets will always land somewhere within the two ( unless they hit an object on the way to the target ). 
No more RNG miss madness.  If you aim center mass and both targeting areas are on the target, you are going to hit something.  You may not hit the little squishy body part that fills only part of the two rings - but you will hit something inside those two rings.  Specific body parts have specific functions.  Wound a leg and the enemy will move slower.  Blow off a giant, pointy arm and that hulking creature can no longer stab you with it.  The targeting and "real balistics" are a great improvement over X-com .  

Even though it's not X-com, there are still some traditional X-com moments.  Don't have time to use the front door?  Blow a hole in the back wall and charge in to rescue a citizen from hot alien death.

Tactically, your starting squad is fairly weak on skills and abilities.  As they level up, your combat options expand.  One great feature is that your heavy weapon user starts out with a jet pack.  Swoop down on an enemy and bash them to death with your auto cannon  ( this is pretty much a necessity because firing your auto cannon takes three of your four action points but bashing only takes one ) . 

A plus - or minus depending how you view such things - is the presence of a "doom timer".   If the human population falls under a certain percentage, it's game over.  If the "skull bar" fills up fully...  not sure what happens, hasn't happened yet, but probably nothing good.   What it boils down to is that time is not your friend.  Enemies continually get stronger and have improved skills.   A red fog of infection spreads inexorably over the map.   If a constant sense of doom or the unfairness of alien infestation excites you, then Phoenix Point is what you are looking for.

Some players have experienced bugs.  I haven't come across any.  The game has been very stable for me.  

Is Phoenix Point  X-com or X-com plus ?  No.  And that's not a bad thing.   Phoenix Point is a fun game with varied elements and enjoyable turn based battles.   Give it a go and see.

82716875.review:
I really like the XCOM games (I played a ton of the original Enemy Unknown as a kid) so I spent a ton of time trying to find the fun here.  For the most part, I was unsuccessful.  There are some things here that work, but lots more that don't.  

In some ways, the game is very concerned with being "realistic"; eg. the "realistic bullet physics". The idea sounds promising, but it doesn't play out well.  Aiming for body parts is often a trivial decision, or a non-decision.  Often your shot/throw gets blocked by a random terrain feature that was impossible to see/plan for.  In reality, often you could work around these obstacles - you could lean over a little bit, or throw your grenade on a different trajectory.  Here, you're just randomly screwed.  

I remember when XCOM 2012 came out and a few people were disappointed that each gun didn't have its own ammunition.. turns out that was a good idea.  PP lets you waste your time buying and scrapping 100 different ammo types, clogging up the crappy UI, and never gives you any gameplay payoff for doing so.  XCOM lets you have some custom ammo types - but at the cost of a scarce equipment slot which makes for an actual interesting choice, unlike any of your inventory decisions here (which are basically non-existent, as you normally have tons of slots/weight to give).   Equipment is mostly lame, with way too many variants of very similar weapons.  You very rarely get the satisfying feeling of a "next generation" weapon upgrade like you do in XCOM (moving to laser/plasma/whatever).

The level design is just terrible.  The maps are bland and repetitive.  You spend a ton of time slowly crawling over empty distances, especially when the map has one enemy left that you can't find.  It took me a half hour to find a stupid worm in a pit once.  The levels are full of overhangs/squigglies that block vision and hinder gameplay in random/tedious ways.  

Mission difficulty is all over the map; some "story" missions were bizarrely easy, some were fine, some were easy but with "traps" you had to work around (or bad random setups that you just wanted to reroll).  In general the difficulty is too low, but spikes to "very frustrating" (eg. the orichalcum shield ancients, or the final boss), especially if your strategy doesn't line up well with the arbitrary, unpredictable mechanics of the mission (which you then solve by reloading/re-equipping: fun!).

There aren't many "real" enemy types, and what's there is super bland.  The enemy evolution feels arbitrary/meaningless, and doesn't pay off in interesting decisions or gameplay.  I paid no attention to whether something was a Arthron Spork Wimpleclip or a Arthron Wankle Splink Engine.  The only gameplay difference they made was whether they had a shield and/or a gun.  The variety of enemies in XCOM is one of the core reasons that game was great, and one of the core problems with PP is how bland the enemies feel.

The AI in XCOM 2012 was reasonably simple and predictable, making the game a contest between your superior tactics vs. their superior power/numbers.  That worked out fine, it's a perfectly workable design.  It's not necessary for your opponents to be tacticians - but it would also be OK if they were.  Instead, the AI here is mega-random.  Sometimes enemies dodge around 3 layers of overwatch to have every enemy on the map focus fire one of your dudes (which makes you shrug and re-load).  Other times a strong enemy (eg. a Siren) runs out in front of 4 of your people and does nothing.  Just waits to die a completely unsatisfying death.  

Your tactics against this random level of opposition tend to end up in one of two directions: you play ultra-cautious and tediously crawl around the map... or just save every turn and YOLO around every corner.  Neither is fun.  I really missed the perfectly implemented timed missions of XCOM 2, where you had to balance out caution and speed.  Or the terror missions.  Most missions here have no timer, and the equivalent of the terror missions still generally just feel like "kill all enemies".

I much prefered playing XCOM 2 on Ironman mode; here the randomness would make that very ill advised.  I imagine most people save scum pretty hard.  That's lame, and drains the game of tension - but it'd be way too frustrating to play PP that way (even the "tips" pretty much tell you to save often).  One of the great mechanics in recent XCOM games were how injuries predominated over deaths.  You paid a penalty for taking big hits - people wouldn't be available for some time so you'd have to rotate through people - but you could reasonably muddle through.

Here, you can lose a few people randomly (and permanently) in an instant (especially to the stupid "umbras", which are a huge random difficulty spike in lots of otherwise easy missions).   So when you lose people, you reload.  That trains you to see losing people as unavoidable, irrelevant, random, and tension-free.  Ran around a corner with no actions left and died?  Who cares, you just reload.

PP does have an injury/stamina system, but it rarely came into play for me.  Serious injuries are rare - usually people just die if they get caught out, and otherwise you heal up with medpacks (which means they're instantly ready to go for next mission, bad design decision here) - so you never feel the same pressure to rotate through members.  You just wait at base until everyone's healed up, then go out again.  The game loses a significant source of interesting decisions (which is a theme with many of the design decisions here).

The upgrades are lame.  XCOM gave you choices of which branch to take - and often you wanted to take both because they were strong and interesting.  But having to pick one was an interesting decision, and meant your people (even of the same class) felt different as they took different choices.  Here, you can dual class and eventually get every upgrade for a character.  This makes your soldiers feel bland and samey.  The upgrades themselves are rarely interesting, with a lot of slots that are just stat boosts or generic abilities (eg. Dash, which you'll get on everyone who can take it).  The one interesting tactic I found (rapid clearance + melee weapon discount, meaning you could easily kill 20 enemies in a turn with one character, especially if you had 4 allies standing around donating action points) felt mega stupid, completely outclassed comparable strategies, and was completely at odds with the tone the game is aiming for.   

I could spend another few paragraphs talking about how much I hate the geoscape, how tedious it is to jet around putting out fires, and in general how the decisions you make in base building/flying around are less interesting than the equivalent decisions in XCOM.   The research tree was bland, and I never felt I was making an interesting decision about what to get next.  It's very easy to get too many research stations and have nothing left to research (because it's all locked behind Ally garbage).. that felt lame and against theme.

Overall... I have endless more complaints and I'm tired of writing.  I feel like lots of design decisions here were guided by weird "principles" or something, choosing (arbitrarily defined) "realism" and "ideas that sounded clever when we were getting started" over "whatever decisions makes for an interesting game".  Over the whole 40 hours (or whatever) I played, I very rarely felt anything other than "glad I don't have to do that mission again".  

If this was the first entry in a new genre (like Enemy Unknown was in 199X) this would seem like a promising game with a bunch of great ideas.  Instead, it's running against a vastly, vastly improved version of itself (in the form of XCOM2, especially with the DLC) - and that makes all of its flaws, shortcomings and outright failings visible in very sharp contrast.

The return fire mechanic is simply broken. Whenever a character is taking a shot, he will step out of cover, fire, and then the enemy will return fire. Only then will your character move back into cover. (If he's not dead by then)

The line of sight and ability to free aim is a good idea, but unfortunately, it is, just like the return fire, not well implemented. It is hard to believe the creator of XCOM made such a poorly designed game...

It is a shame, because it has otherwise good ideas. I like the idea of managing the inventories of my soldier, of exploring the globe and building bases.

But as it stands, Phoenix Point is barely playable because of these two issues.

On the surface this looks like a XCOM clone and it basically is. 

The Good:
The most drastic change from XCOM is the way hits are determined. Instead of a percentage you take aim and have 2 rings, around half your shots will land in the inner ring and all of your shots will land inside the outer ring forcing you to think about angles and what exactly you are aiming at. Oddly this mechanic is not taken farther with the concept of aimed shots (Higher action point cost for smaller ring) to vary your tactical options. Riot shields are also added for both you and the enemy and this works very well with the new aim mechanic. The concept of having to explore locations on the world map for missions and resources is also nice and the story is decent.

The Bad:
Unfortunately just about everything else is wrong with this game. The difficulty curve even on the lowest setting is insane. Anyone that has played XCOM Enemy Unknown/Within knows it is possible at least on the lower settings to not lose a single nation or soldier and win. Good luck with that with Phoenix Point. By the end of the first in game month The enemy has received at least a dozen upgrades while there are literally no true upgrades to be had for your forces. I am not really even sure what the point of research in this game is considering there is so little to research. There is also the fact that equipping soldiers costs a small fortune per soldier and takes days to produce the equipment. This is not helped by the fact by the end of the game your people might as well be made of paper and you have to split your squads across the world. You will NEVER be ahead of the game when it comes to having equipment or manpower. There is also the fact there is no real way to protect the populations in havens because even if you do manage to keep the infected and raiders off of them they do not produce any food and starve to death for some reason leaving me wondering why I am even bothering, The range on your transport is also painfully short making travailing to new hot spots extremely time consuming and difficult. What makes all of this together so annoying is they really could have followed the XCOM formula here and come out with a very good game

Over all I do not recommend it as the bad far outweighs the good. I would refund this if I could but there is just enough here to make you go past the deadline before you see the games numerous problems.

82673050.review:
WALL OF TEXT: After the equivalent of one workweek playing Phoenix Point I've hit a wall. On one hand the game is a great tactical turn based sim -- but on the other hand it's a busy mess that punishes more than it praises. Victories bring little reward while failures are crushing and brutal. One mechanic in most of Xcom's iterations (and spiritual successors like Phoenix Point) have in common is a research tree that allows you to take your victories and shift the balance of power back in your favor. Enemies have deadly weapons? Kill them and reverse engineer them. Powerful new aliens arrive? Research powerful new weapons. In Phoenix point it seems like this would be the case too -- but the better guns never arrive. You start out against a foe more than fairly matched with the initial evolutions of your foe being easy to knock over, but they rapidly get every advantage you do, plus a whole lot more and they just get harder and harder without the player (despite a complex research tree and factions to share research) giving you anything that really helps you overcome your enemy much less turn the tide. The closest to a weapons breakthrough I was given was a powerful but woefully inaccurate cannon weapon but even that got outstripped by the endless march of the armor and size of the opponents you face. The game gave me resources I didn't even know how to use or have an avenue to utilize, and had numerous "artifact" resources I only learned how to find by the time it was too late. You can never have enough men to cover all your bases, and unprotected bases if raided are totally destroyed making it economically unfeasable to restore them to functioning. There are lots of different craft to choose from to move your squads, but the ones that allow you to move big squads are too slow, and the fast ones don't move enough troops into an engagement to win. You'll only be able to maintain about 1.5-2.5 good squads of troops, and losing anyone will be devastating forcing you to save scum (though I consider this standard in the genre) ... what is NOT standard is how 1-2 squads simply cannot get done what is called for to be done and that's all you get. When I hit the "Wall" I had as stated only two squads/vehicles, and the map was COVERED in plot advancing quests on the other side of the earth Where it took forever to get to and back from, with multiple havens getting raided at the same time. You inexplicably don't pick up most of the guns off the people you kill forcing you to spend/waste resources restocking after every mission and frankly it's a losing battle even keeping your troops supplied. A good metaphor for this game is a 4-star meal served to you with fine presentation only to learn your silverware is the size of toothpicks and the bites of the food are huge and you're incapable of cutting them into manageable pieces until the waiter starts grinding your face into your meal by stomping on the back of your head with a combat boot and as you slowly lose consciousness things start to get REALLY mean. 

Seriously -- I felt like I had access to scores of weapons in my playthrough -- but none of them were effective against the aliens. Shotguns that promised to do deadly damage at close range PINGED off of mid-late game enemies armor. Only sniper weapons and unwieldy cannons seemed to harm foes AT ALL, with opponents cleaning your friggin' clock with comparatively similar weapons... because your armor isn't nearly as broken as the aliens.

The faction dynamic in this game is really flavorful and dare I say cool on the surface, but it boils down to a ridiculous game of "three-stooges" with all of humanity on the brink of extinction and each faction being more absorbed with hurting each other over conflicting ideals than fighting the monsters that are LITERALLY EATING THEM. It's like a synedrion scientist would be getting devoured from the waist down by an alien while he is ordering you to sabotage a New Jericho factory for reasons that are completely unexplainable. 

Humanity is in the same boat, but everyone is bailing water into each others parts of the rowboat, with predictable results. It looked like there was plenty of game left when I stopped playing because like I said, it just kept getting more and more brutal. It ended for me when I finally faced an alien that was as big and armored as several vehicles with a health meter to boot, that pooped aliens that mind controlled your characters and if you even grazed it would put up a smoke screen to hide it -- and there I was looking at the same damn toothpicks and inaccurate cannons to take it on. 

I gave up, unwilling to waste another 40 hours to hit the wall again because even with everything I learned in that long of playing a campaign I didn't see hope in trying again with knowledge and optimization. If I were you, I'd move on, and give up in advance. If you want a good Xcom game play the actual Xcoms or try PHANTOM DOCTRINE which is a refreshing departure from the genre, instead. This game is just a pretty Xcom clone that turns you and your danglies into a punching bag.
