I wanted to like the game but instead I hated it.
Everything that got me hooked where things I ended up hating, I really recommend you try this within the 2 hour period, if you don't like it it is not going to get better.

There's just so many design flaws that I cant understand the reasoning behind. No fog of war so you don't know where your soldiers can see and not. This is a big deal, I need that info. I cant see behind walls in real life so when monsters just pop up because I had to assume I could see behind a corner its incredibly frustrating. 
There are apparently places with fog of war so the technology to have that is there. I wouldn't know though I gave up before that, and its not the norm and no mods/options to change anything about it which is weird because there's like 3 DLCs out already and a 4th one is on its way.

The strategy part takes forever because it insists of locking the camera to the soldier you're moving and showing you how they run to where you told them to go. It feels incredibly slow. Even the original X-com had tricks to speed up sending soldiers from A to B. 
I don't need to watch my guy run to see what a good job he did reaching where I told him to go, speed that shit up if you have to show me that or give me the option to do so at least. Now I have to watch people accelerate, run for 4-5 seconds and then de-accelerate and get into position 4-5 times per turn.
Xenonauts did this right, your guy will be where you tell him to be, and he will walk there and you're free to keep assigning orders in the meantime. if he runs into an alien he will stop and alert you. 
Going from that to how Phoenix Point handles things feels like a step back. I mean - it LOOKS cool, the game has really nice graphics and animations but the information provided is not important.

The cover system is also annoying. I thought it would make the game deeper but it just makes it feel more shallow somehow. Everybody is running around to get inside of cover/get into the enemies cover. I don't like it and that's a core feature.

It's incredibly hard to get an overview of how the battle scene is and after a while I just ended up with the good old "pixel hunting" with my mouse, looking square by square at which square be the best square to move to in the case of having cover/being able to shoot the enemy instead of actually looking at area. 
I would say that relying on this information is a crutch for a fundamentally flawed system. I think I would have prefered just some kind of matrix version where I would just be able to see that info at all times. It feels like the "real world" graphics that is not a bunch of lines telling you where safe is is just cosmetics. It's really annoying. The battle scape has too much information and too little information at the same time if that makes sense.

It's a weird decision because I saw a game designer for X-com 2 say they scrapped this design because of the reason I just mentioned. You don't look at the world, you look at where the lines are the most optimal.

There's a lot I can say about the game but the reason it hurts is because I know there is a great game in there but its being held hostage of these for me horrible mechanics. It's possible it's not my kind of game but I don't know who would enjoy this.

I wanted to "get" the combat so I could finally enjoy the game, but the only way apparently is to just "keep playing until you get it". I'm all for "git gud", I love punishing games but in this case I just feel like there's a huge mountain of actual frustration, not challenge to get over and I gave up. Everything is so vague and the combat is so "loose", the more I learned about it the less I wanted to play.

The game seems to know this as well because combat early on (my only point of reference) is extremely easy and I feel that also holds me back from learning how to play it. None of my choices matter really. I tried to play as strategically as I could, trying to learn the new cover system but it only ended up with me feeling that I wasted time because when I would just run up to the baddies and blast them in the face point blanc they died all the same and I had to spend less time being forced watching my guys run.

Permadeath is an awesome mechanic but you are going to have to punish me at some point for doing something wrong so I can learn and get a feel for how to play the game. Reading guides etc still just give me the tip "get a feel of how to play" and if that's the best a game that's been out for one year can give me then I'm sorry the battle design is just too vague.

It took me on average 6 hours of studying up on how to play the game, and this is by alt-tabbing and preparing by late night watching youtube videos about "how to play to be able to enjoy the game".

Eventually I I just cut my losses and played another game of Xenonauts instead.

It just hurts because I would love to like this game so much but theres just so many things you just "have to get over" for me that I will never enjoy the awesome things I really hope future games take inspiration from.

The Good: The free-aim system this game implements is unique and interesting. It requires you to think about a tactical situation very differently from XCOM EU and XCOM 2, where each individual must be placed carefully so they don't get caught in the cross-fire as opposed to bullets magically passing through. Its also important to consider cover and line of sight with the free aim which impacts the success of your shot. There is also the added benefit that even if you miss you still can score some damage on your opponent. I also like the fact that the soldiers have accented English in accordance to nationality, something XCOM has not really done except for very specific characters. Plus the story has a cool premise that is not boxed in by the precedent set by XCOM UFO Defense.

The Bad: Unfortunately, it seems this game has put all its bets on the free-aim system and it has definitely not paid off. The strategic layer has nothing more to offer than XCOM 2. Base building is boring, and resource management even more so since your involvement with either component is pretty surface-level. The various factions aren't that interesting because acting on behalf of one makes the others unhappy. Not that this makes a difference in the overall game as the negative impact is negligible. The game looks and feels like a bad XCOM 2 mod. The character models and customization is bad. The collision physics are bad since the environments feel like its all made of cardboard when it is destroyed. The controller support feels like something the developer slapped on last minute. The mouse pointer is always in the middle of the screen even during dialog and cutscenes. The cutscenes seem to be entirely comprised of concept art and textboxes. I have not finished a full campaign as of this review because the thought of going back to this game makes me consider what I would rather be doing. The game has committed the worst sin imaginable; it's boring and the developer wants you to pay $60 for a game that's realistically worth $20-15. It's highway robbery.

I've eventually given up on every campaign I've played of PP - both on Steam and a few on the Epic Store when it was originally released (and has improved significantly since). 

There's a lot to be said in the game's favour - the ballistics and limb-destruction systems are cool (though, like every comparison to be made between XCOM and PP, you get about one measure of cool for three measures of added fiddling around), and there's a much more considered story/setting than XCOM, even if it is a story told principally through text boxes and concept art cut-scenes and experiences jarring lurches of tones between its grounded military realism and Lovecraftian horror fantasy. 

But three features of PP always line up to make me stop caring:
- Probably in service of its narrative tone, the game is the opposite of XCOM's strategic difficulty: experienced soldiers still die like flies and rookies are extremely expensive to hire, train and equip. This means that after a bad setback (i.e. less than one well-equipped squad in the lategame, when generally you'll only have 1.5-2 going), it's extremely hard to work your way back. There are also very few weapons/technologies/abilities that give you a decisive advantage over the aliens, so there's no ability to get that plasma rifle or whatever and swing back the odds. Those buildings/weapons that do make a difference also take piles of resources and ages to build/research, which discourages experimenting with novel strategies.
- The game is extraordinarily mechanically tedious at times with lots of clicks per engagement - i.e. if you're feeling a bit grumpy about having lost your A-Team, expect a large amount of real-world time before you get a win that makes you feel better. This also goes for outfitting your soldiers, who will ideally be tailored for each encounter. Longish load times and frequent bugs and personal missteps (did you not see the small icon that indicated your target would return fire?) only increase this problem.
- The world doesn't feel worth saving. The factions are catty and ludonarratively interchangeable (e.g. Synedrion's internal bickering the whole time doesn't seem to affect much mechanically). The world is a succession of bombed out wastelands ad nauseam, sprinkled with occasional Apple stores (Synedrion), prison factories (New Jericho), slums (Anu) and impossible to navigate alien slaughterhouses, all essentially devoid of civilians. Apart from a timorously-voiced tutorial assistant, there is no-one in control of Phoenix Point apart from you - and if you're like me, you think it's time to pack it in, too.

TLDR: Phoenix Point is a good game, not a great one, but that’s not its fault. Although the genre is mature and overcrowded, there’s enough here for TBS fans to enjoy and appreciate.

Let me begin by saying that I have not played XCOM2, and cannot make comparisons between the two games. I have however played all the other original XCOM games, XCOM:EU and rebooted franchises like UFO and Xenonauts.This type of game -- alien-invasion type turn-based strategy with tactical combat -- is a very familiar one to gamers, as the genre has been around for a long time. As such, it is very difficult to break new ground, improve on classic systems that work, or refine time-tested designs and approaches. Nine hours in, these are my impressions so far (I will update this review after I complete the game if those change):

+ Storyline is decent, graphics are fresh and updated, voice-acting for the campaign is good, music is appropriate without being too repetitive of annoying

+ Materials / resource management in bases adds another strategic layer, and resupply missions (without incurring too many troop injuries) become vital. These resources have replaced the monetary units that you used to need to buy things, recruit soldiers, etc

+ Combat works well: bullet ballistics, LOS all appear sensible, and "free aiming" allows you to make targeted shots against creatures' weak spots for better tactical outcomes

+ Diplomacy has been updated and enhanced; you can gain advantages by allying with a particular faction, while raiding the others for equipment, research or supplies

+ I found the user interface streamlined, without unnecessary switching from one screen to another. The changes are subtle but improved from other similar-genre games

+ The ability to trade with factions (and recruit from them) is a nice touch, especially since some resources (like tech) can be hard to find. This enhances the strategic choices in building, recruiting and manufacturing -- everything uses these resources, so which do you pick first?

- Fuel doesn’t seem to matter for your aircraft. I’m assuming they get refuelled at the havens you land in, but this doesn’t seem clear. Range management used to be an issue in the early XCOM-type games, so you had to pick your bases carefully. This isn’t the case anymore (even though you still have to pick your bases carefully, for other reasons)

- As a way of standing out more, RPG elements could have been improved. Some gamers may disagree, but having troops with personalities can add to the satisfaction of bringing them into the battle throughout the campaign. Instead, they're just throwaway units here, which IMO is a missed opportunity

- After so many years of games in this genre (and so many lessons to learn from), there still isn’t enough here to make it great, or truly memorable. The formula is more or less the same, with some useful refinements and new features, but nothing earth-shattering enough to make you sit up and take notice

Final thoughts (for now): The field is overcrowded, so the competition is stiff; it’s difficult to stand out here. Is Phoenix Point a must-have game? Maybe, but it doesn’t belong at the top of that list. Does it break new ground or take the crown in the genre? Not in my opinion, but it has enough features and refinements that still make it worth getting/playing, and make it worth recommending. 

6.5/10.0

82174862.review:
It seems inevitable that a game which shares so much with XCOM (not the least of which being Julian Gollop, the lead developer) be compared to the modern XCOM games. Doubtless I am not the first and will not be the last to compare and contrast the two, but it is an important point to make, nonetheless.

While the XCOM games of the modern day give you plenty of soldiers early on, you must train them and keep them alive as best you can, because talent is scarce. Phoenix Point takes an almost inverted approach, in that you start with a scant team that you can't really afford to lose in the early game, but as you progress and build training facilities, it becomes easier to replace those super-soldiers who have fallen in the line of duty. I prefer the Phoenix approach, because the former feels like building an ever taller house of cards that could crumble and leave you with nothing at the first major mistake, while the latter feels like building an aeroplane as you fly it; terrifying at first but gradually more and more stable.

XCOM leaves whether or not shots connect with their target up to the big random number generator in the sky, while Phoenix lets you take matters into your own hands with manual aiming and a much, MUCH more robust movement system. The predictions that Phoenix provides, however, are not always as accurate as one would hope, leading to the awkward situation where you move your aiming reticle over an enemy's silhouette, and believe for all the world that your shot will end their life, only for the camera to pull back and reveal your bullet colliding with the tip of the stalagmite your soldier was using as half-cover, totally blocking the attack. Still, when it works, it's good.

Character classes are far better in Phoenix, with a system that allows the mixing and matching of the seven classes to create horrifying amalgams that combine each class's five abilities in new and exciting ways. Still, a little annoying trait is that each soldier must spend ability points on their new abilities, often forcing you to choose which skills are worth using and which you'd never actually employ. You can get as many ability points per soldier as successful missions you have them survive, but this leads to a re-treading of the XCOM issue where the strongest soldiers are the ones you've had all game long, and losing one will nullify a lot of your forward momentum.

My last comparison is regarding equipment. Grenades, the battle defining weapon of the XCOM games, are more or less useless in Phoenix, but replacing the XCOM Arc Thrower is Phoenix's Neurazer, not merely a tool for capturing enemies but a truly invaluable weapon in it's own right. There's no "basic kit" that you have an infinite supply of; each weapon and piece of armour is made to order, meaning four crafting projects are required to fully outfit a bare-naked soldier. Recruited soliders must be given guns on Hero difficulty and guns AND armour on Legend difficulty, or else the fresh meat becomes dead meat very quickly. This is offset by the fact that you can steal weapons (but not armour) from dead enemies in battle sometimes (it's random whether they drop them or not). So, swings and roundabouts.

Going off of these comparisons alone, I believe Phoenix Point to not merely be a XCOM clone, but rather the superior game, with a lot more strategic depth and room for decision making. It's definitely rough around the edges, but I feel that adds to it's charm. Would recommend to strategy game lovers of every evolutionary subspecies.

From all the Epic Store exclusives, [b]Phoenix Point[/b] was one of the most anticipated by fans worldwide, who just like me, couldn’t wait for the Steam version. I had the pleasure to review it a year ago, so please take in consideration that my Steam play time does not reflect my experience with [b]Phoenix Point[/b]. In fact, my playtime of 120 hours on Epic, could barely justify this review, since the included content is just subliminally impressive and will give you at least 300 hours of solid gameplay.

From the man himself, Mr. Julian Gollop, the mind behind X-COM, comes [b]Phoenix Point[/b], a video game that borrows the elements that made his work so famous for, into a new generation of gamers, and classic fans such as myself. To better understand the importance of [b]Phoenix Point[/b], try to imagine Star Wars classics, but made in today’s age, while still being the most epic movies you could imagine.

Some say classics are classics due to their nostalgia and although they serve as inspiration, they cannot be replicated. However, in this particular case, the well known British producer and designer actually managed to create an instant classic, with all the gameplay, visuals and style we could only hope for.

When the time came to create a universe and a solid story-line, Snapshot Games did what I always considered to be the best approach. Pick something real, and expand it using your own imagination, and thus here we are, with the Pandoravirus: originally discovered by scientists in Antarctica back in 2013, it serves as the main event behind [b]Phoenix Point[/b].

After the entire planet fell into obscurity by death, violence and monstrosity creatures, a special unit entitled [b]Phoenix Point[/b] was created, to fight and contain such mutations. Now, with the full universe waiting for you, the goal is simple: Find, restore and equip fallen bases.

As you expected, [b]Phoenix Point[/b] is a turn-based strategy game, where you’ll control a unit composed of a certain number of soldiers. You take turns in exploring, attacking and if needed, cover other soldiers on the field. The gameplay is impeccable, allowing players to customize their soldiers from the ground up. Train their abilities, set their skills and put them to the test on the battlefield.

Soldiers grow in skill and can become experts in specific weapon types, to further boost the inflicted damage. While in turns, you take control of each soldier, and you can even select what part of your enemy you want to shoot at. It reminds me of V.A.T.S, from the Fallout series. It works as intended, allowing for perfect head-shots or nailing that weak spot.

While traversing the universe, you’ll come across three distinct factions that live by their own set of rules. The Disciples of Anu which are a strict religious group, New Jericho are the ones who firmly believe in purity of the human body, and in the end we have Synedrion, which are those who embraced technology and aim to become one with it.

he game allows you to choose who you want to support, and while exploring the universe, several side-quests will pop-up. It’s impossible to be diplomatic with everyone, and sometimes one choice will benefit one group, above others. It’s also possible to try and scam these factions, as well as commit acts of thievery towards them.

When it comes to performance, [b]Phoenix Point[/b] is very well optimized, even for a game running on Unity. There have been several patches that considerably improved its performance and stability, which ended up reflecting on the visuals.

I really like the visuals, it has a fantastic color palette, very alien-like, with a genuine touch and inspiration from its own story related events. I’m very happy with this decision since I have a tremendous passion for monsters that somehow resemble insects and sea life organisms. It’s absolutely amazing to see how beasts evolved into such colossus!

With a solid presentation and a magnificent campaign, emphasizing exploration and player choices among factions, there is no doubt that [b]Phoenix Point[/b] is one of the most important tactical turn-based strategy games out there, and the perfect Christmas present if you’re a fan of the genre.

TLDR: Go play something else.

Oh, Phoenix Point. Such a disappointment... I'm so close to finishing the game, but my A-Team has been ambushed and I've just run out of patience with the game. It has so many good things going for it, but that just makes the flaws even worse. Let's go from the top.

GOOD THINGS:

Depth: Phoenix Point has lots of different weapons, abilities, and research paths. There are a lot of different ways to approach a situation. Maybe you can use New Jericho rockets with a GL and go maximum explosions, or you can go sneaky with a Synedrion Infiltrator, or you can use the giant mutant doggos from the Cult of Anu.

Free Aiming: Basically Phoenix Point's main selling... Well... 'Point' if you'll excuse the pun. Whenever you shoot at an enemy, you can direct your soldier's fire towards certain parts. There's nothing better than blowing the gun out of an enemy's hands, leaving them dumbfounded. More than once I've neutered an Arthron Tyrant by blowing off their MG arm, leaving them to run into my guns to try and poison me at close range.

Big Nasties: You can fight some big nasty monsters that genuinely take a lot of effort and teamwork to put down, unlike the bigger enemies in other XCOM-style games. You're best off taking out the smaller ones before focusing your attention on the big monster.

BAD THINGS:

Confused Game: Phoenix Point can't decide whether it wants to be like X-COM or XCOM. You get individual customisable soldiers with a load of cool abilities, incentivising you to protect them and level them up, like the new XCOM games. On the other hand, armour is quite frankly not worth a damn, and they die way too easily but are just as easy to replace, like the old X-COMs. Which one do you want to be Phoenix Point? You can't be both.

Jank: I mentioned free aiming and how it's basically the game's main selling point. Unfortunately, free aiming is jank AF. Multiple times I've had a literally guaranteed shot on a close-range enemy, only for my shots to literally phase through them harmlessly, before they then run up and kill my precious max-level soldier, because as I said armour isn't worth a damn. Also, it doesn't play nice with loading sometimes, occasionally CTDing, and then there's the infamous endless enemy turn bug. Then there's enemies landing constant bullseye shots with pistols from across the map, sometimes shooting through solid objects that would usually block LoS.

Ambushes: As I said, I've lost the will to finish the game because of an ambush. Basically, you're told to explore for resources. Oh look, here's an exploration area and WHOOPSIEDAYSIE ambush. Unskippable mandatory mission where you don't get any rewards and you're placed in the middle of a swarm of high-level  enemies. Maybe if there was a warning system, say you go to an area and before you click 'Explore', there's a "x% chance of ambush", which could increase with things like mist of proximity to nests etc. Unfortunately, ambushes are just random, tedious, and punish you for trying to play the game properly.

The Great Betrayal: They sold out their backers for the Epic exclusivity deal. I'd keep a wary eye on these developers in the future if I were you.

If you're looking for a cool XCOM experience, either boot up Enemy Unknown of OpenXCOM. I guarantee you you'll have a much better time. Maybe I'll come back to Phoenix Point in a year or so, assuming it ever gets workshop support so people can remove the bad stuff, such as ambushes and janky free aiming.

82058407.review:
*This is an adaption of a review that I initially posted on Metacritic in May, following Phoenix Point's original release on Epic. I've updated where relevant.

Initial missions start off quite well, and I have to say that I have enjoyed the updated tutorial missions and early game, both of which provide an enjoyable degree of tension, but before too long both your own soldiers and the enemies that you'll face become terribly overpowered - This has quite rightly been nerfed to a degree, however it still leads to a situation where the game ends up being more about trying to alpha strike the enemy with your superhuman squad before they can do the same to you. Top tier soldiers, moving at top speed, are able to cover a large percentage of the map in a single turn and whilst doing so still have the possibility to shoot multiple enemies and regain actions along the way, thus making the whole 'turn based' aspect of turn based strategy redundant. None of this is helped by the fact that the maps themselves are tiny, meaning that you and your opponent will nearly always be right on top of each other from the start of every mission and rarely experience any change of pace.

The perks themselves are pretty bland, usually some variation of doing more damage, increasing accuracy, or increasing movement/will. I think a lot of these enhancements could have been better served if they had been applied via scientific research and development of new equipment. I can enjoy seeing a new gun or projectile doing additional damage, but a unit suddenly being able to do more damage because they've randomly trained to do so doesn't make sense to me, and a unit suddenly being able to will themselves to move faster also feels quite bizarre (This, in particular, is basically magic and, for me, it doesn't fit with the setting). 

The game relies on its USP of a free-aiming system - This was an interesting idea in theory, but I found that trying to estimate what area of a targeting reticule was filled became stale fast and would have preferred at least the option to be able to switch to seeing the percentage chance to hit whatever I was aiming at instead. I think Snapshot themselves possibly recognise that this system is flawed as they've gone through a number of different visual representations of trying to show the player how much damage an expected shot might do. I wish they would just give an option to show the numbers that are being used to create that visual representation instead of finding new ways to obfuscate those numbers.
- There's also the issue that animations continue to cycle after firing your first shot, so you may think that you have 100% covered an opponent with the targeting reticule and are therefore guaranteed to hit, however that opponent may well have moved out of the way by the time your projectiles reach it. 
- Basic features such as change of stance and different firing modes for weapons aren’t present, and movement is grid-based, neither of which mesh well with a free-aim system. Instead, you have to rely on finding full or low cover (basically half cover, but at least here your unit will finally crouch) and hoping that your squad member will use that cover in an effective way. Compare this with games such as Valkyria Chronicles or Age of Fear, both of which have forms of free-aim but also allow the player to precisely control the positioning of their units.
- The free aim system also creates problems of its own when combined with a damage system which allows you to target different body areas - headshots, for example, aren't fatal (as they would be too easy to make), but you will be able to experience death by being shot in the toe when your unit decides to not use cover in the way that you hope they might.

The strategic layer is okay and serves its purpose, but it is quite basic, the same goes for base building (I think that Snapshot have missed a trick by giving you an almost fully functioning base at the start of the game as this leaves less to discover) 

The story is similar, it serves its purpose in driving the game forward and doesn't really do much wrong beyond being a bit cliched and tropey (the factions especially), but I'm not playing an X-Com type TBS game for its story in the first place. I do like that the factions will actively go to war with each other, I'd like to see the diplomacy system be developed more. 

Ambient sound is good, it adds atmosphere and I think helps to create the right mood for the game. More voice acting would be nice, but I appreciate that PP was produced on a budget. Lack of background music doesn't bother me especially, though it does feel a little strange for Snapshot to make this decision after the music score of Chaos Reborn was received so well. (Chaos Reborn, Snapshot's first title is a game that I would strongly recommend btw). 

Graphics are strange - I quite like the washed-out pallet, this also enhances the mood, but I'm finding it very difficult to make out details in any units (this is on top-end graphical settings). Without clicking on them, I'm often unable to distinguish the different load outs of opponents and have had to use colour to be able to make my own squad members stand out from each other. (I don't mean just for the same unit type either, I can't easily tell the difference between a sniper and my assaults in their starting gear) I'm also finding that the camera angle is hindering gameplay, I appreciate being able to zoom in and out of the map, and now being able to also freely rotate, but I really want to also be able to tilt and freely pan that camera so that I can check different firing angles and positions before I move units. - I think again Snapshot recognise that there is an issue with the camera as they have provided sight-lines in order to hold the player's hand and let them know which tiles allow a shot on enemies before moving units to those tiles... but those sight-lines wouldn't be necessary if the player was able to effectively gauge whether the shot was on by just looking at the map in the first place.

The atmosphere of the game as a whole could be fantastic, and the original idea of a Lovecraftian horror TBS horror game was fantastic, but I feel that it is spoilt by the overpowered skills and aids given to the player such as sight-lines and being able to 'hear' units that you can't see meaning that you've effectively got x-ray vision. It's more Marvel's idea of horror than Lovecraft's. 

And that leads to a final point which is that everyone will have different preference of how they like to play any given game, and PP at the moment is missing out on the opportunity to facilitate that by providing menu options to players that would allow each player to apply those preferences. Sight-lines on/off, free camera on/off, fatal headshots on/off, change of stance on/off etc.

Overall I don't think PP is a terrible game, whilst I am highlighting flaws in this review, I feel like there was/is the potential for a decent game. It has a number of interesting mechanics and a good concept, unfortunately, those mechanics are often fighting against each other and I feel that they ruin the original concept. On the flipside, the devs are still actively working on the game both in terms of creating content and improving systems. On Metacritic, in May I gave a score of 4/10 I'm now probably considering it as a 5 or a 6. I wish steam allowed a neutral review option. 

If you liked the modern Firaxis XCom games, if you like superhero games, or if you like short tactical battle games then you might enjoy Phoenix Point; but if you were a fan of the original XComs/UFO titles, if you want a true horror title, or if you're looking for a slower-paced turn-based strategy game then don’t expect Phoenix Point to meet your needs. If you're unsure either-way I'd suggest waiting until the final DLCs are released over the next year and see how everything looks then.

82018257.review:
This is a really fun game with a lot of nice idea's that expand upon the XCOM formula of Jake Solomon and Firaxis. I started playing this thinking: It looks like XCOM, sounds like XCOM and feels like XCOM, so I'm going to play it like XCOM.

WRONG!

This is a beast all of its own. Yes, there is tactical combat and yes there is a geoscape and yes there is research, but it differs on some key elements that make it a different experience. 
It feels to me like a mix of XCOM and Mount & Blade. The game is less structured and guided than XCOM and that makes it inherently a more difficult game, but also one that makes for even more replayability.
You can mix and match classes, there are a lot of weapons to get and the aliens get quite varied with their mods.

The tactical combat is more direct than XCOM. There are more enemies and the maps require less running around to find your foes. The aiming system is really fun and makes you look at terrain in a different way than many of the game's tactical peers. I'm enjoying the monster design and the challenges that they bring to the player.

One thing that made the game stand out to me is that there is more interaction with the world than in Firaxis' XCOM. Leaders talk to you, small settlements can give you quests with a story behind them and you can decide to attack settlements or help them in various ways. This is the part where my Mount and Blade feel came into play. I'm generally roaming around the world in my little plane visiting sites with little events and fighting off Pandoren. This is contrary to XCOM, where you had to retun to base after every mission.

One thing this game lacks compared to XCOM is the visual customization of your troops. There are only a handful of options and the faces tend to be completely obscured by helmets most of the time, so the soldiers feel less like your own, despite them being much more unique due to the various traits they have in combination with the mix- and match class system. 
Another thing is that PP is a lot less polished than XCOM. There are bugs here and there, the UI is not as intuitive and the game doesn't guide the player into itself as much. I didn't find it a deal breaker, but it does show the higher experience Firaxis has with making games compared to Snapshot.

I like the music well enough, it suits the theme of the world being to shit and you fighting a desperate battle to not have the entire population get extinct. The voice acting is pretty good as well and builds even more upon the atmosphere. The three factions that are still present in the world (outside of the Pandoren) are unique and believable.

I'd say if you're a fan of tactical combat and science fiction, give this game a go. Just expect to get your ass kicked during the first few runs, but hey, that's part of the learning experience!

It was difficult for me to decide whether I like this game or not.  I will put it this way: I recommend your second play through.  If you've got weeks to spare, you will enjoy your second or third run at this thing.

Phoenix Point is very difficult and has a lot of balance issues. No play though is going to be the same, but the mechanics will be.  I realized about four hours after the world was lost in my first game, that Phoenix Point's difficulty is mainly due to overly complicated game mechanics that are poorly explained.

In X-Com 2, you have a traveling military base and can deploy whatever combination of soldiers you need where ever they are needed, and there's often a binary choice with advantages and tradeoffs between optional missions.  Here, you have to coordinate intercontinental bases staffed with personnel, and manage your resources in a way that is arbitrary and leaves little room for experimentation.  X-Com 2 puts a lot of agency in the player's hands regarding how they want to advance through tech trees or what goals they want to prioritize.  Phoenix Point appears to do that as well, but it's largely an illusion - the enemies are constantly outpacing your organization's development, so if you waste resources building a facility with a limited scope of utilization or don't pursue a mission that would result in the relationship development you need to unlock some certain technology, you will be so far behind that whatever struggles you take on for the next several hours of gameplay will be for naught.

In Phoenix Point, it's possible to do everything right, and still lose.  In fact, it's likely.  Some people enjoy having the cards stacked against them, but for me, I had the most fun with the game when I switched to the easiest difficulty, and fully understood how the game wanted me to play it, about 12 hours in.

Well it confirmed that this game has a terrible Adaptive Difficulty algorithm. It effectively punishes player’s success by adjusting enemy level to maintain the same “feel” of the game.

And here this is implemented in one of the most moronic ways possible – enemies just get more armour and more HP making it a sluggish grind of "get grouped behind covers / engage single enemy / focus fire for several turns.. next". This is by far the greatest flaw with this game for me and I will not play further.

Story is just silly and will take some serious suspension of disbelief to get on with. 
For example:

The parts where Phoenix Point shines aren't enough to overshadow the parts where it lacks. 4/10

The whole premise behind this game had me hooked from the start. A new take on the moderately done to death alien invasion made me think "Yeah, this one will be a good one!"... Then they went Epic Exclusive for a year, so I forgot about it. Was browsing my queue and it popped up and I decided to grab it. Now, it was 50% off, but still cost me $42.47 AUD ([i] like 21 bunnings snags, very expensive [/i]), would definitely not buy it at full price. I was expecting to get maybe 80 hours of fun out of this one, but I got to about 16 before it was just too much to bear.

[h1] COMBAT [/h1]
The Good
- The combat is decent. The whole aim cone system is new and cool.
- The body part targeting and health pools was fairly well done (though I feel like if you disable somebody's head it should kill them...)
- The action points are good, both in design and utilisaion. Moving 1m only uses a portion of the action point bar, which was something I appreciated, compared to newCOM where you move a step and oops you only have 1AP left.

The Bad
- The aiming needs some sort of indicator (like for example, A PERCENTAGE), because just because I can see the tip of somebody's arm doesn't mean I should necessarily shoot at it. When the cover is blocking 95% of the enemy but the camera angle makes it look like its a good shot, I find myself always checking the free aim then being disappointed. Maybe putting a red tinge to obstacles in the aim cone or something might've helped.
- Cover feels overpowered and useless at the same time. Full cover protects you from most attacks while half cover feels like it does nothing.
- YOU CAN'T EQUIP A SHIELD AND A PISTOL AT THE SAME TIME LIKE WTF

[h1] OVERALL [/h1]
The Good
- The Pandorans (the main enemy) feel fresh and interesting, and the way they evolve is pretty cool.

The Bad
- The Geoscape map feels kinda clunky, and I don't really have an explanation as to why.
- I had multiple instances of cinematics just failing to play, or just freezing mid way through.
- I'm not a fan of the geopolitical shenanigans that are going on. I just want to be able to help humanity best as I can, but it feels like the game is forcing you to pick and choose between the factions, and I hate how the diplomacy missions are to attack the other factions. It feels like the game actively punishes you if you aren't attacking or stealing resources or aircraft from the different factions.
- The inventory management. I feel like they decided for a simple design when they shouldn't have. Xenonauts did the inventory management really well imo, it had an infinite number of standard equipment - projectile firearms, grenades ect that you could just chuck on your new recruits. Oh whats that, you hired a new guy? Too bad you don't have any weapons/armor for him to use. That'll be 500 materials and 9 days to fully equip them.
- The research felt more like a check list than progression. In Xenonauts and newCOM you started with projectile weapons, worked your way through to get laser and plasma weapons or whatever, but it doesn't seem like that's there for Phoenix Point. No, you gotta steal it from the factions or be allied with them to get access to research it. And half the time the newer stuff is barely an upgrade. Not a fan.
- There's probably more I could add here but these were the main things that came to mind.

At the end of the day, I probably over-hyped this game for myself and expected way too much. It honestly felt like I was playing an early access game. Maybe it gets better later into the game but it just ended up feeling like a chore that I didn't want to invest my time into. I'm sure there are plenty of people that are having a blast with this game, but I just couldn't get into it. Maybe I'll come back later and have a better time with it, who knows.

81875400.review:
[b]NOTE: [/b]If you don't care about controller support, like how the gameplay goes, and feel like it's a good bang for your buck, this is still a grab. This is a cautious negative, should be a neutral.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Despite carrying the "XCOM" name on its description as means of comparison, it diverges heavily from modern XCOM, and not in a good or bad way. Problem is, sometimes it could've done better by diverging more. Story is about the same, even bugs feel like imported from the newest XCOM games. [b]"Full Controller Support" is a HUGE LIE[/b].

[h1]"I don't know what 'XCOM' is"[/h1]
(if you do, skip this part)
Short answer is: XCOM is a tactical game where asset management is crucial, strategy is multilayered (long term plans are important, but instant execution is the bread and butter), and gameplay is divided in two equally important parts: real time strategy with base and resource management; and turn-based battles with units.
XCOM reputation comes from the second part. A HUGE part of XCOM difficulty lays in the heavy randomness of battles, and how damage balancing can make a single enemy shot shift the whole battle (against or in favor of the player). When you see memes about "normal person seeing 95% *happy*, XCOM player seeing 95% *nervous sweating*", that ain't a joke. Even a unit that is on full cover can be critically hit by an alien, die, set the whole team in panic, and have everyone else killed because of that. In XCOM, any mistake can be a mission ending mistake. And when training human assets is a long and arduous job, that is the kind of commitment  you make on every mission. You are never safe from the Random Number Generator on XCOM, no matter how safe you play. And playing too safe is not only boring and bad for the player, but there are also mechanics that prevent or punish that.
Now...

[h1]"I know what XCOM is, so what does Phoenix Point changes?"[/h1]
Short answer is: way less luck-reliant on the turn-based battles with units.
On XCOM finding an enemy triggers a cutscene, gives them a free-turn to prepare against you, and makes your regret ever advancing your team? Not on Phoenix Point! When moving, if a unit finds an enemy, they just stop. And on Phoenix Point, actions are divided into "Action Points" that have about nothing to do with "points", since they are not discrete. A 10 tile movement costs one action point? Then 5 tiles is 0.5 action points. And if you stop because you spotted an enemy, no action points are lost. Upon spotting, you can prepare yourself, or even retreat.
The rest of the battle-related things are just as advertised. While the success of a strategy on XCOM can heavily be dictated on luck, on Phoenix Point a properly laid out plan is a definitive win.
These two main differences aren't good or bad, these are what differentiates XCOM from Phoenix Point. If the dependence on RNG on XCOM early game has always turned you down, Phoenix Point might just become your best friend. Specially since damage is balanced in a way that even on early game, all units (yours and enemies) can soak more than a single bullet before dying.

[h1]"OK, now what is the same or hasn't changed significantly?"[/h1]
Similar to XCOM 2, your initial position is less of a "world savior" and more of the "underdog", with not only XCOM being the only faction fighting aliens. Except that in Phoenix Point they had the great writing and backstory to make the player even more of an underdog and make the factions more significant by portraying them as "as capable of being the solution against the aliens, as Phoenix Point might be", creating a more interesting world. BUT INSTEAD, you're appointed as "world savior" by the initial narration, and factions are very receptive of you. There is barely any animosity between them and you, unless you pick a fight. Huge missed opportunity here, to create an even wider difference from XCOM while ALSO making it stand better on itself. Also, the voice acting is kinda bad, and it's not the "so bad its good"-bad, it's the "bland"-bad. Some key persons have great VAs, but soldier barks are generically devoid of emotion. Actors seem fine, but VA direction seems incapable. These compounded problems (too much centralization on the player and bad VA) degraded the potential of having a more complex and more interesting story when compared to XCOM's "you're awesome Commander, now go save the world". Again, if Phoenix Point made this actually work, it wouldn't make it "better" than XCOM, it would've made it unique.
The management side is slightly different from XCOM, being a little more straining and complex, with 3 main resource types (instead of just "Cash" and "Expropriated Alien Stuff"). Instead of randomly appearing missions, you have several places to visit and maybe find resources, battles, or just information. Weaving of the DLCs was improperly made, with time-limited-unique-do-now-or-never missions (or at least that how they appear to be) that appear on early game and pit you against enemies you barely have any chance against (praised be my two snipers, only two capable of damaging those dang missile-shooting heavies). Mission variety overall is actually very good, and layouts fluctuate from more open fields with few buildings to more cramped places. Except for alien nests. Artificially and unnecessarily cramped! Yay. Gonna leave a review on Yelp.

[h1]"OK, I get it, but aren't you forgetting about something?"[/h1]
OH YEAH. BAD CONTROLLER SUPPORT!
If using a controller to play is important for you, and that [b]"Full Controller Support"[/b] made you smile, STOP... [b]STOP. RIGHT. NOW.[/b]
I'm on a Dual Shock 4, forgot I had DS4Windows running, and when I saw the "You seem to be using a mapping software *yadda yadda yadda* 'you don't need it' *yadda* *yadda* *yadda*", it made me smile!
Then, I closed the prompt, closed DS4Windows, opened the game again, and... controller unresponsive.
"Huh. Let's check options, sometimes you need to toggle controller use.". It was already toggled. Controller totally unresponsive.
"Well, sometimes you need to restart the PC. Shouldn't, but let's try". Nothing.
"Well, Steam Controller Configuration Support might be on, and it might need to be off (or the other way)". Nope.
"...back to what I know to use then." DS4Windows just works.
"Great, now let's see how well it's adapted to controller". BADLY.
XCOM has a cursor bug where when changing characters, the cursor doesn't update the position, so when selecting another character and trying to move the cursor, camera whips back to the last position at full speed. That bug is also on Phoenix Point! They didn't bother to update cursor position on character change too (or messed the script the same way)! But wait, there new stuff too! Sometimes it warps outside the playing area, and you simply CAN'T bring it back because you can't move the cursor when its outside the play area! Also, there is no "floor selection", and the cursor doesn't "climb" walls, so trying to select a direction that is on another floor is an adventure in itself, since you need to position the cursor relative to the camera in a way that is targeting the tile on the upper floor you want to go, even if one tile to the "side" (camera relative) is completely off from the that upper floor tile. Trust me, it's BAD.
Also, the rest of the UI+UX is AWFUL for controller. CAN'T use D-Pad for menus (worst part). Sometimes lacks UI helpers telling what button does what. And the cherry on top, is that the UI is heavily cursor-dependent. I cry in anger every time I see "Full Controller Support" and that actually means "you use your controller to badly mimic a mouse, because we couldn't bother doing better than that".
Oh yeah, and the cursor is huge plus is always visible on cutscenes.
Please, don't say your game has "Full Controller Support" if XInput isn't supported out-of-the-box. It makes the disappointment of dredging through bad UI+UX with a controller even worse.

81875283.review:
Is X-COM 2 WotC better? Does it stand up to that game and more in the genre? This is a question you'll probably be asking before you buy. Especially since the product is advertised as being made by someone that's been in the industry for a long time. Yes and no, it's a little complicated.

This is the Year One Edition, so you'll get some nice DLC to go with it. This also means it is priced the same as the other big turn based strategy games of this genre.

It's hard to beat X-COM's WotC, but that will definitely put a hole in your pocket compared to this game. I got it on sale for $30. For that price Pheonix Point is worth it. But how about when it is not on sale? This will depend on a few things and how you feel about them:

There are a few nice QoL things that I've gotten used to from XCOM 2, like being able to move multiple soldiers at the same time and not waiting one-by-one. (This example is actually directly linked to another feature of this game, which is when a soldier is moving and that soldier spots a new enemy, they stop to let you decide what to do, which is nice.) From time to time I feel a little slowed down.

Something I like a lot is that if an attack hits or misses is not entirely up to an RNG machine. YOU have free aim of the shot your soldier is taking. The way you shoot is similar to hip-firing in an FPS, the bullets are randomly spread in a circle. No more shooting 6 bullets with a 99% chance and missing a point-blank target. You can prioritize different body parts, which can be disabled to hinder the target in different ways. The cover you and the enemy takes is also a lot more of a factor than half/full, as is the angle your shooting from. Maybe just part of your arm is sticking out from a wall, or an enemy is flanking you from the other side of a window and just your head can be seen. Very cool system overall and I feel more in control.

There are a few other factions that you interact with throughout the campaign. The stance you take with one effects how others react. You can help and hurt relations between the factions with decisions you make. You can even attack and defend the bases these factions have. Very cool.

Graphically there is a little to desire, but it isn't off-putting. The art is familiar to, you guessed it, X-COM. When it is advertised as being made by the X-COM creator, you fight an 'alien' force like in X-COM, and it looks like X-COM, it is hard not to compare the two during play.

I have not played long enough to notice and long-term cons to the game. It is pretty good, but overall not amazing. Grab it if its on sale. Otherwise grab the standard edition and get the DLCs if you enjoy it!

So before I say anything, I wanted to thank all the beta testers at Epic for this game. I also wanted to let everyone know that I was an original backer of this game but got a refund due to the unacceptable switch to EGS and the ensuing debacle.

So for the review, it seems much more polished than some of the earlier builds. However, this is not to the level of XCOM 2, which many reviewers have compared it to. If you have gotten this far into the review and think this game looks fun to play and do not have XCOM 2, do yourself a favor and get that one instead. 

I like the free aim mechanic and how overwatch isn't an automatic win anymore. I like the different factions working with or against you and not at the player's whim like in other games. I also like the true to lore cutscenes and story. The research chains and technologies give you the incentive to work hard to be diplomatic with the other factions and balance your late game needs. Having the option to raid for tech or aircraft was a nice touch as well. There are many, many different ways you can play depending on how you balance these mechanics. This ensures no two games are the same. 

I think a number of the classes need to be rebalanced as a sniper/heavy or sniper/assault builds are much more useful than any of the other ones. I also think that the havens you need to defend should have buildable point defenses, so you don't have to keep fighting over and over and over. In my first game, I fought almost 70 haven defense battles within a 23-hour game. It felt needlessly tedious. Most of the maps are very similar, even the major story or faction missions. I'd like to see more variety there as well. I never felt compelled to care about any of my soldiers either, like XCOM.  More customization features are needed. 

Lastly, I think there has been a waste regarding some of the factions there. You fight the Pure and Forsaken, but have very little interaction otherwise. Similarly, the bandit and independent factions have such promise and have not been expanded on very much either. Why can you not choose to work with either? There could be special technologies and other consequences for relations with the main factions. If the developers read the reviews, they should use more of the very rich lore background. I'd give it a lukewarm thumbs-up, a 7/10. There is a lot that needs to be improved, but it is fun if you like XCOM, Xenonauts, or other games that are similar. 81827331.review:
A pretty fun game but it has many flaws that mainly stems from progression and balance. If I could give it a maybe I would but honestly, if you're a fan of XCOM style games, this is a good one to try. It's a turn based squad based tactical strategy game with all the bells and whistles that you'd expect from the man who originally created the X-COM series. If you don't have XCOM 2 and are thinking about getting into Turn Based Tactics games then start with XCOM 2 over this. If you're a fan, like myself, go ahead and give it a try.

PROS
-Good combat and aiming system. The "Free Aim" should be a standard in all future XCOM titles.
-4 AP points that can be spent in any order is fantastic. No longer do you need to decide if you run and shoot, shot and stay, or just run.
-Vehicles are a great addition that would be a great addition in XCOM 3.
-Exploration around the Geoscape feels much better than exploration in XCOM2. The ability to send out multiple parties and having multiple bases is a must have.
-The ability to cross class and level up your characters in a pseudo RPG style way is fantastic.

CONS
-Progression feels incredibly slow. You can speed this up by spamming out research labs and trying to steal from factions but direct and indirect aggression towards other factions seems like a poor choice for the player in general.
-Faction interaction needs to be stronger. In my 25 hours of playing I have rarely found any real benefits from directly attacking factions to gain favor from another or steal technology. The Pandoran attacks on Havens are INCREDIBLY plentiful and will boost relations with factions easily. Destruction of Pandoran Nests, Lairs, and Citadels also helps build relation with all 3 factions.
-Vehicles need to be improved. While they are a great addition, they feel somewhat like a poor choice. A vehicle will never improve over a soldier and taking one in the field means leaving three soldiers behind. They are technically the cheaper and economic choice over fielding a soldier and their equipment, but their benefits don't outweigh a full squad of operatives.
-Aircraft needs to be improved. There seems to be little reason to use other faction aircraft when the Phoenix standard is cheap and quick. You can always field multiple strikecraft as well, allowing you multiple teams to be stationed around the world for rapid response.
-Enemy progression is horrific. I am personally unsure if I am being punished for doing good but it seems every operation creates a new Pandoran mutation. The enemy techs up faster than I can, forcing me to devolve into tactics like leaning heavily on snipers and grenade launchers. Standard gear becomes almost useless as well as gear that lacks pierce.
-Character customization is just... pretty bad. It's not like XCOM where you can make your friends, family, and coworkers into perfect avatars. Customization here is bland and the VA work is not that hot either. Units feel less like characters I care about and more like pieces on a board with little to no personality.

HOW IT CAN IMPROVE
-Better diplomacy. Give me a reason to stab someone in the back or support one faction over the other. With how often Havens are attacked there is almost no reason to take a hostile action towards other factions besides roleplaying.
-Improve customization for obvious reasons.
-Have a way for the weapons race to actually keep up with the Pandorans. You always feel like you're several steps behind, forcing you to use somewhat cheesy tactics and combos just to win. Maybe that's what they're going for but it doesn't feel balanced like XCOM.
-WORKSHOP! You want your game to survive and thrive like XCOM? That's how you do it. If you can't fix the problem with a patch or new content then let us do it ourselves.

Fun game, wish I didn't have to wait the extra year to play it due to the EGS acquisition. I supported it on kickstarter and hope to see this game improve and grow with plenty of support from the team.

81796535.review:
Original backer here.

It's quite unfortunate, but Phoenix Point doesn't really get to be the torchbearer of tactical games. Not even remotely so. While it has a number of interesting ideas and a decent setting, it was created with a number of really important flaws - flaws that weren't really addressed by all the patches and DLCs even to this day.

Problem #1: strategic layer is very primitive, lacks important decisions, and overall quite unfun. Strategic layer is the backbone of XCOM-styled games: while most of the in-game time is spent resolving tactical battles, it's strategic layer that allows these battles to be truly different by providing varied constraints (wounded soldiers, logistical issues, etc) and benefits (tech options, loadouts, locations, and so on). And in Phoenix Point - most of strategic aspects are very barebone.
The tech tree isn't really a "tree", more like a patch of grass with lots of side options but barely any power levels or game-changing implements - and thus, the loadouts that you can take on missions are rather boring and uninventive and typically based on abusing certain game mechanic loopholes.
The soldiers are absolutely not unique but at the same time very limited in the highest power level they can achieve, so the game fails both nuCOM approach (soldiers are reasonably unique snowflakes) and oldCOM (soldiers are nearly equal redshirts, but you can often win with quantity if not quality). In Phoenix Point, your soldiers are nameless mooks that stay nameless and easily replaceable all the way through the game; yet battles are so small-scaled and clamped so that abusing superior numbers in any way is simply denied by game rules.
All other strategic aspects are similarly bland - while the globe view looks very busy all the time, you don't really get to make many important choices there, most of the time you just grab the shiniest thing of them all (solider/resource/ship/etc that you need the most right now), and that's it.

Problem #2: tactical combat is badly scaled and its basic mechanics are underdeveloped. nuCOM games with their dice rolls for hits were able to easily balance map scale issues by just tweaking numbers, but with Phoenix Point and it's free aim feature it became a big issue quite immediately after the release, and devs only offered small balance patches to an absolutely huge problem.
In simple terms, small maps and free aim to-hit system makes rules of engagement utterly unrealistic and extremely "gamey". Right after the release, the god-tier weapon in the entire game was your starting heavy cannon, simply due to the fact that it's the highest-damaging "normal" weapon, and you could stack aim bonuses on it to turn into a de-facto sniper rifle, much more powerful that normal sniper rifles. It was patched to a certain degree eventually, but the problems that allowed that issue to happen are all still there, and later engagements are still mostly about your soldiers standing at the edge of the map (if line of sight allows) and firing through the entire map. Cover is irrelevant. Clever positioning is irrelevant. Tactical movement is irrelevant. All that's relevant is reaching certain breakpoints on damage (to deal with enemy armor) and stacking enough accuracy to hit things from whatever range.
The core of this problem is the fact that you can't easily tweak spread values (or very simplistic damage/armor values) to make weapons ranging from sniper rifles to shotguns [b]all[/b] play nicely at the same time on very small maps and versus rather dumb enemy AI. Even with primitive tech tree and no power levels, the basic mechanics of hitting targets and dealing damage are STILL not complex enough to accomodate all the weapons there are in the game.

Problem #3: the story is... severely underwhelming in its presentation. I don't expect too much from an XCOM-style game, but what's presented in Phoenix Point breaks the suspension of disbelief all too much. You're the humanity's savior, but it does seem like nobody (except you) cares about upcoming extinction - in fact, the factions are more than happy to speed it up by warring among themselves. Worse still, while it seems like the most pressing issue for the most part of the game - [b]you cannot do anything about it.[/b] Indeed, just resolve the crisis before all these morons kill each other. It's what they pay you for, after all (except they don't).
So even if you play though the game and fight through the crabby crisis - you're still saving only a bunch of morons that are quite actively suicidal on their own. It's quite anti-spectacular and anti-climactic on all the fronts.

PS: And oh yes - while DLCs bring some additional content, they do so in a very parceled way, not really meshing it together with the main campaign, and thus present no more than a tiny band-aid to the game's deep problems.

So a super long time ago, I kickstarted Phoenix Point, which ambitiously tries to take on the genre that got away from the creator (thanks to the magnificently modernized Firaxis XCOM games). I never played Phoenix Point upon release over a year ago, as I just chose not to bother and I had read all the reports of it being buggy and unpolished... so for any TBS- tactical/strategy combo fans, here are my early thoughts after playing a weekend. 

Overall, it's better than Phantom Doctrine, but still not as 'tight' as War of the Chosen, even though it has, IMHO stronger strategy features than the 'ability-battle-puzzle' board-game-ness style of modern XCOM.

 - The ballistics modeling replacing RNG is actually a way bigger feature than I anticipated, and I like it a lot. It really changes the battle mechanics. Unlearn XCOM - cover doesn't 'reduce damage', there are no critical hits in Phoenix Point, there is no RNG(!) (though there is a standard distribution for effective range), there is manual targeting system (Fallout 3/4 VATs-like) for specific body parts and damage. Once I saw the gameplay perspective, it wasn't a gimmick, it's cool - e.g. flanking an enemy allows you to target the arm holding the enemy's shield, and you destroy it then your 'heavy' that the enemy was previously blocking against can shoot un-impeded.

- Soldiers are way more customizable from a gameplay perspective, there's multi-classing and a lot more paths for designing a character and squad synergy (it's different than the the kind of ability-permutation combinations that XCOM does). To me, this is highly preferable. However both XCOM and Phoenix Point still suffer from not giving 'personality' to your soldiers, though Chimera Squad did this best at the cost of customizability.

 - The story is like a combination of eldritch horror and terror from the deep. The tropes are simple (a jingoistic para-military faction, a religious zealot faction, crab people), so even though the plot doesn't have me going there is some intriguing lore if you like reading between button-based-decision choices. Voice acting and music do nothing to bring you into the game, and it doesn't feel as epic as XCOM but I appreciate a lot of the story-lets; they're better than the one-off events in XCOM (except for Newfoundland, that was epic).

 - The evolving enemies seems interesting; but I haven't seen the impact of this yet. It's more jumps in the enemy power curve than XCOM (e.g. when Muton Elites start appearing it's such a huge jump). It has the impact of changing your tactics over the course of the game which is cool. At the beginning, all enemy units are melee so they charge you - so you can just sit hold tight and kill from a distance and it seems overly easy, but then they start getting ranged attacks (but unpredict-ably of different types) and your own tactics change.... it's neat.

 - The strategy level is way more complex than XCOM, welcomingly so. You have to manage multiple bases, there are multiple resource types, facilities with different buffs accruing over time, and multiple squads via multiple dropships flying around the map. There's a light diplomacy layer and a surprisingly necessary-not-superfluous trade/economic layer. No. The potential for an amazing game is there, buried under some stupid design choices. Game balance issues are everywhere; from research to manufacturing to enemies ... everywhere and everything. 

The difficulty curve is ridiculous. While you're grinding away trying to level up your soldiers so they're actually useful and trying to research weapons that actually might do some damage, the Pandorans constantly leapfrog ahead. The lazy answer to increasing enemy difficulty is to add HP and/or armour and that's what the devs decided to do in PP.

You very quickly and very easily find yourself in fights that can only be won in a brutal bloodbath that can cost you a fair chunk of your squad. That might be cool if it's a last stand against overwhelming odds, but not if it's because the enemy difficulty has just spiked up again and they've gained some ridiculous amount of HP and/or armour so your weapons barely scratch them. Oh, and don't believe the hype about 'true ballistics' (or whatever they call it). You'll miss. A lot. At critical times.

If a fraction of the XCOM modding universe directed their attention to PP to iron out some of the gameplay issues, and to build on what's already there, we could have something approaching the game this could be ... maybe should have been. I get the sense, though, that modding won't be a thing for two reasons: because the devs want to offer the same experience everywhere (no mods on EGS, so ... tough luck) and because of the EGS exclusivity on first release. The moment to capture the attention and affection of modders is when the game first comes out and that opportunity was lost. You only get one chance to make a first impression.

I could drone on longer. I haven't even touched on the random squaddie skill generation that produces usable soldiers or worthless cannon fodder. The thing is, all of these issues existed through its time on EGS without being addressed. While, in fairness, I actually like the new tutorial, it makes no difference if it's the lead-in to a unbalanced game. Same with adding new DLC content.

Phoenix Point is a glass either half full or half empty, depending on your point of view. It could be good, but isn't. It could be bad, but isn't. It's a 'nearly' game. That's what makes it so frustrating. I'd give it a thumbs up and say "buy it at half-price".

81762084.review:
--- At a glance ---

Phoenix Point is very much the spiritual successor to the original (1994 – 1997) X-COM series that Julian Gollop set out to make. While it takes a few cues from the Firaxis/2K reboot in its tactical / mission mode, its overview or ‘geoscape’ mode and accompanying strategic elements have at first glance been plucked right out of the 1994 original.

In many ways the game seems to walk the fine line of avoiding to infringe upon the IP trademarks and copyrights that are now held by the current owner of Mr Gollop’s brainchild. 	That which 2K/Firaxis incorporated into the reboot was left mostly untouched, while that which was left behind was picked up and brought back to life in Phoenix Point. It’s an impressive feat: design a new game that doesn’t infringe on the creator’s lost IP by creating a new backstory, threat and tactical setup that still leaves plenty of room to give fans what they would expect from a spiritual successor to the 1994 classic – and to do so both believably and entertainingly.

A few things that were reintroduced and enhanced in Phoenix Point;
(that were sorely missed in the X-COM reboot):

- free aiming (1): shoot at anything at any time to create a path
- free aiming (2): aim for specific body parts to maximise damage and avoid armour.
- multiple bases: multiple actual bases – with staff and facilities, not just aircraft hangars.
- ranged stun weapons

Apart from that, the game features additional tactical layers (and accompanying difficulties / points of frustration) – such as destructible weapons and ‘active’ factions.

Destructible weapons are a double edged sword... Players can target specific enemy body parts in the hopes of incapacitating them, effectively leaving an enemy defenceless. The same also holds true in reverse – get shot or touched (or sometimes it seems even looked at the wrong way) by an enemy and find your weapon destroyed. 

While the War of the Chosen DLC in 2016’s XCOM 2 features a number of factions, they are anything but active and seem to purely exist passively at the behest of the player. In Phoenix Point however factions are akin to 1997’s X-COM Apocalypse. They will either assist or actively seek conflict with the player as well as other factions – depending on both the players actions as well as the procedural elements in the game. 

Graphically I would put the game between Xenonauts and the 2012 reboot of X-COM. It is certainly a lot more polished than Xenonauts (including the upcoming Xenonauts 2 sequel) – but lacks the X-COM reboots deluxe camera effects, zoom levels, special effects and cutscenes - despite having superior textures and artwork. 2016’s X-COM 2 however graphically trumps Phoenix Point in every possible way despite being 3 years older. The difference in development budget can clearly be seen on this front.

All in all – Phoenix Point is a great game and a worthy spiritual successor to the X-COM family of games. Potential players must realise though that Phoenix Point is not affiliated with the X-COM franchise in any way whatsoever. It is not a sequel, it shares none of the lore and backstory and thus should not be confused with X-COM in any way. It is a standalone game in the spirit of the original X-COM series as it was from 1994 to 1997 – made by its original creator in such a way as to provide a compelling experience without infringing on the intellectual property of the continued X-COM franchise as per its 2012 reboot.

I recommend getting the game and playing it – as I also recommend getting and playing 2012’s  X-COM and 2016’s X-COM 2 as well. There is great fun to be had on both playing fields.

On a personal note however I will add that I am sorely disappointed in Mr. Gollop for having dropped Linux support – which was originally promised. This was later revised to ‘not at launch time’ due to the strain it put on Snapshot’s small development team – but would be revisited later. Here we are a year later and no Linux support in sight. Now that Mr. Gollop’s company has been purchased by Embracer Group through it’s Saber Interactive division, it is unlikely to ever happen. Snapshot should have pushed harder for Linux support.
	It was difficult for me to accept the choice of Unity and C# for Phoenix Point’s development, but I could look past it. I mourned the choice to have Phoenix Point be an Epic Game Store exclusive for a year – but I understood the financial aid it would bring to a small developer. But dropping Linux support altogether – that I find an unacceptable blemish on all of this. As a long term fan of Mr. Gollop’s work I still decided to purchase and play Phoenix Point – but not without some bitterness tainting my palate in what should otherwise be a thoroughly enjoyable dish.


[b]The Good:[/b]

✔ enhanced tactical depth (in-mission)
✔ enhanced tactical depth (global overview)
✔ interesting lore

[b]The Bad:[/b]

✗ lacklustre graphics – comic book style cutscenes
✗ simplistic, repetitive and sometimes flat-out bad voice acting (mission mode)

--- In-Depth Review ---

Note: In-depth review will have to be a little more limited than initially planned due to the length of the ‘at a glance’ section.

• Gameplay

[b]Mechanics:[/b]

Mechanically the campaign / global elements of Phoenix Point function like a hybridisation of the original 1994 X-COM game and modern iterations of the Civilization franchise. Game-changing choices are put before the player in the form of questionnaires, while base management and map navigation are near-identical to the original X-COM.

In-mission mechanics draw heavily upon the X-COM franchise reboot – save the addition of melee combat for any and all characters (i.e. striking with the stock of a rifle) as well as the reinvigorated ‘free aiming system’ which allows players to shoot anything at any time. Aside from creating a path and tactically selecting which body part to focus on when shooting, it satisfyingly ‘proves’ to the player that there is no line of sight – thus no way to make the shot.

Combat depth has further been increased by the very real risk of shooting team mates by accident. Overview is now a specific conical field of vision as opposed to 360 degree ‘awareness’ - with anything and everything being shot in the view cone. Team mates are sure to be hit by stray bullets if they’re standing between a unit and an enemy in the view cone. 

Lastly – ranged stun weapons are back – which is great.

• Narrative

The technological development of humanity has come at a cost far greater than we ever could have imagined. Our development and industry changed the face of the earth – as we unwittingly opened the proverbial ‘Pandora’s Box’.
	We worried about rising temperatures and sea levels as the polar and arctic ice was melting away – never realising what we were releasing onto the world, buried deep within the ice. A virus like no other; insidious and pervasive – merging with everything in its path, depositing its hateful nature into whatever it can grasp - before releasing it into the wild. Waiting, watching, learning. Adapting, honing and experimenting. It will not come all at once, it has patience. It wants to be thorough – humanity must end.

• Atmosphere

Creepy, organic – almost dirty and infectious if it wasn’t offset by clean industrial design. What remains of humanity is marred by self-righteous platitudes – the results ultimately no different from that which the enemy is trying to force upon us. As time moves on - it is becoming more difficult to say which is the more infectious, or insidious. 

• Graphics / Visuals

Well put together – but lacklustre. The developer did what they could with the budget they had. Cutscenes are similar to those found in X-COM Chimera Squad, while gameplay looks polished – but somewhat shallow in its presentation (not its gameplay). Zoom levels are limited as are camera effects – but design and artwork are glorious.

Ah, [b]Phoenix Point[/b]... we finally met. I mean, seriously. This game? It did everything, [i]everything[/i] to prevent me from playing it.
