It's just [i]ugh![/i] I mean, seriously. This game is a bloody rip-off. No matter how you look at it. All the hard work [b]Firaxis[/b] did to make [b]X-COM[/b] to be fun for current generation of players? [b]Julian Gollop[/b] just took it and said “I was first!”. Also, if you plan to play this game on your big-ass [b]TV[/b]? Well... surprise-surprise! [i]F*ck you![/i] Because, even though technically, this game does support the gamepad, the controls are so bad that you'll want to scream. I'm not kidding, it's so bad that the game is close to be unplayable with gamepad. How did they f*cked up [b]Firaxis[/b]' formula? I dunno. The guys sure have a talent. A talent to f*ck things up that is. So, as long as you don't have one of those tiny keyboards to keep on your knees while playing, monitor and mouse are the only way for you.

That's a lot of hate, huh? But you know what? Actually, this isn't another one of those “angry” reviews. Because after you'll actually get through all the pain I've mentioned above? You'll begin to see that... [b]Phoenix Point[/b] is actually OK. And even though the story here is just [b]X-COM[/b] all over again (it's really depressing that all of such games follow the same exact story template, [i]all of them![/i]) with no changes whatsoever (well, aside, maybe, from a slight [b]Lovecraftian[/b] aftertaste), the gameplay is almost as addicting as it was in [b]Firaxis Games[/b]' [b]XCOM[/b]. Sure, [b]Phoenix Point[/b] is way less spectacular, but... it has its moments. Most of which were taken from the other [b]X-COM[/b]-inspired games (like [b]UFO: Extraterrestrials[/b] and [b]ALTAR[/b]'s [b]UFO[/b] trilogy), but, well, what's good is good.

Long story short, [b]Yog-Sothoth[/b] or whatever was his name, infected [b]Earth[/b] with coronavirus (I'm not kidding, that's actually the story here) and now three factions should find the way to deal with it. For you it means that you'll be protecting your bases from the infected, destroying the enemy lairs, fighting evil mist (hello, [b]ALTAR[/b]!), making allies and exploring the world. Sector by sector. Which may feel a bit like mobile game, but... it's fun. I dunno, it just is. Especially since you never know what you'll find in the next place. A bunch of loot, allied base, where you can trade or hire troops, an optional quest or ambush. It's just that – a pretty basic fun. Like I said, your usual [b]X-COM[/b] stuff is all here too (you'll build bases, train troops, capture and research the aliens in the name of science, produce some gear, etc, etc, etc), but this time you'll also be able to produce vehicles and do politics. And even though diplomacy here is really, [i]really[/i] basic (like pretty much everything else), the fact that every action here has consequences and helping one faction instantly infuriates the others? It totally makes things funnier. Especially since you can so-o-o be an a-hole in this game. Receive a gift from your ally and then rob their base and steal their aircraft right away. Because [b]GTA[/b], MOFOs! Seriously, that's some serious gangster paradise we have here. Thug life is strong with this game. Also, I so-o-o enjoyed damage mechanics in this game. I mean, unlike [b]XCOM 2[/b] (which used dice-like mechanics)? Your troops will actually hit stuff! Believe it or not. The biggest problem with gameplay here is that story missions don't feel spectacular, while the regular ones just... well, let's just say there isn't enough variety and the game gets repetitive pretty fast. But all in all, gameplay here is solid and you'll feel fine for at least one playthrough.

In conclusion, I sure ended up with some mixed feelings here. On the one hand, it's kinda sad that the man who designed and coded both [b]Laser Squad[/b] and [b]X-COM[/b] ended up stealing from people who actually worked hard to give [b]X-COM[/b] the new life. Even more so since [b]Phoenix Point[/b] fails to be nearly as good as [b]Firaxis Games[/b]' [b]XCOM[/b]. But on the other hand, when you accept this game for what it is – there's actually quite a lot of fun in it. And since the new [b]XCOM[/b] doesn't come out every day... let's just say that, as long as you like the series, you should give this one a chance. Just make sure not to expect much. Otherwise, you may end up being seriously disappointed. [b]Cthulhu[/b] fhtagn.

I enjoy tactical RPG games. So it's important to me to have a decent story as well as the battle side be acceptable. The world has been ended by a virus that turns people into Lovecraftian fishmen. We're on the third resurgence of it now but a group of people named Phoenix Point are here to try and keep humanity going. There's three other factions that are taking part in this with you. One is the fascist megacorp New Jericho, the syndicalist Synedrion and the religious Disciples of Anu.
New Jericho want to wipe out the virus and the fishmen, Anu want to live alongside the fishmen and Synedrion are sort of in the middle.

The entire game is based around the factions and this is where my first issue with it comes in. There's very little vertical progression of tech. The three factions have specific weapon types that are good against specific things and you can make their weapons...and that's kinda where it ends.
You can ally with them and get some more horizontal weapon changes that again work on specific types of enemies but actually upgrading isn't a thing.

Gameplay loop wise it also feels strange. I'm kinda going around putting out fires but barely making any progress on the story itself. 81716265.review:
Phoenix Point is a fine example of how you find the 'golden mean' between two opposite approaches to the same genre. It obviously borrows heavily from the Gollop Brothers' original hit X-Com games, particularly 'Terror from The Deep' and 'Apocalypse', but has also learned several important lessons from the success of the 'XCOM' series reboot. Effectively, it places itself between those two poles, and in doing so, offers something that might appeal to fans of either set of games, and which will DEFINITELY excite anyone who enjoyed both.

From the original X-Com games, it not only borrows the themes - Lovecraftian horrors attacking mankind from the unknowable depths of the sea from 'Terror from The Deep' and bio-technological foes/mind-control parasites hatching from creepy, Geiger-esque eggs from 'Apocalypse' - but also the depth and complexity. You have many different resources to juggle, different factions to try and keep happy (another element borrowed from Apocalypse), a granular stat-growth system, and the ability to target individual enemy parts to achieve various effects.

From modern XCOM, it takes the more smooth and user-friendly battle-system, a moderation of the 'spreadsheet' approach to stats and information that somewhat marred the classic games, and a lot less time spent watching your elite soldiers run around like headless chickens in a state of abject panic. It still HAPPENS, but not the way it used to in the old games. It also borrows the 'Earth has already mostly fallen to the threat' setting of XCOM2, just for good measure. The real star of the show, though, is something entirely new - the way it handles accuracy. 

Anyone familiar with this style of game knows of the sheer absurdity that a simple, percentage-based accuracy-system can cause. Missing an enemy at point-blank range, to the point that your gun is physically inside the enemy model, simply because there's always a 5% chance to miss. Characters unleashing a hail of bullets in some random direction just because the dice-roll determined that they weren't allowed to hit. Some games, like Phantom Doctrine, dismissed the randomness entirely and made it so that every shot was a hit - with stuff like cover merely reducing the impact of the attacks. A completely deterministic system... which of course generates just as many ridiculous situations.

Phoenix Point, meanwhile, introduces a system that's both realistic and fun to use: When you target an enemy, you get a scope with two circles - 50% of your shots will land within the smaller one, while 100% land within the larger. Hence, if you're close enough that the target will occupy the entire scope, every shot will hit - meanwhile, longer shots with intervening objects are less likely to land a lot of hits. If other units are in the way or standing behind the target, they may get hit too. Cover has no magical percentage-reduction ability, it simply reduces the amount of enemy flesh you can fit within your scope. Targeting a particular limb thus becomes a natural thing as well as a trade-off - if your target is at the edge of the creature, more of the shots will likely go wild than if you aimed for a center-of-mass shot. It also helps that most of the attacks you use are 'burst fire', where it isn't so much a matter of hit/no hit, but rather how MANY of your bullets hit.

It's honestly the best solution I've ever seen to the issue of accuracy-calculations in tactical games like this, and I hope a lot of other developers are taking notes and plotting to blatantly rip it off!

There's not much else to say, really. It's basically an X-Com game with the serial-number filed off. You build bases (albeit with the new twist that you're 'reactivating' dormant bases and repairing decaying facilities, rather than having to build new ones from scratch), recruit soldiers, gather resources, research new equipment and fallen foes, field automated vehicles alongside your fleshy troops for added support, and occasionally wind up wandering into a no-win situation that sees your whole squad wiped out. At that point, depending on your attitude, it's either time to reload an earlier save and try again from a different angle, or time to suck it up and try to salvage the strategic situation despite the tactical loss.

Though, if you're the 'hardcore ironman' type, do be warned: The game doesn't have any outright 'Ironman' switch implemented at this time, so you'd be running purely on your own discipline - indeed, it actively encourages you to save before attempting risky moves. Conversely, it doesn't AUTOSAVE during tactical combat, so there aren't going to be any automatically-generated fallback-points there tempting you. Also, the game is genuinely hard - soldiers are hard to come by and expensive in terms of resources, and take time to train up to the point where they're genuinely effective. Losing a full team can very easily be a situation you can't recover from, if you haven't been specifically working to maintain a stable of reservists, which is an expensive proposition to say the least.


So, with all that said - are you ready to join the fight against the horrific Pandoravirus-induced aquatic mutations that are surging out of the mist-covered seas to devour mankind? Then grab a rifle and sign up today! The Phoenix Project needs YOU!

It's no longer an arbitrary percentage based on stats that leads to a point blank miss because of a bad dice roll. Now there are two circles with every shot guaranteed to at least land in the outer circle and a 50% shot for each bullet to land in the inner circle. The size of the circles depends on the weapon. This makes distance and shot angles far more important. Shots are also no longer entirely fail or miss. If a weapon shots 5 shots then you might hit 3 and miss 2. Melee attacks are now also guaranteed to hit.

When I first played this game back when it came out on EGS and didn't like it, my primary thoughts revolve around one thing:

This game should never have taken user experience design from the Firaxis XCOM series.

Units taking cover and shifting around is a cool spice to the portrayal of XCOM's turn-based combat. It gets incredibly aggravating in Phoenix Point when you realize the half cover animations make certain pieces of half cover completely useless when you try to shoot and your soldier just unloads their burst into the metal pole sticking out of cover.

Hit reactions in slow motion are neat, watching the blood splatter fly in XCOM.

Hit reactions in Phoenix Point mean your Heavy misses a shot because the alien recoiled from earlier impacts in just the right way to dodge a shot.

And the whole free aiming system would work great if you have a shooter-esque control scheme that let you personally customize how your soldiers aimed to avoid the issues that crop up with it. 81676966.review:
[b]tl;dr:[/b] If you're interested in the game, go in with your eyes open that this is not X-COM 3 or you're going to be disappointed.  I'd recommend the game in its current state, and I feel like the general trend of the game improving is a good sign for what's to come. 

[b]Full Review:[/b]

I'm a huge X-COM fan, over 1,000 hours played on X2 alone.  I was an early backer for PP, played through the early pre-release builds, and lived through the disappointment of the exclusivity deal.  So the low playtime on Steam doesn't account for any of the actual time I've played on that other platform.

I was not able to complete a play-through in the early days of PP.  The game had too many issues - both bugs & balance issues.

With the LotA DLC, that all changed.  I've been through 2 full games since then, and the overall experience is in a better place.  I haven't gone through the latest version of the game yet, I'm holding off because Cyberpunk 2077 is right around the corner.  The addition of the new weapons does sound like another step in the right direction.

On to the elephant in the room - comparison to the X-COM series.

PP is a very different game from X-COM, and if what you're looking for is X3 you're going to be very disappointed.  Not because PP is a bad game, but because it's a very different experience.

[b]Pacing:[/b] the games are paced [i]very[/i] differently, and this is one of those things you might not think matters much but it has a huge impact on how the game feels.  

X2 is fairly linear.  You have guerilla ops popping at regular intervals, you occasionally get a council mission or a supply raid, and then you have the ability to raid facilities and do the story missions as you progress.  In between you just fly around and scan stuff to fill the time.

PP's pacing starts off slow, but it ramps up as the game progresses until endgame where you have things to do popping up constantly across the globe (and you'll need multiple teams to put out the fires, because PP has your soldiers in physically different locations and it actually takes time to get to missions).  It does get to a point where it gets kind of on the frantic side.  There's a lot to keep up with, and the increase in the number of events is likely on purpose - as you get closer to the end of the game it does start to feel like a battle against an unstoppable enemy.

[b]Economy:[/b]

In X2 you're got cash, elerium, alloys, intel, and cores.  The method by which you collect each of these is pretty similar, with a few exceptions here and there.  Overall you'll hit resource contention occasionally, but often you'll get a way to resolve that fairly quickly and then you're fine.  Really, the only penalty for running out of a type of resource is you don't get to get that next shiny new toy you want, or you can't contact a new map area yet.

In PP, you have 3 main resources (tech, materials, and food) along with a slew of secondary resources you unlock as the game progresses (3 faction reputations, mutagen, 3 legacy of the ancients resources, and bases and aircraft).  This puts you in a position where resource contention is a constant issue because you don't unlock the ability to have a reliable source of income until mid-game.  Do you buy that new weapon you just unlocked, or do you bring a new base online?  Which aircraft do you want to steal from which faction (because you're going to take a rep hit)?  Do you risk running low on tech/materials and not being able to reload your ammunition after a mission?  Oh, and you don't magically get enough gear for every newbie you recruit - you've got to produce or scavenge it all.

So while I've found myself making some decisions on resource allocations in X2, I've found it to be way more prevalent and impactful in PP.

[b]Game Progression:[/b] This leads me to the way you progress through each game.  

X2 is a more linear game, where things like base building order is pretty set from the start and I don't tend to deviate much from that order.  Rush mag weapons, unlock squad size upgrades, manage the doomsday clock, profit.

PP does allow for a bit more freedom in how you approach it.  The gear upgrades you get aren't as big a jump, but I'd argue opening the classes from the factions are a much bigger deal.  Granted, you'll probably get everything eventually anyway (just like with X2), but there is a bit more randomness to how the early/mid game will play out.

Both games have a clock you're running against, and this is one place I find X2 to work better because there's a constant back and forth.  In PP, I haven't found a way to reverse the progress of humanity being wiped out - so if you make a mistake and put yourself behind early you're going to be in for some trouble.  You can slow the progress, but it's a one-way ticket to humanity's extinction with no way back but to finish out the game.  While this does give a sense of urgency to the late game, it removes that tension you get from the back and forth presented in X2.

[b]Gear/Soldier Progression:[/b] this is a pretty big point of contention, but it's because these are very different games.

In X2, gear jumps are big advancements that feel extremely impactful.  When you open up mag weapons, it's a big milestone.  Same with Warden armor.  And your soldier abilities at certain breakpoints.  You see these jumps in game, and it has a very real impact.

In PP, until you bring ancient weapons online the gear jumps are much smaller.  I think part of the problem here is that the player doesn't get as much feedback on what these stats do when you're on a mission.  If you increase a soldier's stealth stat, you don't have any way of seeing what that really means.  Aim is much more esoteric than in X2 with the free aim system, so a +10% accuracy bump isn't as noticeable as it is with the "all or nothing" way X2 handles hits.

Actual soldier progression in PP is more flexible than in X2.  With X2, you have a solder's class you get to assign when they level up from Rookie rank and that determines what skills you get, with a few random skills assigned when the game rolls that soldier.  With PP the first class is assigned when the solder is rolled (so no picking the first class), and each character gets random abilities assigned as well, but you also get to add on a second class midway through a solder's career.  This opens up a ton of options for customization, and I'd also consider the random skills to be much more relevant as there are some that open up entirely new classes of weapons that can allow for far more flexibility in the way you set up the soldier.  Add on to this that you also have the ability to increase 3 stats on each soldier from the same pool of points you buy skills with and there's a lot more going on as far as player choices go.

[b]Closing thoughts:[/b] with this review getting to novella length, let's wrap up.  

Would I recommend the game?  It depends.  Just because you like the X-COM series doesn't automatically mean you'll like PP, and if you don't like the X-COM series it doesn't mean you won't like PP.  They're very similar games on the surface, but with numerous small differences that stack up to make for very different experiences.  PP has come a [i]long[/i] way since the pre-launch builds, and most of those changes have been for the better.  I feel like the game is in a good place right now, I find it enjoyable enough to hold my attention and to provide what I want for a full play-through.  I'm also very encouraged that the devs are continuing to tweak and improve on a lot of things, even though I miss some of the older overpowered combos that have been removed (RIP Rage Burst Snipers).  If you're interested in the game, go in with your eyes open that this is not X-COM 3.  I'd recommend the game in its current state, and I feel like the general trend of the game improving is a good sign for what's to come.

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/]Follow our curator page: [b]IndieGems[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

[i]Phoenix Point: Year One Edition[/i] is a tactical turn-based strategy game made by the creators of [i]XCOM,[/i] which is one of my all-time favourite games. So you can get a good idea of what the game will play and feel like just from that alone. It's not [i]XCOM 3[/i] but it's an excellent tactical TBS game. After spending a year an an Epic exclusive, it's now on Steam with all of the additional DLCs, updates, and more contents in one package. I bought the base game on Epic a year ago and am happy to have the whole game in one package here on Steam now.

[h1]Story[/h1]
A new virus on Earth started to turn mankind into some of a hybrid alien form, threatening those people last remaining. The Phoenix Project is a secret organization looking to find a solution. Take on the role of their leader in this push to save mankind.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game's tutorial will cover everything you will need to know within the combat sections, this is well done. On the other hand, not everything is explained for things to do in the overworld and that can be improved. If you start the game for the first time, the additional things to do can feel overwhelming until you get used to it.

Most of the time that you spend will be on the battlefield, as that is the main part of the game. The battles are all turn-based. You will control a team and spend your action points per turn. You can take cover in most similar games, finding loot along the way during the missions. You can shoot at enemies when you spot them.

The great thing about this game is that when firing at an enemy, you can choose between a normal shot and an aimed shot. If you select to do an aimed shot, you will zoom in on the enemy unit and you can choose which part of to try to hit. As usual, you will be able to see a displayed/calculated success rate as well as how much damage that particular action would do.

After the battles, you will go to your base, where you can level up, heal, build new things, among other options. And you can go to the overworld map to explore various sites. These will usually contain missions or belong to different factions. These other actions have different goals and values, so you will deal with them through diplomacy, deception, or brute force.

There are four difficulties to choose from, so you can definitely find one that's most suitable for your own comfort/challenge zones.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
These graphics are fantastic, zoomed out or in, everything look really awesome.

[h1]Music & Sounds[/h1]
There's a bit of eeriness feel to the music that fits the game rather well. The sound effects are what you would expect from these games and work fine.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The game can be played with a Mouse and Keyboard or you can use a controller. I prefer the M+KB combination.

[h1]Gameplay Video[/h1]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AgLy9pCDWCs

[h1]Pricing[/h1]
The €50/$60 base price is what you can expect from this game and is justified. The main campaign will likely take an average player about 30+ hours, and you can expect 60-70+ hours if you want to do all of the side content. The current launch sale on Steam is at 50% off for almost 3 weeks, so I think it's a great deal to grab it during this current sale price. And it includes everything released for this game so far in one neat package.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
It has become cliche to speak like this, but if you like [i]XCOM[/i] then I am sure you will enjoy [i]Phoenix Point: Year One Edition[/i] as well. I do enjoy the overworld and all of the events more from [i]XCOM[/i] and this game has a heavier focus on the battles. The battles are absolutely solid in terms of what you would want from a tactical turn-based strategy game.

One thing to note is that when I first installed the game on a regular HDD, it was taking a really long time to load. I did not encounter these loading issues on my SSD. So I would definitely suggest using your SSD if that's an option for you.

It's a great game, and absolutely recommended from me!

I was an initial backer who got burned by Julian Gollop reneging on his promise the game would be released on Epic and Steam at the same time. That said, I'm not going to fault the game itself for this. 

The tactical experience in this game is similar if not better than the XCOM series in that there aren't triggers that set waiting aliens in motion as there are in XCOM. Also, at four hours in, I find the types of missions more varied than they are in the XCOM series, without the artificial time constraints. 

The strategic experience offers more variety also than the XCOM series. You have deeper political considerations with warring human factions. This looks like it will offer better replay value than XCOM. Also, the voice acting for the faction leaders is fairly decent, imo.

What XCOM does better is the personal touch for your characters. I grew attached to characters that I designed and named after friends. IN Phoenix Point, they seem kind of one-size fits all regardless of customization. That said, PP, like XCOM, has classes of fighters that you can tweak as you level up.

Another thing I like better in XCOM is the feel of immediacy in combat (through amped music, closeups of aliens, louder sound effects). Combat is still fun in PP, just not quite as tense. Also, the base building is just butt-ugly imo in PP. A small thing, but I did like XCOM's side view with an animated base.

Worth a buy? I'd say yes, especially as at its release on Steam it's on sale. If you like XCOM, you'll likely enjoy PP, angry backers gripes notwithstanding. PP's combat system is better than most of the XCOM clones out there.

81659447.review:
For a new tactical turn-based strategy players this is a nice game.
For a Firaxis' XCOM veteran players this game is breath of a fresh air.
For a X-COM: Apocalypse veterans (such as me) this game is disappointment.

[u]The issues, from my point of view[/u]:
- [b]Battlescape[/b] is only part of Phoenix Point that is superior to classic X-COM: Apocalypse, that gives game enough depth and prevents it from ending up as Firaxis' mediocrity. However, lack of real-time mode alternative (that was present in X-COM: Apocalypse) gives a tingle of disappointment.
- [b]Base Building & Management[/b] in the Phoenix Point is complete downgrade compared to depth that was present in X-COM: Apocalypse. I can't get rid of a feeling that Phoenix Point base management was added just so they could add a mark that it was added.
- [b]Geoscape[/b] of the Phoenix Point... Is pretty much Google Earth modified to navigate your troop transport between POI (Points of Interest) and nothing else. Extreme let down after classic X-COM games (Apocalypse, Terror from the Deep and UFO Defense). Every time I look it, I feel betrayed (beside bait & switch to Epic).

[u]Conclusion, after crushed expectations[/u]:
If this game was developed by Firaxis, it would've been acceptable, since they can't jump above their heads. But, for a game, whose development was leaded by Julian Gollop, it has barely passing grade. Especially, after taking one more year of sweet time to develop and polish it even further. Julian, you could've done it so much better.

[u]Disappointment, bleak light after the end[/u]:
You see Julian, when I've seen you leading development of Phoenix Point, I've expected it to turn X-Com: Apocalypse^3, just as Stellaris by Paradox became pretty much Master of Orion II: Battle at Antares^3, i.e. true evolution of original genre and style.

[u]Verdict, for good of all of us[/u]:
If you're one of two categories of players mentioned in the beginning, you'll enjoy playing it and there is no reason not to buy it ([b]but, only at 50% of the price[/b]). If you belong to third category as me, it will only scratch your itch, then it flare your anger that will cooldown overtime into solid disappointment. Maybe, in 5 (or so) years it will become what we've expected it to become. Right now, for all the veterans of classic X-COM I'd suggest to put off playing Phoenix Point at least until they will release Festering Skies DLC that should make Geoscape somewhat worthy of being called as such. Meanwhile you can enjoy such classics as X-Piratez or try your hand in one of the OpenApoc's test releases, which you probably did already long ago.

In my opinion the game is very good: HUGE tech tree, better combat mechanics, much better geoscape than those games usually have. A world that you are just part of and is not centered around you. Atmospheric, lots of small details. Lovecraftian theme and horrific aliens. Lore and writing is really good. Factions and diplomacy are a little raw but also way above what others offer. Huge replay value. Also its just different in a world full of X-com clones.

Do not listen to haters, most people who write bad reviews still can't get over how bad the game was on Epic release. You can tell b/c most of those reviews are factually wrong. See a lot of mechanics has changed since year ago but they still critisize it for these old mechanics no longer in the game(like that one guy who claimed you can destroy concrete walls with pistol fire). Some just see one aspect they think is bad and bash it (some say classes variety are bad, others "base building" is poor) - usually wrong too. For example there are 7 classes in the game and you can mix them in any combination, thats a lot. By mid to end game you will have so many bases, that if each of them had Xcom-like building routine you'd drown in micromanagement. Truth is the game is very different from Xcom. But unfortunately has some similarities that people will use to compare. I think its the biggerst problem here.

Regarding the bugs, as someone who played through entire thing since backer builds till 1.9 there is this thing: devs do try to improve the game. Everytime they do it there are some bugs added, some old bugs resurface etc. This is not bc they didnt fix those bugs. They did. Look at the patchnotes if you dont believe me. But when you upgrade the game all the time, you inevitably have new issues and some of them mimic old issues. They completely changed Alien Evolution system, reworked level generation, changed many mission layouts and objectives, added new missions and enemies, new UI, new weapons, new AI, also integrated a lot of DLC content into the game - all this came with new problems. And almost all of them are fixed for Steam release. Just keep that in mind when reading "devs did not fix any of the old bugs" or "the game is still buggy after another year of testing" . Yes there can be some unfortunate bugs that are still in, but its not fair to blame devs for lack of trying.

The game has improved dramatically since last year. Even more so improved during later few months. And I know for a fact it will get even better. Trust me or not, I was one of the harshest critics when it launched on EGS. Everytime I tried another patch I would bash it in Discord server and complain how bad it was. But with little steps Devs did manage to fix most of its problems. And I'm shocked myself to say that, but I can now recommend the game. Even more so I can no longer play Xcom2 which were my top2 favorite game (check my game hours if you dont trust me - Xcom1+2 i have almost 2.5K hrs) because it plays weak after I got a proper taste of Phoenix Point.

I wouldn't pretend the game has no problems. It has some balance holes. Even after nerfs to them you still can create super-soldiers that are terribly OP. You can still get unfortunate squad wipes to some unlucky situations out of you control (rare, but annoying, thought truth is game is built to allow you to handle losses and even squad wipes. Its more like Long War in that regard). There are some exploits you can use to trivialize the game and final mission is still unsatisfying. However most of those issues can be managed and I know it will all be fixed in the later updates.

If you dont want to get it now, get it later when all DLC are out and its polished even further (With January DLC Festering Skies aerial combat will be joined by diplomacy overhaul). Do not trust bad reviews, they do not do game justice and come mostly from either those still traumatized by Epic Deal or those who are too used to Xcom gameplay and are too quick to judge based on that. If one of such people are reading this: I urge you to give PP another shot. Its a gem if you know how to work it.

I really wanted to like this game, hell I didn't even really mind that it was locked on Epic Games for a year, but after all this wait, I gotta say I am thoroughly disappointed. I only got six hours in before biting the bullet and requesting a refund.

The Pros
----------
~ Removing RNG in favour of Bullet Spread is a fantastic idea
~ The Vats Like "Pick Your Shot" system is very cool!
~ You can shoot your own men if they are in your line of fire, making for importance of spacing
~ Crippling Specific Body Parts and Bleedout is fun to play with
~ The factions all seem pretty cool from where I was at.
~ The maps look cool
~ You can shoot then move
~ It's different enough from XCOM to be its own thing while also retaining core ideas you understand


The Cons
----------
~ The game is honestly just insanely easy. The fights are always super manageable and rarely did I ever have any of those "oh shit" moments XCOM gave me.
~ Their introduction of new content is poorly designed and leads to unfair moments. In XCOM when a new enemy is introduced you are at least told it is new or it has a distinct enough style for the viewer to understand "I am about to fight something with different abilities" in Phoenix Point it just catches you off guard. Surprise! These enemies fire back when you shoot them! Surprise! These guys can shoot 4 times in a row despite looking similar to another enemy that can only fire twice. 
~ Research is very vague. While it does sometimes tell you the benefits you get, I ended up missing out on super integral research because I wasn't told its value until a bit too late
~ The sight lines of where you can shoot and where you can't feel very wonky. I can't shoot down at someone directly below me, but if I move one tile to the left I can! Even with the site indicators I sometimes move a soldier to set them up in good sightlines only to discover it wasn't a good area
~ The vehicles just sometimes break. This is what caused me to quit. I did another pastey mission but was gonna get a vehicle out of it. Eventually for no reason the damn thing locked up and I had to restart
~ The maps are way too big for the number of enemies. It's like double the size of XCOM maps with a 1/4 of the enemy
~ The abilities the soldiers get feel very weak or impractical. They get a lot of options but very few feel that strong or are worth using when you could just...shoot the enemy.
~ The customization for soldiers is bad. Like even worse than Enemy Unknown and that's saying something.

Honestly after all this I only have one thing to say. You absolutely should buy XCOM Chimera Squad. While not a full XCOM game it toys around with some new mechanics while retaining the XCOM goodness. It's short cheap and better than this. I'm probably gonna go back to Enemy Within or another round of Chimera Squad, because while I wanted something to fill that itch. Phoenix Point definitely is not the answer. After a long wait and a year trapped in Epic Exclusivity I sadly cannot recommend this game and I really hope that Steam will accept my refund.

EDIT: Refund got declined. Guess I might as well play through the rest cause I own it now.

81635194.review:
Hours on review are not quite accurate, played alot of this on the EGS as I was a backer and was fine with their reasoning of needing the cash from epic and I feel the results of it have been worth it. And they honored their word to give backers an additional key on the platform of their choice, so here I am. Now on to the actual review.

Seen people comparing this to Xcom 2, which is of course fair in one regard as it is from the guys that made the originals, and not the most fair in another. For one thing they are on different engines, which means an entirely different feel. And for another one of the major differences is that Xcom 2 was directly following Xcom: Enemy Unknown (yes i know, duh, but there is a point here) and as such had a fairly set goal they were going for, where as Phoenix Point is going for their own thing.

For example, the free aim system, and the real bullet trajectory, is a much better option than the 99% misses that xcom EU and 2 are famous for. Another major difference is while it does have a "doom clock" type system as Xcom 2 does, the real threat is the game has a system for the "Aliens" adapting to your combat style. So in Xcom 2, once you saw an enemy type you knew pretty much all you need to to fight it for the rest of the game; here, if you get too comfortable with easy headshots with free aim, they will mutate to get more armor on their head to make that less effective, or will be more resistant to explosions if you are very grenade happy, etc. 

For those of us that played Xcom 2: WotC, there was alot of talk of how the various factions didnt get along and were ready to attack each other as much as the Aliens, and then it was just resolved in like 2 and half missions and nothing really was different than 3 new unit types; this game has its three factions actually have agendas that conflict with each other, up to the point of the factions even going to war with each other over those agendas. Not to harp too much on the disappointing factions of WotC, but remember how, while cool and worked in the new system, the only real reward for improving relations with the factions was new cards, or sometimes another of their unique class unit, and otherwise you could just ignore them and not really impact the game much? Phoenix has different tech trees that are unique to each faction, and you can only get them by earning favor with that faction by doing quests for them, siding with that faction against the others, or by attempting to steal the tech at the cost of upsetting that faction.

To finish comparing them, even though at the start i said it wasnt entirely fair but it is the best reference point, the tactical and strategic elements. For one thing instead of unlimited flight via the Avenger In Xcom 2, the manticore ships have set amounts of fuel per movement and have to able to link paths to be able to move to a location. Another difference is that, as opposed to Xcom 2 where you just sit waiting for something to happen that you go to, Phoenix requires you to actually preform scans of your area to find events and looting areas. Yet another serious difference is that in Xcom 2, the tactical was the heavy focus as the strategic just resulted in modifiers for the missions; Phoenix is a little more strategic minded. Yes it is still choices and popups on the global map that then influence what you can do in the tactical battles, but it is more than just "this enemy type now has armor" or "this mission is now available 3 turns earlier than previously". In this case it is down to choosing between helping this enclave to get favor for this faction which leads to new tech to increase your effectiveness attacking this Pandora base, or doing this time sensitive event over here for different faction thus angering the one faction but receiving a direct reward from the other that then can help you deal with this other Pandora base over here that has been causing issues for this third enclave that you are using for resources and recruitment. It is alot more dense and confusing that Xcom 2's method, which works well for how that game is structured, but overall pays off more, in my opinion, cause you are invested in each micro detail as opposed to just telling your troops which alien to shoot first to get resources for which ever tech you selected first this time around; which in turn adds to replayability more than the set events that are pulled from a fairly static pool.

Overall, I feel this game is at least as good as Xcom 2, and WotC expansion, if not better in several/most regards; and well worth the purchase.
For a more numerical label. Xcom 2 WotC is 7.7-8.9/10 for this type of game and Phoenix Point is at least the same if not a 8-9 /10

I was interested in this game years back when it was announced as I am a huge fan of the modern Xcom & Xcom 2 games. I followed it for a while and then abandoned it like lots of people when they announced the move to Epic. I have totally forgot about it since then and its release just kind of crept up on me as I was playing Empire of Sin. I saw the heavy discounted price tag along with all the advertised DLC/fixes/improvements that developer claimed over the year and decided to take a shot. I am glad I did.

Honestly, I wouldve been happy with just another Xcom clone with a different story and some fresh mechanics to keep me interested. I did not expect to find the combat not just different, but also superior and much more tactical in many ways. At this point I am not that far into the campaign of my first playthrough, and here are my favorite things so far about the game:

- Inventory system with weight and item trading between soldiers. You can find containers on levels that have gear, resources, etc. You loot them for gear that you can distribute among your characters and even trade among them. All items you take into battle can be traded during the combat missions among teammates.
- Default shoot VS Free Aim choosing when attacks. Thats right, you can actually just attack targets the normal by clickin on em and pressing a button, or you can aim your shoots with a mouse as you would in an FPS. There is a whole mechanic behind it based on distance/accuracy/cover/etc. and it really stands out as something unique for this type of genre.
- Ability to Melee with your rifle by just smacking an alien bitch upside the head with it. This is a cool "realistic" addition that I quite enjoy.
- Ammo that actually runs out. Having to decide how much extra to carry with you on missions over other items. If you want to reload, you gotta have an extra clip in your inventory/backpack. This adds realism and strategy.
- Accessories for your armor. When customizing soliders you can add special items to the armor based on the armor pieces they wearin. 
- Enemies body parts as targets provide an entirely new tactical layer when shooting beyond the simple "shoot leg to immobilize". There is a whole deep layer to this that Im not going to fully describe as it would be too long, but it really changes the game when your shots hit different body parts and cause varying effects to the enemies based on that.
- Willpower as a resource for your soldiers in combat. It acts sort of like an energy for skills, but also causes soldiers to "panic" when it runs out. You gots to balance it and there are several factors during combat that both add or subtract to it over the course of battle. An extra layer of tactics to consider.
- Customizable stats in soldier editing screen. Unlike in Xcom, you can also directly edit your soldiers stats (strength, speed, willpower) on top of choosing their abilities as they level up. The experience pool is shared among stats/skills, so you gotta decide which to boost and its another thing to consider.
- You get a vehicle you can bring into combat similar to what Wasteland 3 offers if youve played that. 
- Combat plays out very differently in terms of movement/stealth and action points. You dont activate pods like in Xcom, and your dude will actually stop moving if youre running and happen to run into an enemy you didnt see before. You can then either shoot em or decide whatever else you wanna do. This is much more realistic than Xcom way where your dude will spot the pack of 5 aliens and continue running right up to them because thats where you had initially clicked at. 
- So far I dont see hard Turn Limits in the battles, but it has a soft cap in the way of "stamina" for your soldiers. The more turns you take to end the battle, the more stamina you spend and the more rest your soldiers will need. They will have AP penalties if not well rested, but you can still take them to battle even if you did a long ass one right before. 
- Shot hit % is calculated VERY differently from Xcom. First, you dont actually see neither a % nor a set amount of damage you can do if you roll "hit" on your shot. Each weapon actually fires multiple "shots" and each has a chance to hit. That % isn't shown, but estimates are indicated based on armor and damage potential. This is one of the biggest changes to the game from Xcom and developer describes it as a way to instill "simulation" into the game. I can see where theyre going with this and this new ballistics style really changes up how you play the game and so far I like it.

These are just some of the biggest ways that this game differs from Xcom in what I have noticed playing thus far. So far, I welcome these changes as they seem to instill a deeper sense of tactics, realism, and simulation into the combat. I have not spent much in the actual map layer yet so I cannot comment on that, but I am really enjoying what Im seeing so far. I have not run into any bugs at all yet after playing about 10 missions. 

It appears to me that a lot of the Negative reviews about this game are customers angry at the developer either for delaying Steam release for Epic store, or for their supposed "privacy" violations in the tos or data collections? When you load up the game, it does ask you to let it "collect anonymous data" from you based on system specs, etc. HOWEVER, it clearly gives you an option to Opt Out by simply ticking off the check box. I dont know much else about what went on this past year as I told you I stopped paying attention to the game once it went to Epic. 

If you can look past the actual past of this game and the transgressions of this developer, then I highly recommend this game to anybody whos a fan of Xcom or tactical turn based games. Whether you love Xcom and simply want an alternative to play or feel that Xcom is too "simple" and want a deeper game with more simulating combat tactics, then give this game a chance. For the current discounted price and the included DLC, you really cant go wrong. 

Its clear that whatever state this game was at release that caused so many complaints is now behind it. It plays and runs well without any glitches after over 6 hours of playing and I am having a blast. There is also additional DLC on the horizon and this game is still being developed, balanced, and updated with new content. This gives me something to look forward to as I learn the ins and outs.

 It feels all too familiar for Xcom vets, but it has more than enough newly implemented changes to keep you engaged, interested, and thinking about your next move. I wouldnt be surprised to see many of this games mechanics make it into Xcom 3 whenever that is released. Until then, Ill be playing this and prolly some Xcom 2 as well once I do a couple of playthroughs here and master the final difficulty.

81612312.review:
I never understood what happened with the new XCOM, the art style felt like a Nickleodeon cartoon, and the aliens were just ridiculous. It was all very cute, there was nothing about that game that was even remotely scary the way the old ones were.

Worst of all though, the systems were just kinda dumb. It was a game obsessed with right angles, that rolled a dice whenever you took a shot, and that dice only had two faces - hit or miss - for an exact amount of damage, even though you could clearly see your soldiers sending out waves of bullets. The game would tell you you missed your 95% chance, even as it showed you the bullets clearly impacting the alien that you wanted to hit.

No such tomfoolery here, Phoenix Point is a smarter, more elaborate beast. More simulation and less kids cartoons.

The shooting is smarter, the cover system is smarter, the overwatch is smarter. At the fundamental level it's a better game because it hands you a greater level of control and trusts you to figure it out, instead of cutting corners and making everything strictly rules-based like XCOM did. XCOM was a boardgame, Phoenix Point is a wargame, just like its grandpappy.

It does come with a few caveats though. The writing and voice direction are abysmal, and that's sad because the artstyle is really good, and the factions are delightfully campy, so you really want to immerse yourself in the world. Sadly the cutscenes are just cringy and brutal to watch.

Also the maps are never quite big enough, so it always feels like you’re fighting in a diorama instead of exploring an unknown location. You don’t get the tension that comes with discovery, clearing a dark farmhouse, or dreading whatever is crouched behind the next hedge. XCOM failed to recreate that too, and I don't understand why neither game seems to care. 

When people talk about X-Com, the second thing they'll mention after the countless hours they spent playing it, is the terror. The stuff you remember is night missions where slimy little sectoids would amuse themselves by picking off your poor night blind recruits. Still to this day, no one has made a game to emulate that experience, and in a world where game developers boast of permadeath features and use Dark Souls as a verb, that's extremely ponderous.

I feel like Snapshot should've pushed a lot harder on the worldbuilding, the tension and the horror, but as imperfect as it is, Phoenix Point is still awfully clever about a lot of things that matter, and it's easily the closest we've come to a genuine X-Com ancestor.

81612095.review:
This game deserves better reviews in my opinion. I have played it on Epic for over a year now, trying it here and there after each update, and now with the year one release I think it's in a really good place and I am excited to see how it develops going forwards.

Most of the negative reviews here will compare this to XCom 2 or complain about Epic Games or some random tech issue. I understand that the epic games deal, and if you have tech issues starting the game, that you might be frustrated and leave a negative review. That said, the vast majority of players reading these reviews likely are curious about the game itself. Let me tell you that, as a fan of the original UFO Defense, this is a huge step forwards from XCOM 2.

Why do I prefer it over the latest entry in the XCOM series? Mainly for three reasons.
1- No more bullcrap pod system for enemies.
2- A real action point system
3- A combat system that isn't just a dice roll.

1- The pod system in the modern XCOMs completely changes the way you play once you get used to the game. You inch forward with your first soldier to draw out a pod of enemies then proceed to fight with the rest of your soldier. If you move forwards to far with your last character, you are screwed on your next turn. This is unrealistic and boring.

In phoenix point, the aliens are not acting in pods waiting to be "woken up" but they actually explore and move on their turns and also will move on their own. Xcom 2 tried to address this but failed in my opinion. 

2- Action points are back! Instead of having two big actions like in the modern XCOM games they went back to the original where you have full control over your characters. If you have enough AP you can move, shoot, and then fall back. You can loot off the ground, shoot, and then hide... You have options and moving one square to far into your "2nd action" doesn't completely end your turn for that character. It gives you freedom to make tactical decisions just like in the original xcom.

3- The combat system is honestly the best I've seen in any game like this. It's a big meme that LOL YOU MISSED A 95% SHOT in the new XCOM but it's a meme because it feels like bullshit. Why? Because it is. Your trained soldiers should not miss a point blank shot. It is unrealistic. In this game you have a cone of where your bullets can spread and your shots fall within those cones predictably. This means cover doesn't just effect the dice roll, but it actually acts as cover. If you have a light pole between you and an alien, you might hit that light pole! Even if they aren't ducking right behind it. It's completely realistic and so refreshing compared to the RNG of the modern XCOM games.


This game isn't perfect. In fact, I think XCOM2 has much better mission variety and production values. That said, even with those things I just don't want to play it anymore because I feel like I've figured out the puzzle. I know to creep forward and then wake a pod up and shoot. I know when to take cover and how to bait enemies out to improve my dice rolls. The tactical game in Phoenix Point is much more interesting and dynamic.

This game is like Xenonauts with a better budget. Julian Gollop really recognized what made his original game special over the modern franchise. I am thankful for it. I hope that Snapshot continues to work on it though because, while it's wonderful to play, it sure could use some more personality, something UFO Defense and the new xcom games are dripping with.

Pros:
-Combat system is more fair and more exciting than any other tactical game IMO.
-Action points give you more freedom than in the modern XCOM games.
-No pod system! Enemies move and behave in more realistic ways.
-Geoscape is easy to understand and there are some neat mechanics with factions.
-Enemies evolve! They'll try to counter your tactics by changing as the game goes on.
-I'm a sucker for the aquatic theme of the monsters. Makes me want to go play terror from the deep again!

Cons:
-Lacking mission variety compared to XCOM2.
-Lacking personality. This is probably my biggest gripe. The voice acting, customization, and even environments are pretty dull. You'll want to play this game for the gameplay, not for the personality or graphics. Hopefully that changes one day. Especially with the underwater theme of the creatures... It could have been so much more interesting looking.

EDIT:
I'll add one more con to the game. The ending mission is weak and requires a ton of AOE. Almost out of character from the rest of the game. I love the lovecraftian boss but it's a slog to get there and more of a chore than a fun mission. I can see it ruining an ironman run quickly and I hope it's addressed later.

That said, still the best xcomish game out there and I'm replaying it now after 120 hours. I spent my 120 hours split between two runs, one which I gave up on. I used all the DLC and enjoyed all the lore and missions. Some complain about the frequency of the missions. I agree some of them aren't worth much but honestly, I like having tactical puzzles to just run my guys through. I play it for fun not to rush the ending.

Love the game. Cybernetics and mutations seem tacked on but that's a small complaint. This game deserves more love, full stop.

Welcome to Julian Gollop's job application for XCom 3. They threw around the recognizable names in the marketing quite a bit so I see no sense in not doing the same here. But all I got from the game is that they're testing some ideas, to be pitched for another project.

Overall it's one of those cases where I wished for the neutral recommend button. I definitely don't recommend it for a full price but at a sale you at least won't miss the amount of money you just flushed down the tubes.

The first gut punch actually comes before the game starts. For the first time ever, I read through a license agreement and there is some juicy shit in there. I don't want to go into the exclusivity scandal here - you can do your own research. But the terms and conditions reminded me of it. Not only do they sell player data to anyone who's interested (which is fairly normalized at this point) but they also keep the data as part of future company merger deals which struck me as new. Also, you're forfeiting your right to pursue legal means against the developers for anything. In turn, they more or less painted themselves as rather hostile towards the concept of mods or a workshop. I wouldn't hold my breath on the expectation that this game is fixed by modders.

Anyway, the game itself is to be described as XCom with gimmick testing … on a severe budget. The story is pretty much the same, the only difference is that the invasion is already on earth and has taken root instead of coming from outer space. I did notice that much of the gritty horror aesthetic from the earliest promo material has given way to how XCom 2012 and XCom 2 2016 are looking. I assume it's intentional.

From here it's XCom: You investigate anomalies leading to combat encounters. You research new stuff. You build your base. There is no real visual for base building, just a “card system”, I suppose you could call it. Which is odd to me because the tutorial has you fighting on a map that is your factions base. Fairly detailed, too. Probably scrapped in development somewhere. The enemy develops/mutates along side you but I'm not far enough into the game to see if that's truly unique or similar to how XCom throws ever more potent enemies at you every month. There is also diplomacy with other factions but for me that just led to more combat encounters, so yeah. All in all, the impression of great ideas vs. cut-corners in development shines through during every aspect of the game. And while dialing back on what you can achieve is the reality in most game developments today, the "producer's razor" is really palpable even to the layman here. 

Character customization and by extension the players emotional attachment to their band of schmucks doesn't go as far as in XCom. With what I believe to be a bug, everyone keeps their helmet on even when I explicitly say not to. More realistic, I guess, to have everyone look the same status of battle-ready on a battle field but I would like to properly suffer with my goon squad in their moments of heroism and incompetence. For that I need to be able to tell who's who. Right now I can't. It's a really petty gripe, I know. But we're on the topic of comparing to XCom. So there you go.

On the subject of things that work, the real-time aiming does function as intended and is the thing the game correctly praises itself on. It's very much necessary, too, because enemies soak up a lot of damage. So you want to aim for the head manually every time since your pawns do not know how to aim for shit.

Vehicles and giant boss monsters feel properly implemented. Although their behavior becomes easily readable very quickly. Most maps don't accomodate their range and abilities, either. However, that's again a minor gripe for XCom veterans.

The combat sections do feel a little sluggish. Not because of performance but due to many individual details like model animation, camera controls, unskippable movement sequences. It all comes together to recreate a segment from the behind-the-scenes of XCom's (2012) development where the lead designer talked about how their first prototype was almost unbearably slow, forcing them to cut down on action time, animations and camera controls to make their game more “crisp”. This refinement hasn't happened here and the game could use something like the “don't waste my time”-mod for XCom 2.

I am still wondering what they did with all their epic store extra money and one full year of potential additional development. So far the game does not show me any brilliance, just a focus test of features that, I am sure, will make a reprise in other games. Phoenix Point is not bad by any means. Just not grand either. Another one to tide you over until XCom 3.

81595655.review:
[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]

[i]I am on the Phoenix Point Community Council; a focus group that gets to play early builds, to complain to the devs about AI, and to ask for things they want (Behemoths) and don't want (OP stuff), and to vociferously sulk when their brilliant ideas are neglected.

I also help out with the official wiki (http://wiki.phoenixpoint.com) and I'm the author of the Mentaculus (http://wiki.phoenixpoint.com/Getting_Started) (former 'A Comprehensive Guide for Phoenix Point or an attempt at one'). 

(Unfortunately) I have not received any payment from Snapshot, or from anybody else for doing any of the stuff I have done in connection with the game; apparently nowadays you can get paid for playing games while people watch you but I don't have the inclination for exposing myself to that kind of voyeurism. 
 
I did get this Steam key, which was offered as a token of appreciation to all non-backers on the CC. [/i]

[h1]Time spent with the game[/h1]

I bought Phoenix Point on the EGS a year ago and it's the only game I have been seriously playing since then. I got around 700 hours, counting the beta testing; for comparison I got around +300hours with Xcom2, around 1500hours with XCom EW across different platforms, 70h with Xenonauts, and about a short lifetime with the original X-Coms and JA2. 

I have been play-testing beta versions of this YOE release for the past few weeks, which is why I decided to do this review.

I will focus on what is different between the YOE, the previous 1.8 Arkham build (the last version on the EGS before the YOE, and on which most other reviews are based) and the version on release. 

If you are interested in an in-depth look at the gameplay and mechanics, please check out the Mentaculus http://wiki.phoenixpoint.com/Getting_Started. I tried my best to keep it spoiler free. Please note that many changes from Polaris/YOE have not been incorporated yet.

[h1]Review[/h1]

[u]The short version[/u]

PP was very rough on release. Some of us liked it anyway (I proclaimed it a 'masterpiece' in December 2019 and got into a very rich and productive discussion that sometimes resulted in harsh language being exchanged) for what it managed to do and more for what it attempted, but it wasn't in any state where I could recommend it to someone who, well, likes their games kinda finished. 

A year later and after beta testing for a few weeks the last YOE build, which is hopefully at least as good as what is getting released, I'm happy to recommend it to the general public. 

[u] What has changed [/u]

The changes since the Epic release on December 3rd 2019 are too numerous to list in a comprehensive manner. It's the kind of stuff you would expect from a 'good' early access release ('good' as in it allowed to play the game from start to finish) and a proper release, but to highlight the main ones:

- Pandoran evolution has been completely redone, so that (depending on difficulty) more dangerous creatures appear later and they come in different strains, and variations within the strains that change from playthrough to playthrough 
- Pandoran deployment has been redone as well, so that now you always get a mix of higher and lower evolved Pandorans 
- Exploration has been redone so that now havens and a special base structure gradually reveal surrounding Points of Interest, and there are 17 bases spread around the globe in fixed locations that you can activate almost from the start of the game
- The Doomsday Clock has been changed from an abstract 'oneiric delirium index' to a decreasing 'human population census', so you can slow it down by activating bases near the mist and protecting the havens there
- Skills, abilities, perks, weapons and armors have been rebalanced. Particularly speed has been reduced by about ¼ - ⅓. 
- Difficulty has been reworked so that Rookie and Veteran are easier
- The difficulty curve is smoother. Right now the game starts easy and becomes harder (at least until somewhere around mid-game where your operatives can become too powerful)
- UI has been much improved, there are also stats for soldiers, memorial for the fallen, and end of game stats. 

The Polaris/YOE update has:

- Overdue bug fixes (like with opening crates and dashing/jetpacking…) 
- A proper scripted tutorial and ongoing context tutorial similar to the one in Wasteland 3
- A reworked tech tree for Phoenix Point; there are 4 new weapons and a deployable shield (and they are all great!) and some minor stuff
- Drastically reduces modifiers (bonus and malus) to speed and accuracy from armor, and damage buffs as well as some other effects from personal perks. This is a major change as, for example, it makes heavies in heavy armor more accurate, snipers less accurate and cuts on the meta-builds. You can really feel the difference now with the heavies wielding the new autocannon, which is something that many players were asking for 
- There are some improvements to the AI, but less than what was asked for. 

[h1]Conclusions[/h1]

There are many things that PP does that have ruined other XComs and X-Coms for me:

- Realistic [b]ballistics[/b] (vs abstract die rolls), the [b]willpower system[/b] (use of skills and abilities ties into morale), [b]confined RNG[/b] in the tactical battles (the only element of chance is in the trajectory of the projectiles, everything else is deterministic), the [b]strategic layer[/b] (though it could use some improvements in a few departments, it's realized well enough so that you feel like you are part of a world that doesn't spin entirely around you), the [b]flexibility and variety of gameplay styles[/b] (everything can be approached and done in a myriad different ways, both in the tactical and in the strategic layer), [b]mature setting[/b], and the [b]lore[/b]... (the [b]art and the design[/b] is mostly outstanding). 

There are, however, a few things that need to be said: 

- PP is, in essence, a [b]table top or a miniatures game with ballistics, not a military simulation[/b]. Many players are not happy with certain design choices like absence of bullet drop, no penalty to accuracy from movement, lack of suppression fire mechanics, etc. and the presence of "power fantasy" skills, many of which are more like spells in disguise. 

- It is [b]not a remake of the original X-Com[/b], nor is it really a mix of the old originals and the Firaxis iterations. For better and for worse, [b]Phoenix Point does its own thing[/b].

- The ruleset is fairly complex and some of it is a bit counterintuitive… Which is why I started working on a guide that eventually became the Mentaculus. The good news is that the [b]Year One Edition/Polaris update comes with a first class tutorial and ongoing context tutorials[/b]. 

- There are still plenty of things that can be improved upon and some stuff that still bears correcting, like [b]the AI[/b] (particularly for human friendlies and enemies), some [b]balance issues[/b] here and there (OP skills/combinations/weapons; damage over time effects that can be OP, annoying or frustrating, depending, which side of the equation you are on in each case), [b]logistics[/b] (you can instantly teleport items between operatives on different continents, if you are willing to put up with the tedium),[b] diplomacy[/b] (counterintuitive and not sufficiently developed; it's too easy to become allied with all the factions, even as you continue to raid them for aircrafts and resources) and there is room for [b]more enemy types/abilities[/b], and for more [b]reactivity[/b] 

These issues and a lot of other things are being worked on - it's called the Year One Edition for a reason- , and to be fair none of them are game breaking. 

I want to stress that I would feel differently if the game was just another clone or a reskin of something that has already been done to death, but, love it or hate it, with Phoenix Point you are getting a gaming experience that you simply can't get anywhere else at the moment.

81555556.review:
OK, full disclosure, I’m an original Fig backer who stuck with PP through the Epic deal and joined the Community Council because I wanted to help the devs fix & improve the game.  So I see myself, like all the Community Councillors, as a critical friend – someone who can see the huge potential in this game, but who doesn’t hold back from telling the devs in extreme detail why it isn’t great yet.

Because, let’s face it, when this game was released on Dec 3rd 2019, it was a mess!  The Tutorial sucked, it was really difficult to figure out how the game worked, and if you played it the way that most people played, it generated a difficulty spike that went through the roof in the midgame.

But all credit to the devs: they listened.  They set up a feedback tool on Canny and created the Community Council: a panel of players drawn from all ends of the spectrum, dedicated to telling them exactly what was wrong with the game and suggesting ways to fix it.  So the game released on Steam is lightyears ahead of the game that was originally released on Epic. 

I unashamedly love this game – though it should be obvious by now that I’m not an uncritical fanboy.  It has the potential to be the best TBS on the market and has effectively retired XCOM for me in its current iterations.  

Compared to XCOM (and let’s face it, everyone compares it to XCOM), its Tactical Layer is much more flexible.  Its AP system is so granular that you can do almost anything you like in whatever order you like (ie. Move, Fire, Move again, recharge your APs and Move some more).  Its ballistic firing system and Location Targeting Reticule give you all kinds of tactical options when firing (do you shoot its head off, take out its weapon, or go for the higher percentage chance to hit?).  The Will Point system gives you even more tactical options and is a pretty decent approximation of Morale (though others would disagree).  Your Squaddies are never limited in what or how much they can carry – you are perfectly at liberty to arm a Sniper with an HMG, but if you do so (s)he’ll suffer penalties for using a weapon (s)he’s not used to that’s too heavy to carry: but you can always choose to multiclass into a Sniper/Heavy and merge the benefits of both classes.  The enemy as it evolves presents different challenges, and while there isn’t quite enough variety for some, the devs are constantly adding new enemies into the mix.  

The Strategic Layer looks more limited from a superficial standpoint, but when you dig into it, you discover an open sandbox of a world where you’re faced with multiple branching decisions and rarely enough resources (until the endgame, when you can end up with too many if you know what you’re doing).  Unlike XCOM, the game doesn’t hold your hand, so a lot of this is hidden under the hood.  You’re never presented with a Mission List from which you can only choose one.  Instead, you have to assess the strategic options on the Geoscape and weigh them up for yourself.  Do you respond to that call for help from a Haven on the other side of the continent? Or do you explore that scavenging site to get resources? Do you get the resources you need through Trade?  Or do you commit your limited manpower to that Story/DLC/Diplomatic Mission that is waiting to be resolved?  All of these are possible, but if you don’t prioritise – or if you try to do them all – you will be overstretched and inevitably fail.  So you’re constantly weighing up your options and making difficult decisions, even though at times it’s not obvious that you’re doing so.  

But though this is the game’s biggest strength, it’s also its biggest weakness.  The design philosophy of PP is NOT to restrict player’s options wherever possible.  And this has led at times to some poor (in my view) design decisions.  The most glaring is in Squad Skills.  As I’ve already said, it’s possible to multi-class characters, which opens up a range of extremely powerful synergies – but because there seems to be an ideological resistance to imposing limitations on skills, some of these synergy builds can get stupidly OP.  Put simply, if you know how to exploit the meta, you can build a Terminator capable of wiping out the enemy’s ability to strike back in the first turn of a mission.  This to my mind is game-breaking and hasn’t been fixed yet: so experienced players who know how to exploit the meta have to play with self-restrictions to keep the endgame challenging.  It’s the classic XCOM Inverse Difficulty Curve writ large, and I still don’t understand why the devs won’t grasp the nettle and fix it.  

So I play with a series of self-limitations which keep the game challenging and fun, but it’s definitely not ideal.  On the other side of that coin, I can point you to any number of players on the forums who still complain today that the game is too hard, even on the easier levels.  So you can never satisfy everyone.  To my mind, the best way to solve this conundrum would be Second Wave Options, but they don’t seem likely any time soon.  I’m hoping that the modding community will step in and do what the devs either can’t – or don’t want to – do, but I’m not holding my breath. 

All that said: this is still a very good, very enjoyable game, and it’s getting better all the time.  

What the Epic haters never want to acknowledge is that far from taking the money and running, Snapshot did the exact opposite.  By taking the Epic deal, this mid-weight Indie secured its long-term future, ensuring that it would be around to support and improve the game for years to come; then committed itself to doing just that.  It set up several ways to get feedback from its players and has been acting on that feedback ever since, albeit too slowly for some.  It even sends out regular updates telling you what requests have been acted on and how.  And far from f!ing over any backers who didn’t want to follow it onto Epic, it compensated them for the inconvenience with more than a year’s free DLC (since I believe Festering Skies is also part of the deal).  

It’s a sad fact of life in the gaming world that virtually no game is released in a fully polished state because there’s never enough time – and the people who decry a company for crunching its staff to meet impossible deadlines are often (but not always) the same people who troll a company for releasing an incomplete game, or for delaying the release beyond its advertised time.  Snapshot chose to square that circle by releasing the game in a post-beta state and using the time bought by the Epic deal to refine it into a game which – though it still has some annoying bugs and balancing issues – is a breath of fresh air in the TBS games market.  Whether you think that was a dick move is entirely up to you, but I certainly don’t think the players who waited for the Steam release are the ones who got a bad deal out of this.

So while the game you’re getting on Steam is not as slickly polished as XCOM - and JA2 fans will take great delight in telling you all the reasons why it’s not as brilliant as JA2 - it’s still a good game that deserves to be taken on its own merits, rather than for the way its creators ensured they stayed afloat to get it this far.

Just don’t try playing it the way you play XCOM, 'cos if you do you’ll get slaughtered.  And for more on that, see my ‘Helpful Hints for XCOM Players’ in the Steam Guides for this game.
