Phoenix Point: Year One Edition is a turn-based strategy game with global strategy elements from the creator of X-COM and you'll notice this immediately. Phoenix Point is like XCOM in many ways. 
First off, Phoenix Point was released one year ago exclusively on the Epic Store. Now it is available on steam with all of it's DLC's and a big discount. 

The story is told through dynamic pictures and voice-overs. The Pandoravirus broke out. People infected are going to mutate into some kind of monsters. It starts interesting enough for a strategy game. 
There also seem to be different fractions in the game but I can't tell more about that yet. 

But the most important thing are the turn-based fights. As I said, you'll immediately feel right at home if you've played X-COM before. It basically plays like XCOM with a few different and new mechanics and a few changes overall. For example, your units have 4 AP instead of 2. Also, in XCOM when you move within a blue zone, no matter where exactly, 1 AP is used. Here, you can move halfway through the blue zone, stop, and move on. If your unit is moving and an enemy appears within the line of sight, your unit will stop. This lets you react accordingly to the situation. This is one of the many improvements compared to X-COM. 

Another new mechanic is called "free shot". If you want to shoot a target, you can decide whether your unit shoots automatically or you do it like in an FPS. The camera changes to first-person and you can aim and shoot by yourself. This is an exciting new feature because it goes hand in hand with a new mechanic called "realistic ballistics". This means, that objects that cover certain parts of the body will protect the unit. So, let's say there is a wall between your character and the enemy. The wall covers half of the enemy's body. If you shoot, you can't hit the parts of the body that are covered. 

Another thing PP does differently is if comrades are within your line of fire. There is a chance you'll hit them partially. This is nothing new to the genre in general but compared to the last XCOM games. 

In XCOM, if no enemy is in sight, you'll hear them and get a notification that shows you where they approximately are. In PP, this is the same but you get to see exactly where they are just not if it's an enemy and which one or a friendly unit. You also can hear what they do but not if a shot was successful, etc. 

You can take up to 8 units on a mission AND a vehicle. Units can be transported with it and vehicles can move and shot without a unit in them.

Every unit can carry some items with them. You can carry up to three weapons, items, etc. with you and immediately use them. Let's say you have a weapon and additional ammo. Reloading does not cost AP if you carry ammo in one of them. Additionally, every unit has a backpack (not visible). How much they can carry is limited and if you have ammo in the backpack, you'll need to spend AP for reloading. This is a small detail but can be the difference between shoot or getting shot. 

Aside from the turn-based battles, there is Global strategy involved. It resembles X-COM's base management. You also have a base you'll need to take care of, upgrade, etc. You can move around with your space plane and discover new places. Every move takes time (flying to a new place takes X hours, etc.). All of the options available seem to be detailed and just as complex as in XCOM but I can't give a final judgment about that since I didn't play that much yet.

Units gain EXP after every mission. Every level up gives them skill points you can spend to unlock new abilities or upgrades.  You also get skill points after every mission which will go into a shared pool. Every unit can use these.

Loading times are pretty long. Especially loading times BEFORE a mission are very long compared to XCOM even on a good rig. This can be annoying. There also was a bug at release which didn't let you activate the DLC's even though you own them. They fixed it a few hours after release but it still sucks because you need to start a new campaign to use them. It doesn't matter for anyone buying the game now, but this is something that should NOT happen considering the game was already out on epic. 

Overall Phoenix Point: Year One Edition is perfect for anyone loving X-COM and turn-based strategy games in general. I can't recommend it enough. The turn-based fights are detailed with much love and bring in new and exciting mechanics. After playing approx. 2 hours, you can easily tell which level of quality and detail this game has. But to be fair, 2 hours isn't enough to go into detail about everything (e.g. global strategy). All the options seem detailed and promise to be just as "complex" as in X-COM (if you want to call it complex at all).

I will update my review after playing more accordingly but this sure as hell get's a recommendation especially since it's on sale. It's definitely worth 25€/USD. Just get it already, you'll love it!

81542125.review:
[i]Phoenix Point[/i] is a child of [b]Julian Gollop[/b], the creator of the original [i]X-COM: UFO Defense[/i] (1994), and his Bulgarian studio [i]Snapshot Games[/i]. You will find yourself in a familiar situation: lead the Earth defence, this time against [i]Pandoravirus[/i] and its alien-looking offsprings, [i]pandorans[/i].

[h3][i]X-COM[/i][/h3]
[b]One of the core concepts of the original is the broad scope[/b]: turn-based tactics expanded with a strategy together with role-playing elements and unfold the narrative with research. All [i]X-COM[/i] descendants try to find the essence of its identity but many don't acknowledge the [b]reversed difficulty curve[/b] immersion. You start in a desperate situation but every day, every looted alien tech get you closer to victory and makes even a failed mission success and enjoyment.

The [i]Firaxis's[/i] re-creations chased the [i]X-COM[/i] spirit but not always the design. Some of the game’s systemic elements were replaced by discrete choices but each of them was meaningful and kept player in control. Solomon's streamlined titles were able to preserve the scope of the original and the rewarding feeling of progress.
[b][i]Phoenix Point[/i] inclines toward more complexity[/b].

[h3]Ballistics[/h3]
The major [i]Phoenix Point[/i] appeal is the [b]first-person free-aim shooting[/b] with [b]realistic bullet trajectories[/b]. Additional tactical options lies in [b]destructible environment[/b] and the [b]location-targeting system[/b]. Alas, the [b]intriguing concept clashes with clumsy design[/b]:

Effects are bound to crippling a location, not just hitting, and are quite limited: weapon unusable, disabling related ability, [i]Movement[/i] or [i]Will Power[/i] penalty. There are no damage multipliers or temporal effects like losing action points, decreasing accuracy, falling, or dropping a weapon... Enemies with strong skills are very susceptible to location targeting, e.g.: [i]Siren's[/i] head with [i]Mind Control[/i], but against many others, you are just pouring bullets into the same spot (even though the body part has been already destroyed) because you have already lowered armour rating there or it is easiest to hit.

The ballistics also diminishes the effectiveness of cover dependent on the attacking angle. The decision to add melee weapons, or rather high mobility to make those weapons viable, makes the issue more apparent.

[h3]Sense of Progression[/h3]
[i]Phoenix Point[/i] strikes off on its own path with [b]marginal equipment upgrades[/b]. You rarely get anything clearly better than what you had before. It is an interesting approach which gives you more options but it has a price: [i]Phoenix Point[/i] with its [b]heavy emphasis on soldiers[/b] is more [i]RPG[/i] and less [i]strategy[/i] than [i]Firaxis[/i] titles. The game offers a decent amount of classes. One skill per level may seem like a poor relative to [i]Firaxis's[/i] characters but the disappointment quickly fades once you will realise that you can multi-class.

Your soldiers will gradually become [i]Gods of Destruction[/i] as [b]right skills can completely change the situation from desperate to trivial[/b]. To counter your super-powers [i]pandorans[/i] will grow thick shells and become bullet-sponges with several hundred to higher thousands [i]HP[/i] and even the basic enemy, [i]arthron[/i], will rip through the heaviest armour and kill your best guy in one turn. The lethality results in [i]Blitzkrieg[/i] scenarios: [i]"must kill them before they can act"[/i]. While it keeps battles challenging it is prone to unfair deaths and diminishes the sense of progression.

[h3]Randomness[/h3]
Missions are randomly generated based on the objective and hostile faction: [i]pandorans[/i], mutated [i]forsaken[/i], cyberware [i]pure[/i] or fellow humans. [b]The game will randomly pick some enemies and spread them around the map without any logic.[/b] This wonky design of making everything random and [i]different[/i] leads to the feeling of everything being the same.

The mid and late-game is a slog as you are locked in the neverending heaven defences. While the game knows a few mission types, most fall to the annoying [i]"timer"[/i] category and heaven defence is its prominent member: you must do the mission immediately and you don't defend against [i]pandorans[/i], you have to kill enemies fast before they destroy a facility. Unfortunately, enemies may spawn next to the objective which you are supposed to defend giving you no chance to prevent a mission failure the first or second turn. A [b]high level of randomness[/b] sometimes plays in your favour and you are done within 2 turns, another time you are killed by an undetectable sniper. Some enemies are well-thought with their strengths and weaknesses, like face-hugging [i]fragger[/i], others are absurd: artillery which can pacificate your troops with a single lucky volley fire cross the whole map.

[h3]Strategy[/h3]
Faithful to the original, you will manage bases, research, manufacturing and training recruits. Unlike [i]X-COM[/i], where you had to cover the globe with bases and radars to scan for randomly appearing UFOs, [i]Phoenix Point[/i] [b]generate the globe with all possible mission locations when you start the campaign[/b]. Those are revealed around bases with active radar or by visiting nearby friendly heavens. For some strange reason, all locations serve as gas stations for your aircraft. As you explore them you get a random event: a mission or just resources covered with a bit of well-written storytelling.

Three ideologically distinct rival factions are what was left from our civilization: authoritative [i]New Jericho[/i], anarcho-syndicalist commune of [i]Synedrion[/i] and theocratic [i]Disciples of Anu[/i]. None of them is morally better than the others and each of them offers unique technologies and character classes. Sadly, [b]diplomacy is eviscerated to raiding outposts[/b] and special [i]"graduating"[/i] missions.

Do you remember [i]X-Com 2[/i] and its [i]cash/intel/alloys[/i] with a separate way of acquisition and usage to make the strategy more engaging? [i]Phoenix Point[/i] uses three easily swappable resources: [i]food[/i], [i]material[/i] and [i]tech[/i]. You can produce only [i]food[/i] and you are forced for a [b]pointless trade[/b]. It is hard to believe that such veteran designer as Julian Gollop wouldn't immediately see that it is the same thing as having only one resource with the added chore.

It is not the only issue with the peculiar economy: the price of a new aircraft is barely equivalent to equipping two soldiers. Strangely, 90% weapons will be automatically destroyed even with a head-shot of the owner prohibiting you to loot it. Even ammo for the basic weapons is quite expensive and will cost you appr. 50% of mission rewards.

Overall, the strategic layer of [i]Phoenix Point[/i] feels like a placeholder. It somehow works but the obvious and ignored design flaws are depressing. [i]Snapshot[/i] even made the situation worse by the recent re-design of thematic Lovecraftian progression-meter to a [i]Doomsday Clock[/i].

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]
March 2019: Julian Gollop announced 1-year [i]Epic[/i] store exclusivity. I appreciate [i]Epic[/i] support but I understand why many backers feel betrayed. To avoid the tension [i]Snapshot[/i] closed communication. [i]Phoenix Point[/i] has fresh ideas but feels like being designed by people who don't speak to each other. Some parts are outright woeful, some others just do not fit to the rest of the game in any logical manner. Yet, among all Firaxis's progeny [i]Phoenix Point[/i] is one of the best but frequently wide where it should be deep.

91325623.review:
This review is taken from a point of view of someone who recently bought the game (April 2021) and from someone looking for something to scratch the XCom itch.

Like XCom, the game consists of both a strategic layer - or Geoscape - and the tactical layer. I will cover both and then mention some overall game play elements.

The strategic game is, in my opinion, superior to the recent XCom reboots in every way. It is not simply and random RNG excuse for supplies or a few story mission placements but there is actual game play value in the layer. Later in the game, it can take a bit of getting used to since so many things are going on, but I feel the game did a very good job on this aspect of the game.

The tactical layer, however, is where the game finds itself lacking a bit. First off, the maps are very limited and not randomly generated. As the game is much longer than an XCom play through, this can make things a bit tedious and feeling representative as you go through the missions. I do like that the aliens are spread over the map, active since the beginning of the mission and not sitting around in 'pods' waiting for you to discover and pick apart at your whim.

Overall though, the game lacks any kind of progression curve like you find in XCom. Most of the research is rather useless and makes no sense for many items (why do I need to research an alien to unlock shotguns in the year 2047?). Furthermore, there really is no progression tech wise. Most weapons are similar in the game with slight variation in their stats (one offers higher damage and range, while one may offer lower damage, shorter range and armor penetration but neither is necessarily better than the other). The lack of progression in weapons is rather peculiar considering all the aliens in the game have a progression as the game goes on (most aliens progressing through five levels). This does keep the game a challenge throughout, but I feel they could have had some kind of progression to at least keep up with the alien progression throughout the game.

I do like that the game has a bit more complexity than XCom but some of it is there for the sake of being there. For example, in 2021, there is really no need in a tactical game of soldiers to have to manage ammo inventory. It adds nothing to the game and is nothing more than a tedious step for the sake of being there. In a RPG fine, but not a game where you are managing 12-24 soldiers.

To conclude, the game does offer an alternative XCom experience, though with many enough difference you should not play like XCom. Is the game bad? No. Like all games, including XCom, it has it's places it does well and others that could use improvement and therefore, if what I mentioned above would be okay with you in a game, than I would recommend purchasing it.

91195792.review:
Great game. While the reflexive response of most people seems to be comparing it to XCOM (which isn't a bad thing per say) there are plenty of things setting it apart from being an out and out XCOM clone. 

One of the things that stick out the most to me is the fact that you only have to make sacrifices/trade-offs regarding what missions you take and which you don't if you don't have enough soldiers/aircraft built up, rather than a static pick 1 of 3 like in XCOM. While this is balanced by the fact that travel times exist and you aren't guaranteed to be able to reach a mission in time (if your aircraft is on the other side of the world or something, for example) as well as the potential for a ton of active missions popping up at once, I really like the fact that my ability to respond at any given time is something dependent on the effort I've put in developing and such rather than a static value.

This also means that just because you have a capped out A or B team, developing more units and squads has actual value as even half a dozen or more teams can be genuinely useful rather than just more units you developed just because. It really feels like your developing into more and more of a powerhouse as the game goes on and your ranks swell to dozens of soldiers that actively see combat rather than just a rotation of the same 6-10 doing everything.

Something else I really like is that weapons don't have a real linear development tree, which makes building up a varied arsenal both viable and important.  Instead of the blunt this is better than that of XCOM different versions of the same weapon class excel against different enemies and in different situations. Accuracy, Armoring shredding potential, firing AP cost, Damage per shot, type of damage (out of conventional, virus, paralyze), number of shots per burst, and even the cost of ammunition are all things to consider. This is something that extends to armor as well, seeing as different types give different bonuses with focuses on protection, accuracy bonuses, stealth bonuses, movement, etc.

Leveling up an individual soldier is also quite a developed and in depth process, with things like hybrid classes giving a tremendous amount of a possible variations regarding a units skill set. With assignable points both from level ups and as flat gains for every mission a unit takes part in, its possible to unlock every skill (for a unit's given main/secondary class) and max all 3 stats given enough time, and although that is a very long winded process, the difference between a recruit and a fully improved soldier is tremendous and (given how long it takes) something that feels well and truly earned when you finally work your way up to it.

While i could go into other things ranging from the shooting system to the almost dead space style of killing your enemies limb by limb, I've already ranted enough and i feel like plenty of other people have touched on those things.
